title: Blackbird Marsh Trail
listingDescription: Hike a 0.44 mile scenic loop that connects to Fort Pickens Campground Loop A and the Florida National Scenic Trail.

images.altText: A sign marks the start of the Blackbird Marsh Trail
images.title: Blackbird Marsh Trail
images.caption: Blackbird Marsh Trail

bodyText:
This flat, sandy trail is 0.44 miles total, with resting points and interpretive markers where birds and other wildlife may be observed. 

Visitors may begin the Blackbird Marsh Trail about 160 yards from Loop A at the Fort Pickens campground. There is only one parking spot at the trailhead, additional parking is available at the restroom facility. 

The Blackbird Marsh Trail also connects to the Florida National Scenic Trail and social trails leading to Pensacola Bay. 

Trailhead Locations:

  • Fort Pickens Campground Loop A, north side
  • Florida National Scenic Trail - between Battery Langdon and Campground Loops B-E

Duration: 15-30 minutes
audioDescription: Blackbird Marsh Loop Trail. 109 words.From the side of the campground this broad smooth sandy path heads through low brush and cattails into scattered pines and live oaks beyond. At the start of the trail is a sign giving distances to Bayside Beach Access (0.3 miles), Campground Loop B-E (0.3 to 0.6 miles) and Fort Pickens via Florida National Scenic Trail (1.5 miles). Text reads, "This half mile loop trail connects with the Florida National Scenic Trail providing pedestrian access to the resources and facilities of the Fort Pickens area. Hiking, biking, and pets on leash permitted."To the left of the sign is a dog waste station. End of Description.

title: Brackenridge Accessible Trail Beach Access
listingDescription: At this point, visitors can exit the fully accessible Brackenridge Accessible Trail and venture down to the waters of the Santa Rosa Sound.

images.altText: Shore line of Naval Live Oaks
images.title: Brackenridge Beach Access
images.caption: Brackenridge Beach Access

bodyText: The Brackenridge Nature Trail is a 0.3-mile boardwalk loop trail located in the Naval Live Oaks Area. At this point, visitors can exit the Brackenridge Accessible Trail and venture down to the coast of the Santa Rosa Sound. The shallow water of Santa Rosa Sound is a great place to swim, snorkel, or kayak.
audioDescription: The boardwalk trail makes a T intersection. The left point of the T leads down a short ramp onto the earthen trail. The Brackenridge Nature Trail is a 0.3-mile boardwalk loop trail located in the Naval Live Oaks Area. At this point, visitors can exit the fully accessible Brackenridge Accessible Trail and venture down to the coast of the Santa Rosa Sound. The shallow water of Santa Rosa Sound is a great place to swim, snorkel or kayak.

title: Brackenridge Accessible Trailhead
listingDescription: A fully accessible 0.3 mile boardwalk loop with interpretive exhibits. This boardwalk trail also provides access to the full Brackenridge Loop Trail (additional 0.5 mile) which is not fully accessible.

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service panel with the title, "Brackenridge Trail." Boardwalk through trees in the background.
images.caption: Brackenridge Trailhead

bodyText: Located next to the Gulf Islands National Seashore Headquarters, is the entrance to the Brackenridge Accessible Trailhead. It begins in the park's Naval Live Oak Area, heads west 0.3 miles, and exits at the Santa Rosa Sound shoreline. This fully accessible trail leads to 30-foot-wide wooden deck and benches that overlooks the Santa Rosa Sound. This is a great place to photograph the sunset or view wildlife. The trailhead also provides access to the full Brackenridge Loop Trail (additional 0.5 mile) which is not fully accessible.
audioDescription: Located next to the Gulf Islands National Seashore Headquarters, is the entrance to the Brackenridge Accessible Trailhead. It begins in the park's Naval Live Oak Area, heads west 0.3 miles, and exits at the Santa Rosa Sound shoreline. This fully accessible trail leads to 30-foot-wide wooden deck and benches that overlooks the Santa Rosa Sound. This is a great place to photograph the sunset or view wildlife. The trailhead also provides access to the full Brackenridge Loop Trail (additional 0.5 mile) which is not fully accessible.

title: Brackenridge Loop Trail Observation Deck
listingDescription: A scenic observation deck looking out towards the Santa Rosa Sound.

images.altText: A wooden deck and benches overlook the Santa Rosa Sound.
images.title: Brackenridge Observation Deck
images.caption: Brackenridge Observation Deck

bodyText: Located behind the Gulf Islands National Seashore Headquarters, is the entrance to the Brackenridge Loop Trail Observation Deck. The deck located in the park's Naval Live Oak Area, is a 30-feet-wide and encompasses benches and outdoor exhibits that overlook the Santa Rosa Sound. This is a great place to photograph the sunset or view wildlife. The trailhead also provides access to the full Brackenridge Loop Trail (additional 0.5 mile) which is not fully accessible.
audioDescription: Located behind the Gulf Islands National Seashore Headquarters, is the entrance to the Brackenridge Loop Trail Observation Deck. The deck located in the park's Naval Live Oak Area, is a 30-feet-wide and encompasses benches and outdoor exhibits that overlook the Santa Rosa Sound. This is a great place to photograph the sunset or view wildlife. The trailhead also provides access to the full Brackenridge Loop Trail (additional 0.5 mile) which is not fully accessible.

title: Brackenridge Loop Trailhead
listingDescription: Visitors can depart the fully accessible boardwalk trail and venture out onto the 0.5-mile Brackenridge Loop Trail (not fully accessible). This loop trail connects with the Fishing Trail and an observation point.

images.altText: A boardwalk in the woods makes a right-angle turn. From the turn, an earthen trail extends into the forest.
images.caption: Brackenridge Earthen Trailhead North

bodyText: Visitors can depart the fully accessible Brackenridge Boardwalk Trail and venture onto the 0.5-mile Brackenridge Loop Trail. This trail is not fully accessible. It connects to the Fishing Trail and an Brackenridge observation deck.
audioDescription: Visitors can depart the fully accessible Brackenridge Boardwalk Trail and venture onto the 0.5-mile Brackenridge Loop Trail. This trail is not fully accessible. It connects to the Fishing Trail and an Brackenridge observation deck.

title: Brackenridge Nature Trail
listingDescription: Explore coastal forest on an accessible boardwalk or venture off to extend your hike on the Brackenridge Nature Trail.

images.altText: Two boardwalk paths diverge into the sunny woods.
images.title: Brackenridge Nature Trail
images.caption: Brackenridge Nature Trail loop

bodyText:
The Brackenridge Nature Trail is an accessible loop trail located directly behind Gulf Islands National Seashore Headquarters on Gulf Breeze Parkway. At the trailhead, there is a 30 foot wide wooden deck and benches that provide picturesque views of the Santa Rosa Sound and the Pensacola Bay Bridge. The boardwalk loop traverses through coastal forest and past several waysides detailing wildlife found in the area. Bird calls can be heard year round, if you are patient enough to stop and listen.

The fully accessible portion of the trail is 0.3 miles total. Visitors may choose to extend their hike and complete a second loop found directly off the accessible boardwalk, adding 0.5 miles to make the trail a figure-8. For an even further extension, visitors may connect the Brackenridge figure-8 loop to the Fishing Trail.

Visitors may park in the lot directly in front of the headquarters building in Naval Live Oaks. Though there is no fee for entry, gates to this area open at at 7am and close at 5pm. 

Duration: 15-30 minutes
audioDescription: A boardwalk trail extends in two directions into the woods, forming a loop as it passes waysides and benches.

title: Brown's Pond Trail
listingDescription: This 2 mile out-and-back trail is wide and sandy, which serves its purpose as a fire break for controlled burns. Look for Brown's Pond and wildlife near the trailhead.

images.altText: A pond stands with trees throughout.
images.title: Brown's Pond Trail
images.caption: Brown's Pond Trail

bodyText:
This 2.0 mile out-and-back trail can be started the dirt parking area on Reservation Road, which is a residential area. The east side of the loop is a clearly distinguished, sandy fire break that will take you all the way to Highway 98. There is a side trail off the main Brown's Pond Trail that is much narrower and winding, and two join near the end of the main trail. This trail also intersects with the Beaver Pond, Old Quarry, and Andrew Jackson Trails.

Near the trailhead, visitors will see Brown's Pond, and may be able to observe wildlife that uses this area as their home. During the spring, listen for sounds of fish mating calls beneath the water.

Duration: 1-1.5 hours
audioDescription: A sandy trail leads into the forest, and a pond filled with trees and grasses can be seen to the left.

title: CCC Overlook
listingDescription: This ending point on the trail offers a view of the bayou just past the tree line that visitors can enjoy.

images.altText: A clearing with a sign in the middle is surrounded by trees.
images.title: CCC Overlook
images.caption: CCC Overlook

bodyText:
In front of you is the CCC outlook, originally put at the end of this trail to give visitors a view of the bayou. This view is now somewhat obscured by vegetation, as the National Park Service values allowing nature to blossom as much as possible. However, the water can still be seen beyond the palmetto leaves and magnolia tree branches.

The foundations of this outlook mark the location of the dining pavilion built and used by the Civilian Conservation Corps while creating this recreation area.
audioDescription: In front of you is the CCC outlook, originally put at the end of this trail to give visitors a view of the bayou. The outlook is a circular concrete platform that is raised a half foot off the ground. The platform is approximately 10m in circumference and has a small curb along the edge. This view of the bayou is now somewhat obscured by vegetation, as the Park Service values allowing nature to blossom as much as possible. However, the water can still be seen beyond the palmetto leaves and magnolia tree branches.

title: CCC Spur Trail Stop 2: Fallen Tree
listingDescription: See one of the many microhabitats that exist in this forest while looking at this felled tree. While passing this trunk look closely and you can see several species of fungi, insects, and plants that call this trunk home.

images.altText: A fallen tree stands to the side of a trail through the forest.
images.title: CCC Overlook Trail Fallen Tree
images.caption: CCC Overlook Trail Fallen Tree

bodyText:
In front of you on either side of the path is the remnants of a Live Oak tree that fell across the trail. Instead of removing the tree, rangers separated the trunk into two pieces and left them to decompose. This was done for the betterment of the environment, because while decaying vegetation may look unappealing, it serves an important role in forest habitats.

Felled trees are essential in aiding plant regeneration, cycling nutrients, providing food, and serving as wildlife habitat. While passing this trunk look closely and you can see several species of fungi, insects, and plants that call this trunk home.
audioDescription: Up ahead the trail thins to pass through the remnants of a Live Oak tree that had once fell across the trail. Rangers separated the pieces so you could walk through but the path has narrowed here due to the trunks and the extra foliage that has grown due to the nutrients the tree provides.

title: CCC Spur Trail Stop 3: Bench
listingDescription: Take a break while of the CCC Spur trail and gaze at the surrounding wilderness.

images.altText: A wooden bench on the side of a trail through the woods.
images.title: CCC Overlook Trail Bench
images.caption: CCC Overlook Trail Bench

bodyText: To the right of the trail is a bench for visitors to take a break on. While relaxing make sure to take in the surrounding wilderness. Across from the bench there is a Yaupon holly bush. This is a common shrub we see in the park that can grow 12-45 ft high. This shrub has green serrated leaves, grey bark, and red berries. American Indians used the caffeinated leaves and twigs to prepare tea for ceremonies. But be careful; eating the berries can make you sick. Other vegetation that can be seen from this spot are pines, live oaks, and magnolia trees.
audioDescription: To the right of the trail is a bench for visitors to take a break on. While relaxing you have the opportunity to see and hear plenty of wilderness. For example, the trees across from the bench seem to host several families of squirrels, which you can hear running around and playing.

title: CCC Spur Trail Stop 4: Road Remnants
listingDescription: In this section, visitors can see some of the remnants of the CCC encampment that was here.

images.altText: Stones that used to be a road can be seen on the side of a trail surrounded by trees.
images.title: CCC Road Remnants
images.caption: CCC Road Remnants

bodyText:
In front of you on either side of the trail is some of the remnants of the CCC encampment that was here.The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC), established by Congress on March 31, 1933, was a nationwide program that provided jobs for young, unemployed men during the Great Depression.

The CCC’s goal was to make valuable contributions to forest management, flood control, conservation projects, and to help develop state and national parks for recreation. The CCC 1437th Company came to Ocean Springs with the goal of creating a state park on Stark and Davis bayous. This work would include building roads, bridges, parking areas, picnic areas, outdoor fireplaces, a boat harbor, a pier, as well as installing electric, water, and sewage systems.

What you see on either side of you is what is left of the road that lead to the men’s quarters while staying in Ocean Springs. Once work was completed the road was torn up and turned into a trail, however parts of the curb remain. These curb pieces can be seen throughout most of the trail underneath foliage. To the left stands the most visible of the curb pieces, with what is thought to be an old drain behind it.These curbs are made of similar material that sidewalks are made of today.
audioDescription: In front of you on either side of the trail is remnants of the road that lead to CCC encampment that was here. Once work was completed the road was ripped up and turned into a trail, however parts of the curb remain. To the left stands the most visible of the curb pieces, with what is thought to be an old drain set behind it. These curbs are made up of similar material that sidewalks are made of today.

title: CCC Spur Trail Stop 5: Building Framework
listingDescription: On this section of trail, visitors can see more of the remnants from the CCC encampment that was here.

images.altText: Moss covered rocks that used to be a building can be seen in the middle of a trail.
images.title: CCC Building Framework
images.caption: CCC Building Framework

bodyText:
In the 1930's, the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) were tasked with creating recreation areas around the United States. The 1437th Company, comprised of ~200 men, moved to Ocean Springs from Quitman, Mississippi on May 23, 1938 to start work June 20, 1938. The company built a total of 10 buildings to be used by the men while stationed here. The buildings consisted of four barracks, a mess hall, a bath, an office, a supply, officer’s quarters, and a recreation building.

In front of you on the trail is presumable leftover framework from the CCC's time here. From this point onward all remnants seem to be of similar design. Please make sure to watch your step while walking.
audioDescription: In the middle of the trail are two protruding concrete pieces connected like the corner of a square with the tip pointing towards the way you came. These pieces come approximately six inches out of the ground so watch your step. They are thought to be leftover framework from the Civilian Conservation Corp's time here.

title: CCC Spur Trail Stop 7: Wayside
listingDescription: The last stop of CCC walking tour ends with an wayside that gives more information about the CCC members who were stationed here in Davis Bayou.

images.altText: A wayside providing information on the CCC Overlook Trail stands in the forest.
images.title: CCC Overlook Trail Wayside
images.caption: CCC Overlook Trail Wayside

bodyText: Located to the right of the overlook stands a wayside that gives more information about the Civilian Conservation Corps and the work they did here. The sign also has images of the 1437th Company that was stationed here.
audioDescription: Located to the right of the outlook circle stands a wayward sign that gives more information about the Civilian Conservation Corps and the work they did here. The sign reads: “These foundations mark the location of a dining recreation pavilion built by the Civilian Conservation Corps during the Great Depression. A CCC Camp in the Davis Bayou area provided jobs and training for about 200 Mississippi residents and other Southerners from 1938 to 1941. Crews planted trees in eroded areas and built roads, picnic grounds, cabins, piers, and other structures. These CCC facilities became the nucleus of Magnolia State Park, which was incorporated into the national seashore when it was established in 1971. Seafood specialties right out of the golf can be had for the asking at District E’s only “seashore” camp, a few yards from the Gulf of Mexico, near Ocean Springs, Mississippi.” The sign also has three images. The leftmost image is of Magnolia State Park headquarters. The middle image is of Ocean Springs CCC members standing for inspection at the start of a workday. The right image is of five CCC members working together to plant a tree.

title: Cat Island
listingDescription:
Cat Island is only accessible via private boat. If traveling in your private vessel consult navigational charts. To find an operator who can provide tours, fishing charters, or transportation, visit our Authorized Commercial Operators page .

Learn more about Cat Island online .

images.altText: Drawn image of a white building with a red roof. The building is on a platform with stairs leading up to a porch with people from a wooden boardwalk. At the base are rocks and a small boat in the water. Blue sky in the background.
images.caption: Cat Island Lighthouse

bodyText: Cat Island is a barrier island off the Gulf Coast of Mississippi and is only accessible via private boat.  The island's name comes from French explorers who mistook raccoons for cats.
audioDescription: Cat Island is a barrier island off the Gulf Coast of Mississippi and is only accessible via private boat.  The island's name comes from French explorers who mistook raccoons for cats.

title: Chasefield Plantation Gravestones
listingDescription: No one is buried here. These gravestones are from Chasefield Plantation Cemetery, originally located on land that is now part of Pensacola Naval Air Station. They were moved to this location in 1957. Chasefield Plantation was the home of Major William H. Chase, who supervised the construction of Ft. Pickens in the early 1800's. The gravestones read: SACRED to the memory of GEO. EDMUND CHASE Born 2nd May 1807. Died 28th March 1844.[broken] ...Susana GOLAY who departed this li

images.altText: Six white stone headstones surrounded by a white wooden fence.
images.caption: Chasefield Plantation Gravestones

bodyText: No one is buried here. These gravestones are from Chasefield Plantation Cemetery, originally located on land that is now part of Pensacola Naval Air Station. They were moved to this location in 1957. Chasefield Plantation was the home of Major William H. Chase, who supervised the construction of Ft. Pickens in the early 1800's.
audioDescription: A white picket fence several paces from the parking lot forms a rectangle roughly three yards by ten yards. Inside the fence stand eight thin marble gravestones arranged in pairs. All are weathered. Three are broken, one all the way to the base. In some places bricks outline human-size rectangles behind the gravestones. The ground is a mix of gravel and sand with a a great number of weeds. A trodden path runs lengthwise along the center of the enclosure and a gate is at the right end.

title: Civilian Conservation Corps Spur Trail
listingDescription: Enjoy a walk on the CCC Spur Trail, a 0.2 mile long hiking trail that takes visitors through the woodlands surrounding the bayou.

images.altText: A trailhead sign stands in front of a forest and wooden boardwalk.
images.title: Civilian Conservation Spur Trail
images.caption: Civilian Conservation Corps Spur Trail

bodyText:
The CCC Spur Trail is a 0.2 mile long hiking trail that takes visitors through the woodlands surrounding the bayou, ending at an outlook point that faces the water. The trailhead is located on the west side of the main park road on the way to the visitor center. You'll travel through a mix of pines, deciduous trees, and palmettos, before reaching the overlook. 

The trail is named for the Civilian Conservation Corps who were responsible for creating this recreation area in 1938. While on this trail visitors can view the remnants of the CCC settlement while experiencing the biodiversity of Mississippi forest habits.

Duration: 15-30 minutes
audioDescription: CCC Trail Trailhead. 123 words.This short trail to the CCC overlook turns off of the main Davis Bayou gravel trail that follows the road through the park. A slightly arched wooden footbridge crosses a ditch at the side of the road. The bridge has wooden railings. At the far end, a few timber steps in the dirt path lead back to higher ground where the sandy trail heads off into the woods.The forest here is a mix of pines and deciduous trees with a mix of small shrubs and saw palmettos as the understory.A small sign at the entrance to the trail reads, "CCC Overlook. Pedestrian use only. 0.2 mile. Please! Pack out all trash. Keep your public lands clean."End of Description.

title: Colonial power struggle
listingDescription: Starting in the mid 1500s the Pensacola area became a pawn in a European power struggle in the New World. Adventures from Spain, France, and Britain competed with each other to establish a foothold on the Gulf of Mexico. Spain established several settlements in the Pensacola area from 1559 to 1821. Except for brief French periods and one British colony, Spain claimed the Pensacola area until the United States acquired Florida in a treaty.

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service sign with the title text, "Colonial Power Struggle" in the foreground. Four black cannon in the background.
images.caption: Interpretive Panel: Colonial Power Struggle site

bodyText: Starting in the mid 1500s the Pensacola area became a pawn in a European power struggle in the New World. Adventures from Spain, France, and Britain competed with each other to establish a foothold on the Gulf of Mexico. Spain established several settlements in the Pensacola area from 1559 to 1821. Except for brief French periods and one British colony, Spain claimed the Pensacola area until the United States acquired Florida in a treaty.
audioDescription: Colonial Power Struggle. 166 words. Four cannon are laid on blocks in a row, pointing to the west along the side of the park road, each cradled on concrete mounting blocks. As you face to the west, a small parking area lies along the road to the right. Across from the parking is a "T" shaped one-story wood-frame building. It is white with a green roof and a wide covered porch wrapping all the way around the building. To the east and west lie more buildings, smaller, but in a similar style. As you face to the east, a large cannon on top of the walls of Fort Pickens can be seen.The cannon are 12 feet long. The one at the north end, farthest to the left as you stand at the muzzles, has no markings. The other three each have a British royal insignia in their middle. This consists of a crown at the top with ornate initials below, a "G" and an "R."End of Description.

title: Converting A Cannon
listingDescription: Feel the grooves inside this rare cannon barrel. This Rodman cannon was cast in 1861 as a 10-inch smoothbore, which fired round cannonballs. To keep up with current technology, the US Army in 1884 inserted an 8-inch rifled sleeve into the old cast-iron barrel, because rifled guns had longer ranges than smoothbores. Steel later replaced cast iron, and the old guns were sold for scrap. The piece on the right is part of a smoothbore. The piece on the left is part of a rifled bor

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service sign in front of a large black cannon. Brick Fort Pickens walls in the background.
images.caption: Converting A Cannon Site

bodyText:
Feel the grooves inside this rare cannon barrel. This Rodman cannon was cast in 1861 as a 10-inch smoothbore, which fired round cannonballs. To keep up with current technology, the U.S. Army in 1884 inserted an 8-inch rifled sleeve into the old cast-iron barrel, because rifled guns had longer ranges than smoothbores. Steel later replaced cast iron, and the old guns were sold for scrap. The piece on the right is part of a smoothbore. The piece on the left is part of a rifled bore.

Keep off the Cannon. For your safety and to help preserve this historic cannon, do not climb on the gun barrel.
audioDescription:
304 words
This spot is located in the northern part of the parade ground about halfway between the entrance the black structure of the Pensacola Battery. Cradled on a concrete mount is a 12-foot-long cannon. The open bore, which points towards the east is about two and a half feet off the ground. A sign asks, "Please stay off the cannon," but feel free to touch.

On either side of the mount is a broken piece of a cannon bore. The one on the left has ridges running down the length of the bore. The one on the right is smooth on the inside.

Interpretive panel: Converting a Cannon.

Text at the upper left of this panel reads,

"Feel the grooves inside this rare cannon barrel. This Rodman cannon was cast in 1861 as a 10-inch smoothbore, which fired round cannonballs. To keep up with current technology, the US Army in 1884 inserted an 8-inch rifled sleeve into the old cast-iron barrel, because rifled guns had longer ranges than smoothbores. Steel later replaced cast iron, and the old guns were sold for scrap. The piece on the right is part of a smoothbore. The piece on the left is part of a rifled bore.

"Keep off the Cannon. For your safety and to help preserve this historic cannon, do not climb on the gun barrel."

At the upper right is a photograph of the cannon in front of the panel looking down the bore. The grooves and ridges running the length of the inside can be clearly seen. The caption reads,

"Rifled barrel inside a smoothbore."

At the bottom of the panel is a diagram showing a lengthwise cross section of a cannon with measurements of the bore and other parts. A label on the right side reads,

"8-inch Rifle - converted. Breech Insertion."

End of Description.

title: Davis Bayou Area
listingDescription: Welcome to the Davis Bayou Area ! Continue along Park Road to discover all of the facilities and resources available in this area. Check out the William M. Colmer Visitor Center, go for a hike on one of the many trails, enjoy one of the picnic areas or pavilions, fish from the Fishing Pier, launch a boat, canoe, kayak or paddle board, or stay for the night in the campground. There are many ways to explore and enjoy the area.

images.altText: Large brown National Park Service sign with white text that reads, "Davis Bayou Area, Gulf Islands National Seashore." The National Park Service brown and green arrowhead is on the right.
images.caption: Davis Bayou Entrance Sign

bodyText:
Welcome to the Davis Bayou Area! Continue along Park Road to discover all of the facilities and resources available in the Mississippi portion of Gulf Islands National Seashore.

There are many ways to explore and enjoy the area.Check out the William M. Colmer Visitor Center, go for a hike on one of the many trails, enjoy one of the picnic areas or pavilions, fish from the fishing pier, launch a boat, canoe, kayak or paddle board, or stay for the night in the campground.
audioDescription: Welcome to the Davis Bayou Area! Continue along Park Road to discover all of the facilities and resources available in the Mississippi portion of Gulf Islands National Seashore.

title: Davis Bayou Area Orientation Kiosk - Picnic Area
listingDescription: Davis Bayou Area The salt water of the Gulf of Mexico mixes here in the Davis Bayou Area with fresh water from the mainland to create a rich estuary teeming with wildlife. Walk the trails, camp, and explore the bayous and salt marshes, which serve as nurseries for crabs, fish, and other marine life. See the film and exhibits in the visitor center. Fish from the pier, paddle around a bayou, or camp here in the 52-site campground. Plan your visit to Fort Massachusetts on West S

images.altText: National Park Service sign with the title, "Gulf Islands National Seashore."
images.caption: Gulf Islands National Seashore

bodyText:
Davis Bayou Area

The salt water of the Gulf of Mexico mixes here in the Davis Bayou Area with fresh water from the mainland to create a rich estuary teeming with wildlife. Walk the trails, camp, and explore the bayous and salt marshes, which serve as nurseries for crabs, fish, and other marine life. See the film and exhibits in the visitor center. Fish from the pier, paddle around a bayou, or camp here in the 52-site campground. Plan your visit to Fort Massachusetts on West Ship Island, or one of other the barrier islands off the coast.

Know Before You Go:
- Check the weather in advance
- Be aware of uneven and slippery surfaces
- Do not disturb or remove any natural, historical, or archaeological objects
- Do not feed wildlife
audioDescription:
Two panels:
Gulf Islands National Seashore. 417 words.
Davis Bayou Area. 375 words.


Davis Bayou Area. 375 words.

At the top of the panel is a photograph of a salt marsh, rippling water in the foreground edged by a wide area of thick marsh vegetation - grasses and reeds. In the back ground lies a forest.

Below the picture on the left text reads,

"The salt water of the Gulf of Mexico mixes here in the Davis Bayou Area with fresh water from the mainland to create a rich estuary teeming with wildlife. Walk the trails, camp, and explore the bayous and salt marshes, which serve as nurseries for crabs, fish, and other marine life. See the film and exhibits in the visitor center. Fish from the pier, paddle around a bayou, or camp here in the 52-site campground. Plan your visit to Fort Massachusetts on West Ship Island, or one of other the barrier islands off the coast."

The middle of the panel features a map of the Davis Bayou Area. Several smaller waterways join to form the wide estuary. The park wraps around the main bayou on the eastern and northern sides with the visitor center in the lower south east part. From there roads go north, then west, crossing some of the waterways, to the campground. From there the road goes north again passing picnic areas in the northwest part of the park. From the main part of the park the park road turns back to the east then heads north, crossing railroad tracks to connect with Highway 90 at the park entrance. Park land extends in a narrow corridor along this route.

At the bottom of the panel are two smaller photographs. The one on the left shows an Asian-American woman and a small child looking out over the grasses of a marsh along the Davis Bayou Trail. To the right is a picture of a man in a kayak drifting on the water as he holds his paddle across his lap, marsh grasses in the background. Text at the lower right reads,

"A Few Precautions. Be alert for sudden storms. Be aware of uneven and slippery surfaces. Watch children closely.

"Park Restrictions. Do not disturb or remove any natural, historical, or archeological objects. Do not feed wildlife. Metal detectors are prohibited."

Gulf Islands National Seashore. 417 words.

This panel is four feet wide and three feet tall. Across the middle is a map showing the various areas of the park. The map includes most of the Mississippi coastline, the Alabama coastline and the westernmost part of the Florida panhandle. Areas included in the park are outlined in green - several off-shore islands near Biloxi, Mississippi and other islands off the Florida coast from Perdido Key in the west to Okaloosa at the eastern end. Park areas on the mainland include Davis Bayou near Biloxi, Fort Barrancas in Pensacola and Naval Live Oaks south of Pensacola.

Text on the panel is in both English and Spanish. At the top text reads,

"This national seashore protects our historical heritage and ever-changing features of the Gulf Coast-salt marshes, marine woodlands, sparkling white beaches, and coastal waters. Walk the trails, photograph seashore plants and wildlife, swim and boat in the emerald green waters, learn the stories of early inhabitants, or just relax and enjoy the solitude."

To the right of the text is a photograph of a white sandy beach stretching into the distance, wispy dune grass on the right and water at upper left.

Text below the map reads,

Gulf Islands National Seashore includes several islands and portions of the mainland. Here you can boat, fish, and swim in the gulf waters. On land the national seashore provides campgrounds, primitive camping areas, and trails that pass through dunes, woodlands, and marshes-habitats of a variety of mammals, reptiles, and birds. For information, exhibits, and bookstores, stop at the visitor centers."

Across the bottom of the panel are five photographs. Beginning at the left, the first one shows an alligator stretched out on a log in bright sunshine. The label reads, "Wildlife."

The next picture shows a group of people looking out over a grassy area surrounded by red brick walls. The back wall has large arched openings into dark spaces behind. In the middle are three uniformed men standing with rifles at their sides. At the right is a man dressed in a park uniform. The label reads, "Tours."

The middle photograph shows crooked live oak tree branches dripping with long Spanish moss. The label reads, "Nature."

The fourth picture shows three children in swim suits splashing in shallow water. The label reads, "Recreation."

The last picture shows a view down a structure made of a series of rounded arches, light coming from openings on the left. The label reads, "History."

End of Description.

title: Davis Bayou Area Orientation Kiosk - Visitor Center
listingDescription: This orientation kiosk is located just outside the William M. Colmer Visitor Center and offers information about the area and the national seashore at large.

title: Davis Bayou Blueway
listingDescription: Connecting Davis, Stark, and Halstead Bayous this blueway is an excellent way to explore the area's marine resources. The winding marshes are rich in plant and animal diversity, but also demonstrate the extremes of the salt marsh environment. The Davis Bayou Blueway offers an excellent example of a unique and productive ecosystem.Kayak launch located 200 feet to your left. Safety Precautions: Always carry water and sunscreen. Leave your trip plans with someone on land, and u

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service sign in front of reflective water.
images.caption: Davis Bayou Blueway Site Photo

bodyText:
A great place to view a variety of animals, launch a kayak or begin your walk on a trail.

Davis Bayou Blueway, Connecting Davis, Stark, and Halstead Bayous, is an excellent way to explore the area's marine resources. 

The winding green marshes are rich in plant and animal diversity, but also demonstrate the extremes of the salt marsh environment. The Davis Bayou Blueway offers an excellent example of a unique and productive ecosystem.

The Davis Bayou Blueway was developed through a partnership between the National Park Service, National Park Foundation, and Heritage Trails.
audioDescription: The wayside over looks the gorgeous view of a large waterway that makes up Davis Bayou Blueway. Connecting Davis, Stark, and Halstead Bayous this blueway, is an excellent way to explore the area's marine resources. The winding green marshes are rich in plant and animal diversity, but also demonstrate the extremes of the salt marsh environment.

title: Davis Bayou Boat Launch
listingDescription: The Davis Bayou Boat Launch features a two-slip trailer launch and a small craft hand-launch area. This launch is the perfect place to access Davis Bayou, the Mississippi Sound, and the Gulf of Mexico. Trailer parking is permitted in the designated spaces and gravel parking area. At the hand-launch area, located on the east side of the parking lot, visitors can access the Davis Bayou Blueway.

images.altText: Two wooden docks stand in front of a pavement ramp overlooking the bayou.
images.title: Davis Bayou Boat Launch
images.caption: Davis Bayou Boat Launch

bodyText:
The Davis Bayou Boat Launch features a two-slip trailer launch and a small craft hand-launch area. This launch is the perfect place to access Davis Bayou, the Mississippi Sound, and the Gulf of Mexico, as well as take pictures and go fishing. Trailer parking is permitted in the designated spaces and gravel parking area.

At the hand-launch area, located on the east side of the parking lot, visitors can access the Davis Bayou Blueway. Connecting Davis, Stark, and Halstead Bayous this Blueway is an excellent way to explore the area's marine resources. Common sites at the launch are of fish jumping out the water, boating traffic, and birds like pelicans and seagulls diving for food. 

The winding marshes are rich in plant and animal diversity, but also demonstrate the extremes of the salt marsh environment. The Davis Bayou Blueway offers an excellent example of a unique and productive ecosystem, and was developed through a partnership between the National Park Service, National Park Foundation, and Heritage Trails.
audioDescription: The Davis Bayou Boat Launch features a two-slip trailer launch and a small craft hand-launch area. This launch is the perfect place to access Davis Bayou, the Mississippi Sound, and the Gulf of Mexico. Trailer parking is permitted in the designated spaces and gravel parking area. At the hand-launch area, located on the east side of the parking lot, visitors can access the Davis Bayou Blueway. Connecting Davis, Stark, and Halstead Bayous this Blueway is an excellent way to explore the area's marine resources.

title: Davis Bayou Campground
listingDescription: Located east of downtown Ocean Springs, Mississippi, visitors enjoy the Davis Bayou Campground for its easy access to boating, fishing, biking and hiking trails. The campground features 52 sites nestled among live oaks and pine trees and is adjacent to a saltwater marsh. Most campsites offer some shade throughout the day and offer a tranquil setting for migratory bird watching and picnicking.Know Before You Go! Click this link to watch a helpful video on planning your cam

images.altText: A red truck attached to a white camper. A road runs in front of the truck. Trees in the background.
images.caption: Davis Bayou Campground

bodyText:
Located east of downtown Ocean Springs, Mississippi, visitors can enjoy the Davis Bayou Campground for its easy access to boating, fishing, biking and hiking trails.

The campground features 52 sites nestled among live oaks and pine trees and is adjacent to a saltwater marsh. Most campsites offer some shade throughout the day and offer a tranquil setting for migratory bird watching and picnicking.

Know Before You Go!
audioDescription: Located east of downtown Ocean Springs, Mississippi, visitors can enjoy the Davis Bayou Campground for its easy access to boating, fishing, biking and hiking trails.

title: Davis Bayou Campground Restrooms
listingDescription: The Davis Bayou Campground Restrooms are for registered campers only and feature men's and women's restrooms as well as shower facilities.

images.altText: Light brown cement building with a brown roof. Three brown metal doors in the side of the building.
images.caption: Davis Bayou Campground Restrooms

bodyText: The Davis Bayou Campground Restrooms are for registered campers only and feature men's and women's restrooms as well as shower facilities.
audioDescription: The Davis Bayou Campground Restrooms are for registered campers only and feature men's and women's restrooms as well as shower facilities.

title: Davis Bayou Fishing Pier
listingDescription: Visit the fishing pier for an amazing view of the water and chance to land a fish.

images.altText: A wooden boardwalk stands over a blue bayou waterway
images.title: Davis Bayou Fishing Pier
images.caption: Davis Bayou Fishing Pier

bodyText:
A great place for recreational fishers to cast a line. The all-weather board pier extends about 50 feet out and over the water, ending under a small pavilion. As you look out over the water keep a lookout for wildlife such as fish, birds, and even dolphins. Beyond the water to the southeast, trees can be seen in the distance. This land mass is deer island, which is a barrier island that extends from Biloxi. Looking west with your back to the shore, the tall buildings of Biloxi are visible in the distance.

Recreational fishers in Mississippi are required to have a Mississippi State Saltwater Fishing License. All fishing regulations within the seashore correspond to the state fishing regulations.
audioDescription:
Davis Bayou fishing pier. 159 words. The all-weather board pier extends out into the sound about 200 feet. The wide walk has wood railings on either side. Halfway along the walk it bends slightly to the right. In the corner there is a bench. At the end there is a six-sided covered pavilion about 25 feet wide with benches along the railings. The pier extends out to the left from the pavilion, paralleling the bank for another 75 feet. There the pier connects to a maintenance area with boat slips and small maintenance buildings. This area is closed off by chain link fencing.From the pavilion looking west, which is to the right as you stand with your back to the shore, the tall buildings of Biloxi are visible in the distance. Closer along the shore is the entrance into the bayou. The shore is lined with marsh grasses and reeds with small shrubs behind and then the woods.
End of Description.

title: Davis Bayou Fishing Pier Restrooms
listingDescription: These restrooms are located within walking distance of the Davis Bayou Fishing Pier and the Visitor Center Picnic Area.

images.altText: Brown cement structure with a brown roof. Wooden bench on a cement walkway in front of the structure. Green trees surround the structure.
images.caption: Davis Bayou Fishing Pier Restrooms

bodyText: These restrooms are located within walking distance of the Davis Bayou Fishing Pier and the Visitor Center Picnic Area.

title: Davis Bayou Gator Pond
listingDescription: Stop by the Gator Pond to see some of the wildlife the park has to offer. Remember to respect wildlife by giving them space - you are in their home!

images.altText: A wooden platform stands in front of a dark pond and vegetation.
images.title: Gator Pond Overlook
images.caption: Gator Pond Overlook at Davis Bayou

bodyText: The Gator Pond is located on Robert MeGhee Rd, which that connects to Park Road and will take you all the way down to the campground. On the side of the road is a small boardwalk that overlooks the gator pond. This is one of the best places in the park to see alligators sunning themselves along the bank. It also provides a great opportunity to take pictures of turtles basking and birds feeding. Parking is available across the street in front of the Nature’s Way Loop Trail entrance.
audioDescription: This stop has a 6 foot by 6 foot overlook that gives visitors a chance to look into a calm part of the bayou. Here you can see and hear wildlife all around you. The most prevalent noises are of the many songbirds that nest near the area.

title: Davis Bayou Group Campsite
listingDescription: Gulf Islands National Seashore's Davis Bayou Group Campsite offers a tent camping experience for organized groups in the Davis Bayou Area in Mississippi.

images.altText: Sun shining through a large oak tree.
images.caption: Davis Bayou Camping

bodyText: Gulf Islands National Seashore's Davis Bayou Group Campsite offers a tent camping experience for organized group parties with a minimum of 10 individuals and a maximum of 40. It features restrooms, showers, drinking water, fire pit, grills, and trash dumpster.
audioDescription: Gulf Islands National Seashore's Davis Bayou Group Campsite offers a tent camping experience for organized group parties with a minimum of 10 individuals and a maximum of 40. It features restrooms, showers, drinking water, fire pit, grills, and trash dumpster.

title: Davis Bayou North Trailhead
listingDescription: Hike from the park's picnic area to the William M. Colmer visitor center, stopping for scenic overlooks and other trailheads along the way.

images.altText: A wood framed orientation panel stands between a road intersection and the forest.
images.caption: Davis Bayou Trailhead, north (intersection with Boat Launch Road)

bodyText:
This trailhead of the Davis Bayou Trail begins at the intersection of Robert McGhee Road and Boat Launch Road, and continues south for 1 mile to the William M. Colmer Visitor Center. The trail runs alongside Hanley and the main Park Road. The trail provides access to the CCC Spur Trail and the Nature's Way Loop Trail.

Duration: 30-60 minutes
audioDescription:
79 words, plus orientation panel

This trailhead is located at the intersection of Robert McGhee Road and Boat Launch Road which turns off to the left, heading south. Across the road from the intersection is a parking lot and a picnic area. The trail runs alongside Robert McGhee Road back to the east where it crosses a bayou stream and then follows the road through the woods. The woods here are a mix of pines and deciduous trees.

Orientation panel: Davis Bayou Trails. 438 words.

At the top of this panel is a photograph looking across the reeds and cattails alongside the waterways of the bayou. A blue heron stands in the water in the back ground.

At the bottom of the panel is a photograph of two alligators resting on shore.

Down the right side of the panel is a map of the Davis Bayou Area identifying the trails and facilities of the park. The visitor center is near the southern end of the park. The main park road goes from there north along the east side of the park, then turns west through the middle of the park crossing several of the bayous. The campground is at the western edge of the park. From there the road turns north to reach a loop at the northern edge, past a picnic area. Several trails extend out form the visitor center. Another follows the road through the park, with side trails along the way. A bicycle/multiuse trail follows the road on the western side of the park.

Text on the left reads,

"Walk the trails in the Davis Bayou Area and discover the sights and sounds of the salt marsh and coastal woodlands on Mississippi's Gulf Coast.

"Davis Bayou Trail. Listen to the birds and other sounds as you explore the forest and bayou along this 1-mile trail from the visitor center to the picnic area. The trail provides access to the CCC Spur Trail and the Nature's Way Loop Trail.

"CCC Spur Trail. Follow this 0.2-mile trail along a wooded section to the Civilian Conservation Corps camp location. This trail was once a roadbed built by the CCC.

"Nature's Way Loop Trail. Hike this 0.5-mile trail and notice how the types of plant species change as the elevation rises slightly between the bayou and forest in a former dune area.

"Visitor Center Trails. Walk the short trails for views of Davis Bayou and Mississippi Sound; 100 yards; the fishing pier is wheelchair-accessible.

"Live Oaks Bicycle Route. Follow this paved route as it winds 2 miles through the park and 13 miles through the adjacent community to downtown Ocean Springs.

"Safety Precautions. Wear a hat and sunglasses. Drink plenty of water. Be aware of venomous snakes, insects, and poison ivy. Stay on the trail. Watch children closely. In emergencies call 911.

"Park Regulations. Do not disturb or remove any natural, historical, or archeological objects. Do not feed wildlife. Metal detectors are prohibited.

"If you are fortunate you may see a great egret or an alligator sunning itself at the bayou along Robert McGhee Road."

End of Description.

title: Davis Bayou Overlook
listingDescription: The Davis Bayou Overlook offers a great view of Davis Bayou which flows into two additional bayous in this area. These bayous are full of life above and below the water. Davis Bayou Blueway connects Davis, Stark, and Halstead Bayous into a 1.5 mile recreational waterway. Appropriate for beginning and experienced paddlers alike, the winding marsh exhibits rich plant and animal diversity while demonstrating the extremes of the salt marsh environment.

images.altText: A wooden platform and railing surrounded by vegetation overlooks the bayou.
images.title: Davis Bayou Overlook
images.caption: Davis Bayou Overlook

bodyText:
The Davis Bayou Overlook offers a great view of Davis Bayou. These bayous are full of life above and below the water. Davis Bayou Blueway connects Davis, Stark, and Halstead Bayous into a 1.5 mile recreational waterway.

Appropriate for beginning and experienced paddlers alike, the winding marsh exhibits rich plant and animal diversity while demonstrating the extremes of the salt marsh environment.

Davis Bayou Blueway is federally protected within the boundaries of Gulf Islands National Seashore and provides a pristine example of the unique, productive, and vanishing salt marsh ecosystem.
audioDescription: Davis Bayou Overlook. 131 words.The platform here at the end of the board walk is 18 feet wide with a bench along the full width at the end. It sits about 15 feet high. To the left as you face the end, the view is blocked by trees, mostly small pine trees. Other trees lie to the right, but the bayou is visible through them. One tree on the right is growing through the tailing. The view on the right looks over wide areas of marsh with thick grasses and reeds. The water level will depend on the tides, either flowing freely or bare mud flats. In the front, the bayou empties into the waters of the sound and the high rises of Biloxi can be seen in the distance. End of Description.

title: Davis Bayou Picnic Area
listingDescription:
The Davis Bayou Picnic Area is located on Robert McGhee Road and is the perfect place for a picnic all year long with plenty of shade trees and picnic shelters scattered throughout the area. Picnic tables and grills are spaced throughout and are surround nearby fields for games and activities.

There is a restroom facility located on the northwest side of the picnic area.

images.altText: Wooden picnic tables under silhouetted trees at sunset.
images.caption: Davis Bayou Picnic Tables

bodyText:
The Davis Bayou Picnic Area is the perfect place for a picnic all year long with plenty of shade trees and picnic shelters scattered throughout the area. Picnic tables and grills are spaced throughout and are surround nearby fields for games and activities.

There are a total of five covered pavilions available for use with a restroom facility located on the northwest side. Groups of 25 or more wishing to use the pavilion should complete and submit a Special Use Permit .

title: Davis Bayou South Trailhead
listingDescription: Hike from the William M. Colmer visitor center to the park's picnic area, stopping for scenic overlooks and other trailheads along the way.

images.altText: An earthen trail leads into the forest beside an orientation panel.
images.caption: Davis Bayou Trailhead, south (parking lot)

bodyText:
This trailhead of the Davis Bayou Trail begins at the edge of the visitor center complex parking lot and continues north for 1 mile to the picnic area. The trail provides access to the CCC Spur Trail and the Nature's Way Loop Trail, and runs alongside Hanely and the main Park Road.

Duration: 30-60 minutes
audioDescription:
92 words, plus orientation panel

This trailhead is at the edge of the parking lot. The sandy trail is covered with pine needles and fallen leaves. The woods on either side are a mix of tall pine trees and smaller deciduous trees. The undergrowth is fairly thick with smaller trees and shrubs. From here, the trail goes straight into the woods and then curves to the left.

The parking lot behind you has several islands with grass, trees and shrubs. That, along the woods on all sides, provides lots of shade.

Orientation panel: Davis Bayou Trails. 438 words.

At the top of this panel is a photograph looking across the reeds and cattails alongside the waterways of the bayou. A blue heron stands in the water in the back ground.

At the bottom of the panel is a photograph of two alligators resting on shore.

Down the right side of the panel is a map of the Davis Bayou Area identifying the trails and facilities of the park. The visitor center is near the southern end of the park. The main park road goes from there north along the east side of the park, then turns west through the middle of the park crossing several of the bayous. The campground is at the western edge of the park. From there the road turns north to reach a loop at the northern edge, past a picnic area. Several trails extend out form the visitor center. Another follows the road through the park, with side trails along the way. A bicycle/multiuse trail follows the road on the western side of the park.

Text on the left reads,

"Walk the trails in the Davis Bayou Area and discover the sights and sounds of the salt marsh and coastal woodlands on Mississippi's Gulf Coast.

"Davis Bayou Trail. Listen to the birds and other sounds as you explore the forest and bayou along this 1-mile trail from the visitor center to the picnic area. The trail provides access to the CCC Spur Trail and the Nature's Way Loop Trail.

"CCC Spur Trail. Follow this 0.2-mile trail along a wooded section to the Civilian Conservation Corps camp location. This trail was once a roadbed built by the CCC.

"Nature's Way Loop Trail. Hike this 0.5-mile trail and notice how the types of plant species change as the elevation rises slightly between the bayou and forest in a former dune area.

"Visitor Center Trails. Walk the short trails for views of Davis Bayou and Mississippi Sound; 100 yards; the fishing pier is wheelchair-accessible.

"Live Oaks Bicycle Route. Follow this paved route as it winds 2 miles through the park and 13 miles through the adjacent community to downtown Ocean Springs.

"Safety Precautions. Wear a hat and sunglasses. Drink plenty of water. Be aware of venomous snakes, insects, and poison ivy. Stay on the trail. Watch children closely. In emergencies call 911.

"Park Regulations. Do not disturb or remove any natural, historical, or archeological objects. Do not feed wildlife. Metal detectors are prohibited.

"If you are fortunate you may see a great egret or an alligator sunning itself at the bayou along Robert McGhee Road."

End of Description.

title: Davis Bayou Visitor Center Picnic Area
listingDescription: Enjoy a relaxing picnic under the shade of live oak trees with a view of the water.

images.altText: People sitting at a picnic table. Other picnic tables are scattered around them on green grass. Green trees hang overhead.
images.caption: Davis Bayou Visitor Center Picnic Area

bodyText: This is a small picnic area near the William M. Colmer Visitor Center where visitors can relax under the shade of live oaks with a view of the water. The area features several uncovered tables, each with a charcoal grill. It features of the bayou and conveniently located near the fishing pier and fishing pier restrooms.
audioDescription: This is a small picnic area near the visitor center complex. The area features several uncovered tables, each with a charcoal grill. It has a nice view of the bayou and conveniently located near the fishing pier and fishing pier restrooms.

title: Ferry Landing Plaza Restrooms
listingDescription: Public restrooms built on top of the Cable Tank foundation are located in the Ferry Plaza.

images.altText: A tan and brown restroom building stands on green grass.
images.title: Ferry Landing Plaza Restrooms
images.caption: Ferry Plaza Restrooms

bodyText:
Public restrooms are located near the Mine Storeroom and Ferry Pier, about 500 feet from the entrance to Fort Pickens. They stand on the foundation of the Cable Tank building.

This large, rectangular concrete foundation is all that remains of the Cable Tank. Inside this the structure, the Army stored electrical cables in water-filled drums. These cables were used for the submarine mine defenses on Pensacola Bay. The Cable Tank was first constructed in 1898, but was destroyed by the June 1899 explosion at Fort Pickens' Bastion D. The Army rebuilt the Cable Tank, with some new modifications, by 1900.
audioDescription: A tan and brown building with three restrooms.

title: Fishing Trail
listingDescription: The 0.92 mile Fishing Trail runs the length of the Santa Rosa Sound side of the Naval Live Oaks Area. There are several water access points along the trail for fishing or to launch a kayak.

images.altText: A trail cuts through trees and looks out to the horizon.
images.title: Naval Live Oaks Fishing Trail
images.caption: Naval Live Oaks Fishing Trail

bodyText:
The Fishing Trail runs the length of the Santa Rosa Sound side of the Naval Live Oaks Area. There are several water access points along the trail for fishing or to launch a kayak. Visitors may traverse through dense forest down to the sandy bay, where wildlife can be observed. This trail connects to the Brackenridge Loop Trail and overlook.

The Fishing Trail runs 0.92 miles parallel to US Highway 98, not including intersections with other trails. If completed as an out-and-back, the total length is 1.84 miles.

Trailhead locations:

  • Intersection with Brackenridge Nature Trail
  • 3 pullouts on the south side of US Highway 98 going east from Gulf Breeze to Naval Live Oaks

Duration: 1-1.5 hours
audioDescription: The Fishing Trail runs the length of the Santa Rosa Sound side of the Naval Live Oaks Area. There are several water access points along the trail for fishing or to launch a kayak. This trail connects to the Brackenridge Loop Trail and overlook.

title: Fishing Trail Beach Access
listingDescription: Access the quite waters of the Santa Rosa Sound using the Naval Live Oaks Fishing Trail. There are no restrooms, beach showers, or water fountains at this access point. Camping, pets, glass, and driving are not permitted on beach.

images.altText: Fishing Trail
images.title: Fishing Trail
images.caption: Fishing Trail

bodyText: The Fishing Trail runs the length of the Santa Rosa Sound side of the Naval Live Oaks Area and ends on the shore with beach access. There are several water access points along the trail for fishing or to launch a kayak. This trail connects to the Brackenridge Loop Trail and overlook.
