title: Florida National Scenic Trail Northern Terminus
listingDescription: The Florida National Scenic Trail , or just Florida Trail, is a federally-designated trail intended to offer a continuous non-motorized recreation opportunity showcasing the biodiversity, history, and culture of Florida. Its northern terminus lies here on the white sands of Gulf Islands National Seashore. Follow it south for over 1,300 miles and you'll eventually find its southern terminus in the river of grass in Big Cypress National Preserve. Across the United States there

images.altText: A metal framed National Park Service sign with the title text, "Florida National Scenic Trail." A white building, green grass, and blue sky in the background.
images.caption: FNST Kiosk Side 1

bodyText:
The Florida National Scenic Trail , or just Florida Trail, is a federally-designated trail intended to offer a continuous non-motorized recreation opportunity showcasing the biodiversity, history, and culture of Florida.

Its northern terminus lies here on the white sands of Gulf Islands National Seashore. Follow it south for over 1,300 miles and you'll eventually find its southern terminus in the river of grass in Big Cypress National Preserve.

Across the United States there are only 11 National Scenic Trails. The Florida Trails offers an exclusive Florida experience including the only segment of a National Scenic Trail that follows an ocean beach right here at Gulf Islands National Seashore.

The Authentic Florida Experience
Florida is home to many unique environments, some of which are not seen anywhere else in the world. This gives trail users prime access to some of the best nature and wildlife viewing opportunities in the country. By traveling the Florida Trail, one can experience a variety of ecosystems including longleaf pine forests, sand dune scattered beaches, and hardwood hammocks. Wildlife viewing along the Florida Trail is also spectacular, providing visitors with the opportunity to see black bears, alligators, panthers, gopher tortoises, and many species of endangered birds including wood storks, red-cockaded woodpeckers, and roseate spoon bills. Whether exploring a secluded wilderness area or a Florida Trail Gateway Community, the Florida Trail is the perfect place to find an authentic outdoor experience.

Follow the Orange Blazes
If you wanted to hike from the western end of Florida's panhandle to the Southern tip of the state, how would you do it? Follow the orange blazes of course! These orange blazes, with the Florida Trail signs, will help you navigate the trail from end to end. The first blaze was painted by the Florida Trail Association on October 29, 1966. Today there are thousands of blazes to guide hikers through Florida's most beautiful natural, cultural, and historic resources. Let the orange blazes lead you on your next adventure!Further Trail Information. To learn more about the Florida Trail, purchase trail maps, plan your trip, or discover volunteer opportunities, visit our website. www.floridatrail.org
audioDescription:
157 words, plus orientation panel

At the east side of the parking lot by Fort Pickens is a sand and gravel path heading off into a bushy area dotted with a few tall trees.

At the start of the trail is a sign with the logo for the Florida Trail at the top: a rounded triangle with a silhouette of the state in the middle with the initials "F-T." The top strokes of the initials are slanted and connected to form a peaked roof. The sign gives distances to Battery Worth (0.8 miles), Campground Loops A-E (0.85 to 1.3 miles) and the southern terminus in Big Cypress National Preserve (1,300 miles). Text reads,

"One of 11 national scenic trails in the United States, this trail provides one of the best ways to get around Fort Pickens and beyond! Hiking, biking, and pets on leash permitted."

To the right of the sign is a dog waste station.

Orientation panel: Florida National Scenic Trail. 526 words.

This panel is 2 feet wide and three feet tall. Down the right side is a footprint with tread, like a hiking boot. In the upper right corner is a logo for the Florida Trail, a rounded triangle with the silhouette of the state in the middle and the initials "F-T." Text at upper left reads,

"The Florida National Scenic Trail, or just Florida Trail, is a federally-designated trail intended to offer a continuous non-motorized recreation opportunity showcasing the biodiversity, history, and culture of Florida. Its northern terminus lies here on the white sands of Gulf Islands National Seashore. Follow it south for over 1,300 miles and you'll eventually find its southern terminus in the river of grass in Big Cypress National Preserve. Across the United States there are only 11 National Scenic Trails. The Florida Trails offers an exclusive Florida experience including the only segment of a National Scenic Trail that follows an ocean beach right here at Gulf Islands National Seashore."

Below the text is a column of four photographs. Beginning at the top, the first one shows a hiker wearing a backpack moving away from us along a beach's water's edge. The one below that shows a young woman relaxing as she sits in the opening of a tent in the woods. The next one shows four hikers walking down a path through the woods, ferns on either side. The bottom picture shows a young woman pointing to the Florida Trail logo on a wooden post. Text beside the photographs reads,

"The Authentic Florida Experience. Florida is home to many unique environments, some of which are not seen anywhere else in the world. This gives trail users prime access to some of the best nature and wildlife viewing opportunities in the country. By traveling the Florida Trail, one can experience a variety of ecosystems including longleaf pine forests, sand dune scattered beaches, and hardwood hammocks. Wildlife viewing along the Florida Trail is also spectacular, providing visitors with the opportunity to see black bears, alligators, panthers, gopher tortoises, and many species of endangered birds including wood storks, red-cockaded woodpeckers, and roseate spoon bills. Whether exploring a secluded wilderness area or a Florida Trail Gateway Community, the Florida Trail is the perfect place to find an authentic outdoor experience."

At lower right is an image of an orange paint blaze. The text reads,

"Follow the Orange Blazes. If you wanted to hike from the western end of Florida's panhandle to the Southern tip of the state, how would you do it? Follow the orange blazes of course! These orange blazes, with the Florida Trail signs, will help you navigate the trail from end to end. The first blaze was painted by the Florida Trail Association on October 29, 1966. Today there are thousands of blazes to guide hikers through Florida's most beautiful natural, cultural, and historic resources. Let the orange blazes lead you on your next adventure!"

At lower left more text reads,

"Further Trail Information. To learn more about the Florida Trail, purchase trail maps, plan your trip, or discover volunteer opportunities, visit our website. W-w-w-dot-f-s-dot-gov-slash-f-n-s-t or w-w-w-dot-floridatrail-dot-org."

End of Description.

title: Florida National Scenic Trail at Battery Langdon
listingDescription: The Florida Trail passes by historic Battery Langdon before continuing across the street at Langdon Beach.

images.altText: A sign for the Florida National Scenic Trail stands in front of a concrete battery with black doors.
images.title: Florida Trail at Battery Langdon
images.caption: Florida Trail at Battery Langdon

bodyText:
The Florida National Scenic Trail passes directly in front of historic Battery Langdon. This bunker was built in 1923 and protected the largest guns in the area.

To continue on the Florida Trail, head south across Fort Pickens Road to Langdon Beach. The trail then continues along the beach for 5 miles before exiting the park near Park West on Fort Pickens Road. Thru-hikers may wish to take the Pensacola Beach Trail for another 9 miles before reentering the park in the Santa Rosa area. The Florida Trail then continues along the beach for 7 more miles before exiting onto a paved path on Gulf Boulevard.

Happy hiking!
audioDescription: In front of you stands Battery Langdon, a large concrete bunker about 40 feet tall. Vegetation grows over the top, and a parking lot can be seen to the right. To the left, a sandy path takes you to the top of the battery, while behind you, waves can be heard crashing on the seashore.

title: Florida National Scenic Trail at Opal Beach
listingDescription: The Florida Trail continues along the beach of Santa Rosa island for 7 miles within the national park. You can find a trail marker and wayside for the trail at Opal Beach.

images.altText: A sign for the Florida National Scenic Trail stands in front of pavilions at the beach.
images.title: Florida Trail at Opal Beach
images.caption: Marker for the Florida Trail at Opal Beach

bodyText:
This trail marker stands on Opal Beach in the Santa Rosa area of Gulf Islands National Seashore. The Florida National Scenic Trail hugs the coastline for 7 miles in this area of the park, before exiting at Navarre to the east or Pensacola Beach to the west. The northern terminus at Fort Pickens can be found about 20 miles to the west of here. 

Restrooms and parking are available on site. Enjoy the relaxing walk on white sandy beaches with a breeze at your back and a beautiful view of the famous Emerald Coast.
audioDescription: There are pavilions and restrooms located behind the trail marker. In front, there is an endless swatch of white beach and turquoise blue ocean water.

title: Florida Trail & Blackbird Marsh Trail Intersection
listingDescription: This is the intersection of the Florida National Scenic Trail and the Blackbird Marsh Trail. The Blackbird Marsh Trail can be used to access Fort Pickens Campground Loop A. Following the Florida Trail to the east at this point would lead you to Langdon Beach, and following it to the west would lead to Fort Pickens Campground Loop E.

images.altText: A sign for the Florida National Scenic Trail intersects with another trail.
images.title: Florida Trail Intersection
images.caption: Florida Trail & Blackbird Marsh Intersection

bodyText:
This is the intersection of the Florida National Scenic Trail and the Blackbird Marsh Trail in the Fort Pickens Area. From here, visitors may hike a scenic and informative nature trail showcasing many types of Florida vegetation. The loop is 0.5 mile total. Visitors may also reach campground Loop A via the south entrance of the Blackbird Marsh Trail. Continuing east on the Florida Trail will lead to Battery Langon and Langdon Beach after another 0.5 miles. Continuing west leads to Campground Loops B-E.

The Florida National Scenic Trail , or just Florida Trail, is a federally-designated trail intended to offer a continuous non-motorized recreation opportunity showcasing the biodiversity, history, and culture of Florida.

It begins here in Gulf Islands National Seashore. Follow it south for over 1,300 miles and to its most southern terminus in the river of grass in Big Cypress National Preserve.
audioDescription: This is the intersection of the Florida National Scenic Trail and the Blackbird Marsh Trail in the Fort Pickens Area. The Blackbird Marsh Trail can be used to access Fort Pickens Campground Loop A. Following the Florida Trail to the east at this point would lead you to Langdon Beach, and following it to the west would lead to Fort Pickens Campground Loop E.

title: Florida Trail Stop 2
listingDescription: Built as part of an Eagle Scout project, this bench serves as a place to rest and watch listen for wildlife on the trail.

images.altText: A wooden bench sits among vegetation
images.title: Florida National Scenic Trail Stop 2
images.caption: Florida Trail Stop 2

bodyText:
About 0.1 miles from the Northern Terminus, you'll find a wooden bench. It was built as part of an Eagle Scout leadership service project in 2010, and more information can be found on the silver plaque in its upper right corner. 

Whether you are finishing your 1400 mile hike from south Florida, or have just stepped foot on the trail, take a moment to pause. Sit and relax for just a few minutes and you'll begin to hear bird calls arise from the bushes around you.
audioDescription: Sitting on the wooden bench, you are surrounded by vegetation. The leaves rustle and bird calls begin to arise from the bushes around you. A silver plaque on the bench reads: "Eagle Scout Leadership Service Project by Jacob Harris. June 6, 2010. Boy Scouts of America Troop 417. St. Ann Catholic Church, Gulf Breeze FL

title: Florida Trail Stop 3
listingDescription: Look for wildlife, view the Florida National Scenic Trail Terminus plaque, or just enjoy the water at this wooden footbridge.

images.altText: A wooden bridge arches over and turns into a trail that continues on into the forest.
images.title: Florida National Scenic Trail Stop 3
images.caption: Florida National Scenic Trail Footbridge

bodyText:
Standing in front of you is a wooden footbridge surrounded by vegetation. On the south side and closest to Fort Pickens, you'll notice a metal plaque enclosed by a brick structure. It was installed by the Florida National Scenic Trail Association to mark the northern terminus of the trail.

If you look into the water below the footbridge, you may see fish or alligator snapping turtles. Look above you and you may see herons nesting in the treetops or eagles flying overhead. Enjoy observing and taking pictures of wildlife, but please do not feed any animals. Be wary of other hikers on the trail, especially those on bicyles or with dogs.
audioDescription: In front of you is a wooden footbridge surrounded by water on both sides. There is a small brick structure with a metal plaque adjacent to the bridge that houses the official Florida National Scenic Trail Northern Terminus marker. The path continues after the bridge in both directions, sandy and surrounded by trees and bushes.

title: Florida Trail Stop 4
listingDescription: An intersection on the Florida Trail that can take you in a few different directions.

images.altText: Sparse vegetation stands at the intersection of trails and a roadway.
images.title: Florida National Scenic Trail Stop 4
images.caption: Florida National Scenic Trail Stop 4

bodyText: Here, the Florida National Scenic Trail is accessible from the road, located on the south side of the trail. On the north side, a small trail and a 15 minute walk will take you down to the bay, where you may see birds and other wildlife. To continue toward Battery Worth, walk west for another 0.3 miles. To continue to Fort Pickens, walk west for about 0.4 miles.
audioDescription: Sparse vegetation sprawls on both sides of the trail. The ground is patchy with dirt and sand, and you may hear cars pass on the road nearby. Another trail to the north is sandy, and will take you down to the bay.

title: Florida Trail Stop 5
listingDescription: Enter Fort Pickens campground Loops B-E, or head west toward Battery Worth.

images.altText: A sign for the Florida National Scenic Trail stands in front of a paved campground loop.
images.title: Florida National Scenic Trail Loops B-E
images.caption: Florida National Scenic Trail at For Pickens Campground Loops B-E

bodyText: This is the intersection of the Florida National Scenic Trail and Fort Pickens Campground Loops B-E. The Florida Trail runs through the campground, past restrooms, tent and RV sites, and other amenities. Please be respectful of visitors staying at the campsites as you make your way through. Follow the paved road straight through the campground to reach the sign to continue on the Florida National Scenic Trail leading to Campground Loop A.
audioDescription: Ahead of you lies Fort Pickens Campground Loops B-E. There are tent and RV sites, restrooms, parking, and trails, with many trees and grassy patches.

title: Florida Trail Stop 6
listingDescription: On the west side of Campground Loops B-E, the trail leaves the pavement and reenters the sand and pines.

images.altText: A sign for the Florida Trail stands in front of a grassy path.
images.title: Florida Trail at Campground Loop E
images.caption: Florida Trail at Campground Loop E

bodyText:
Behind you stands Fort Pickens Campground Loops B-E. Close by, in front of overflow parking, you'll find a short Bay Trail that will take you down to the water if you choose. If not, cross over the wooden planks and continue straight, where you'll once again step onto a hard dirt path surrounded by vegetation. There is not much shade on this section of trail, so bring water and sun protection.

0.15 miles into this section you will find the Blackbird Marsh Trail Loop, which also links up to campground Loop A. After about 0.75 to 1 mile of hiking, you can reach the Langdon Beach Pavillion, or a pavillion located near campground registration.
audioDescription: Wooden planks in front of you cross over onto a hard dirt trail. Behind you stands a campground with grassy spots, RVs, and tents. The pine trees and bushes grow high, and you may hear birds chirping nearby or cars driving around the campsites.

title: Florida Trail Stop 7
listingDescription: An intersection will take you to Battery Langdon, a nearby pavilion, or back to the campgrounds

images.altText: A sign for the Florida National Scenic Trail stands in front of an gravel trail and vegetation.
images.title: Florida Trail Stop 7
images.caption: Florida Trail Stop 7

bodyText:
You've reached the intersection of the Florida National Scenic Trail with two gravel trails. To the south, you may follow a very short trail leading to Battery Langdon. To the east, you may hike past a park compound to reach a pavillion, parking area, and small trail leading to the bay. You may continue the Florida Trail in either direction, as both locations must eventually turn south to cross Fort Pickens Road and enter Langdon Beach. 

To the west, the trail reaches campground Loops B-E after 0.6 miles and continues on to Fort Pickens.
audioDescription: Two paths stretch in front of a sign for the Florida Trail. The path to your right is very sandy and leads to a large hill, which is actually a concrete battery covered by bushes and trees. The left path on the left is gravel and leads to a pavilion and restrooms. Behind you, there is more sparse vegetation.

title: Fort Barrancas
listingDescription:
High on a bluff overlooking the entrance to Pensacola Bay, Fort Barrancas stands as a monument to the legacy of America's early homeland defense. Built with 6 million bricks, walls 4 feet thick and 20 feet high, Fort Barrancas was completed in 1844 and remains an example of military engineering and a marvel of human ingenuity.

Check out the Fort Barrancas Tour in your app to explore this historic structure.

images.altText: Exterior brick walls of Fort Barrancas and the white walls of the Spanish Water Battery.
images.caption: Fort Barrancas

bodyText:
Fort Barrancas stands as a monument to the legacy of America's early homeland defense. Overlooking Pensacola Bay, Fort Barrancas is the last in a series of forts built on this strategic bluff, and was used by Spain, France, Britain, and the United States. Built with 6 million bricks, walls 4 feet thick and 20 feet high, Fort Barrancas was completed in 1844 and remains an example of military engineering and a marvel of human ingenuity.

Begin your 10-stop self-guided tour of Fort Barrancas here then explore the rest of the Fort Barrancas Area. 

The Fort Barrancas Area consist of Fort Barrancas, Spanish Water Battery, and Advance Redoubt. It was recently recognized as a Network to Freedom site. 
 
Tour the visitor center, Fort Barrancas, and Spanish Water Battery. Hike the Woodland Trail. Then walk along the Trench Trail-or drive-to Advanced Redoubt, a nearby fortification built by the United States in the mid-1800s to protect Fort Barrancas and Pensacola Navy Yard from land-based attacks.
audioDescription: High on a bluff overlooking the entrance to Pensacola Bay, Fort Barrancas stands as a monument to the legacy of America's early homeland defense. Built with 6 million bricks, walls 4 feet thick and 20 feet high, Fort Barrancas was completed in 1844 and remains an example of military engineering and a marvel of human ingenuity. The Fort Barrancas Area consist of Fort Barrancas, Spanish Water Battery, and Advance Redoubt. Overlooking Pensacola Bay, Fort Barrancas is the last in a series of forts built on this strategic bluff and was used by Spain, France, Britain, and the United States.
passportStampLocationDescription: Network to Freedom and Fort Barrancas Area

images.altText: A wooden orientation kiosk with information panels and a bulletin board.
images.caption: Fort Barrancas Area Orientation Kiosk

bodyText:
Fort Barrancas Area

The Fort Barrancas Area consist of Fort Barrancas, Spanish Water Battery, and Advance Redoubt. Overlooking Pensacola Bay, Fort Barrancas is the last in a series of forts built on this strategic bluff between 1698 and 1844 and used by Spain, France, Britain, and the United States.
 
Tour the visitor center, Fort Barrancas, and Spanish Water Battery. Hike the Woodland Trail. Then walk along the Trench Trail-or drive-to Advanced Redoubt, a nearby fortification built by the United States in the mid-1800s to protect Fort Barrancas and Pensacola Navy Yard from land-based attacks.
audioDescription:
Fort Barrancas Area. 391 words.
Gulf Islands National Seashore. 417 words.

Fort Barrancas Area. 391 words.

Text at the upper left of this panel reads,

"Overlooking Pensacola Bay, Fort Barrancas is the last in a series of forts built on this strategic bluff between 1698 and 1844 and used by Spain, France, Britain, and the United States. Tour the visitor center, Fort Barrancas, and Spanish Water Battery. Hike the Woodland Trail. Then walk along the Trench Trail-or drive-to Advanced Redoubt, a nearby fortification built by the United States in the mid-1800s to protect Fort Barrancas and Pensacola Navy Yard from land-based attacks."

To the right is a photograph of one long wall of Fort Barrancas with a line of openings or gun ports. Its high wall is topped by an earthen berm and a flag pole flying the American flag.

Below the text is a map of this area of the national seashore, with the direction north at the bottom. The park's area runs north-south with Taylor road cutting across its middle. Your current location is at the visitor center in the upper third of the park. From here the Trench Trail runs down the map to the north, crossing Taylor road and ending at Advanced Redoubt. From here at the visitor center, the Woodland Trail makes a loop in the southwest corner of the park. Another short trail heads southeast from the visitor center to the triangular-shaped Fort Barrancas and the "U" shaped Spanish Water Battery just to the south of the fort. Parking is available here and at Advanced Redoubt. Restrooms and picnic tables are located here at the visitor center.

Text to the side of the map reads,

"Safety Precautions. Beware of uneven and slippery surfaces. Stay off walls and historic objects. Watch children closely."

Across the bottom of the panel are three photographs. Beginning at the left is a picture of the gleaming white Spanish Water Battery, taken from the rear. Its back wall extends to the right, while in front the curved walls face the water of Pensacola Bay in the background.

The middle picture shows a gallery in Fort Barrancas, a long corridor formed by a series of arches through brick rooms, lit by windows to the right.

The final picture shows Advanced Redoubt, a view down the dry ditch overlooked by openings in the fort wall to the right

Gulf Islands National Seashore. 417 words.

This panel is four feet wide and three feet tall. Across the middle is a map showing the various areas of the park. The map includes most of the Mississippi coastline, the Alabama coastline and the westernmost part of the Florida panhandle. Areas included in the park are outlined in green - several off-shore islands near Biloxi, Mississippi and other islands off the Florida coast from Perdido Key in the west to Okaloosa at the eastern end. Park areas on the mainland include Davis Bayou near Biloxi, Fort Barrancas in Pensacola and Naval Live Oaks south of Pensacola.

Text on the panel is in both English and Spanish. At the top text reads,

"This national seashore protects our historical heritage and ever-changing features of the Gulf Coast-salt marshes, marine woodlands, sparkling white beaches, and coastal waters. Walk the trails, photograph seashore plants and wildlife, swim and boat in the emerald green waters, learn the stories of early inhabitants, or just relax and enjoy the solitude."

To the right of the text is a photograph of a white sandy beach stretching into the distance, wispy dune grass on the right and water at upper left.

Text below the map reads,

Gulf Islands National Seashore includes several islands and portions of the mainland. Here you can boat, fish, and swim in the gulf waters. On land the national seashore provides campgrounds, primitive camping areas, and trails that pass through dunes, woodlands, and marshes-habitats of a variety of mammals, reptiles, and birds. For information, exhibits, and bookstores, stop at the visitor centers."

Across the bottom of the panel are five photographs. Beginning at the left, the first one shows an alligator stretched out on a log in bright sunshine. The label reads, "Wildlife."

The next picture shows a group of people looking out over a grassy area surrounded by red brick walls. The back wall has large arched openings into dark spaces behind. In the middle are three uniformed men standing with rifles at their sides. At the right is a man dressed in a park uniform. The label reads, "Tours."

The middle photograph shows crooked live oak tree branches dripping with long Spanish moss. The label reads, "Nature."

The fourth picture shows three children in swim suits splashing in shallow water. The label reads, "Recreation."

The last picture shows a view down a structure made of a series of rounded arches, light coming from openings on the left. The label reads, "History."

End of Description.

title: Fort Barrancas Entrance Sign
listingDescription: The Fort Barrancas Area is located onboard Naval Air Station Pensacola and features centuries of coastal defensive structures. Tour the visitor center, visit Fort Barrancas, or hike the Woodland Trail. Then walk along the Trench Trail or drive to Advanced Redoubt.

images.caption: Fort Barrancas Area Entrance Sign

bodyText: The Fort Barrancas Area is located on Naval Air Station Pensacola, Florida, and features centuries of coastal defensive structures. Tour the visitor center, visit Fort Barrancas, or hike the Woodland Trail. Then walk along the Trench Trail or drive to Advanced Redoubt.
audioDescription: There are two entrance signs to the Fort Barrancas Area which is located on Naval Air Station Pensacola and features centuries of coastal defensive structures. Tour the visitor center, visit Fort Barrancas, or hike the Woodland Trail. Then walk along the Trench Trail or drive to Advanced Redoubt .

title: Fort Barrancas Overlook
listingDescription: The US Army built Fort Barrancas in the 1840s as one of four fortifications to protect Pensacola Bay and the navy yard from attack. Fort Pickens on Santa Rosa Island and Fort McRee on Perdido Key guarded the channel. Fort Barrancas and its water battery, situated on a bluff, could support their crossfire and fire shots at ships that entered the bay. Advanced Redoubt was built to protect the Navy Yard and Fort Barrancas from a land-based attack. During the Civil War the Confed

images.altText: Three metal framed National Park Service signs. The white Spanish Water Battery and brick Fort Barrancas in the background.
images.caption: Fort Barrancas Overlook Site Photo

bodyText:
The U.S. Army built Fort Barrancas in the 1840's as one of four fortifications to protect Pensacola Bay and the navy yard from attack. Fort Pickens on Santa Rosa Island and Fort McRee on Perdido Key, guarded the channel.

Americans built harbor forts during the Revolutionary War (first system) and another series of forts between 1789 and 1812 (second system). Advanced Redoubt and Forts Barrancas, Pickens, and McRee were part of the Third System of coastal fortifications built between 1816 and 1870.

Fort Barrancas and its water battery, situated on a bluff, could support their crossfire and fire shots at ships that entered the bay.

Advanced Redoubt was built to protect the Navy Yard and Fort Barrancas from a land-based attack. During the Civil War the Confederates briefly held Fort Barrancas and exchanged gunfire with Federal forces at Fort Pickens.

Spanish Water Battery
The white, stuccoed, semicircular structure down in front of you is BaterÃ­a de San Antonio, a battery built by Spain in 1797. After recapturing the Pensacola area from the British, the Spanish decided to build this fortification as part of a plan to strengthen harbor defenses. The maximum range of smoothbore cannon at that time was about one mile. The United States modified and armed the battery while building Fort Barrancas in the 1840s.

The term water battery comes from the fortification's location, which was close to water level. From this battery gunners could fire smoothbore cannon shots at ship masts or skip shots across the surface of the bay hoping to hit wooden hulls at the waterline.

Fort McRee
In front of you across Pensacola Bay once stood Fort McRee. The US Army built the fort at the end of Perdido Key in the early 1840s to help protect Pensacola Bay and ended up almost destroying it during the Civil War. In January 1861-three months before the war started at Fort Sumter in South Carolina-the US Army abandoned Barrancas and Fort McRee and consolidated its troops at Fort Pickens. The governors of Alabama and Florida quickly dispatched state militias to occupy the vacant military posts. In a massive artillery exchange with the Confederates in November, cannon fire from two Union ships and Fort Pickens nearly demolished Fort McRee. Considered obsolete by the end of the Civil War, Fort McRee was never repaired.

Simultaneous volleys raked [Fort McRee's] outer walls and parapets ... the whole structure seemed to bulge and sink to earth in one general conflagration.

Years after the Civil War battle the ruins of Fort McRee crumbled into the sand and the Gulf of Mexico.

Fort Pickens on Santa Rosa Island and Fort McRee on Perdido Key guarded the channel. Fort Barrancas and its water battery, situated on a bluff, could support their crossfire and fire shots at ships that entered the bay. Advanced Redoubt was built to protect the Navy Yard and Fort Barrancas from a land-based attack. During the Civil War the Confederates briefly held Fort Barrancas and exchanged gunfire with Federal forces at Fort Pickens."At the right side of the panel is a map showing the four forts in the Pensacola area with orange circles showing their firing ranges. The map has the direction north at the bottom. Your current location is at Fort Barrancas, which with the adjacent Spanish Water Battery sits on the shore of the Pensacola Bay at the top of the map (to the south). Fort Pickens is shown on the western end of the island south of the bay with Fort McRee on another island to the west. Firing ranges from these three forts overlap over the entrance to the bay. Advanced Redoubt is directly north of Fort Barrancas, near the bottom of the map. The caption reads, "Third System Forts. Each cannon has a crew of eight men in blue uniforms lined up on both sides. One man holds a long pole over the rear of the cannon. Other men in uniform observe the action from the rear.At the left is an illustration of one of the soldiers. He wears a long blue jacket and knee britches with wide red cuffs and red stocking, a three-cornered hat on his head. He holds a long pointed pole with a white string looped over the end. The caption reads, "A Spanish artilleryman holds a slow match used in firing a cannon."At lower right is a drawing of a cannon firing from the wall of a fort on shore at left towards a three-masted ship in the water at the right. A yellow line traces the path of the cannon ball which hits the water near the ship and the bounces up to hit its side.
