In January 1861-three months before the war started at Fort Sumter in South Carolina-the US Army abandoned Barrancas and Fort McRee and consolidated its troops at Fort Pickens. The governors of Alabama and Florida quickly dispatched state militias to occupy the vacant military posts. In a massive artillery exchange with the Confederates in November, cannon fire from two Union ships and Fort Pickens nearly demolished Fort McRee. Considered obsolete by the end of the Civil War, Fort McRee was never repaired."Below the text is a brown-toned photograph of Confederate soldiers standing in formation at For McRee. Two rows of men stand in attention on the sand. Dunes rise to high fort walls behind them. The men wear hats and hold rifles at their right sides. Two of the men do not have jackets. To the left is a quote from A History of the First Regiment Alabama Volunteer Infantry which reads, "Simultaneous volleys raked [Fort McRee's] outer walls and parapets ... the whole structure seemed to bulge and sink to earth in one general co

title: Fort Barrancas Tour: Stop 1
listingDescription:
Glacis


This gentle earthen slope protected the fort from land-based artillery while exposing attacking infantrymen.

images.altText: A cement sidewalk cuts through a grassy field with green trees. A brown metal sign with the number, "1" is posted in the center.
images.caption: Fort Barrancas Self-Guided Tour Stop 1

bodyText:
Glacis

The first stop on the tour is the gentle earthen slope, called a glacis (glah SEE), protected Fort Barrancas. In a battle, the glacis shielded the fort’s brick walls from cannon fire. When attacked by land, soldiers had to charge uphill while in full view of the defenders inside Fort Barrancas.

Enslaved laborers used sand to build the glacis. They likely used sand from the dry ditch they dug into the bluff. Using carts pulled by mules, enslaved laborers transported sand around the construction site. They planted grass on the glacis to protect the slope from erosion.
audioDescription:
96 words.

This tour stop is on the walk leading to the fort. On the right of the walk the ground rises in a grassy slope. Standing here at the bottom, nothing can be seen of the fort itself which is on the other side. Over the crest of the hill, slightly to the left, is a flag pole with the American flag.

The slope is bare of trees, although there are several along the sidewalk. To the left of the walk is a fence separating this area from the woods.

End of Description.

quickFacts.value: Network to Freedom; Civil War; slavery, Black History
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Fort Barrancas Tour: Stop 10
listingDescription:
Water Battery



The tunnel from the parade leads to the water battery. Cannon projectiles from the battery ricocheted off of the surface of the bay to hit ships at the water line.

images.altText: Spanish Water Battery
images.title: Spanish Water Battery
images.caption: Spanish Water Battery

bodyText:
Spanish Water Battery

A steep tunnel runs underground from the parade to Batería de San Antonio, or the Spanish Water Battery, a National Historic Landmark.

In the military, a battery is a small structure designed for cannon or a group of cannon commanded by a single officer. Spanish engineers built this battery between 1797–1798 after declaring war on Great Britain. From its location at the shoreline, seven cannon could ricochet cannonballs across the surface of the bay to hit ships at the water line. To protect the battery’s rear, a small stockade named Castillo de San Carlos was built on the bluff rising above.

After Spanish West Florida became a US territory in the 1820s, Army engineers demolished the Castillo and built Fort Barrancas in its place. They then modernized the Spanish Water Battery and named it Barrancas Water Battery. With 15 cannon, the battery continued its original purpose in protecting the entrance to Pensacola Bay.
audioDescription:
161 words.

This tour stop is located on one side of the main part of the Spanish Water Battery as you exit the tunnel passageway from the parade ground of Fort Barrancas. To the left is a 10-foot-high wall topped by a level space where the cannon were placed. To the right there is an alcove in the wall of the main structure about 15 feet wide and 10 feet deep. On the back wall of the alcove is an opening near the ground level, now covered with iron bars. The opening has a wooden shutter which can be closed.

Underfoot a narrow brick walk leads around the wall to the right to the main open space of the fort. From there on the right is a long staircase, 26 steps in all, which leads up to a platform with high walls. On the left, a shorter staircase, 14 steps, leads up to the cannon area.

End of Description.

quickFacts.value: Spanish Water Battery, Batería de San Antonio, Historic Landmark,
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Fort Barrancas Tour: Stop 2
listingDescription:
Drawbridge



Operated by a counterweight and winch, it pivoted at the center. It could be raised to isolate the fort's scarp from a land-based attack.

images.altText: Brick pathway leads across a green wooden drawbridge to an archway opening in the side of a brick fort.
images.caption: Fort Barrancas Drawbridge to Main Entrance

bodyText:
Drawbridge

Enslaved carpenters built a drawbridge for Fort Barrancas in 1843. The drawbridge was operated by a counterweight and winch system.

Soldiers would use the drawbridge to cross over the dry ditch from the counterscarp and enter the fort. The drawbridge would be lowered during peacetime and raised to secure the fort before a battle. The mechanism for raising and lowering the drawbridge can still be seen inside the fort today.
audioDescription:
222 words.

This tour stop is at the head of the drawbridge over the dry ditch leading to the entrance of the main part of the fort. At the far end of the bridge is an arched opening in the wall leading into the fort. Above the wall is an earth mound or berm. Slightly to the left on the far side of the berm is a flag pole with the American flag.

The first 20 feet of the entranceway is paved with brick and slopes downward through a cut in the earth that is mounded against the outer wall protecting the fort. Between the outer wall and the main wall of the fort, the deep dry ditch stretches 30 feet. The bridge over the ditch is wooden. There are no railings, but there is a raised wooden curb on either side.

From the bridge there is a good view of the ditch on either side stretching along the wall. Tall brick walls border each side of the ditch with narrow openings facing each other across the ditch. The left end of the ditch is open. On the right side, the ditch turns to go down the far side of the fort. Openings in the outer wall at that point look down the ditch on this side.

End of Description.

quickFacts.value: Civil War, Black History, Confederates, Network to Freedom
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Fort Barrancas Tour: Stop 3
listingDescription:
Scarp and Counterscarp



The main walls (scarp) supported the barbette which provided defense against both ships and infantry. The outer walls (counterscarp) supported the glacis and provided loopholes for muskets and embrasures for cannon to fire into the ditch.

Ditch



A dry ditch covered two sides of the fort. Assaulting infantrymen who entered the ditch would suffer heavy casualties from musket and cannon fire through openings in the walls.

images.altText: Exterior brick walls of the fort showing loopholes spaced evenly along each wall. A large, open, grassy field is in between the walls.
images.caption: Fort Barrancas Scarp and Counterscarp Walls and Ditch

bodyText:
Scarp and Counterscarp

The fort’s main exterior wall is called a scarp. The scarp measures 20 feet tall and four feet thick. The scarp is a free-standing structure, meaning the wall is not attached to the fort’s inner framework. This design feature allowed soldiers to continue using Fort Barrancas even if the scarp collapsed in a battle.

The counterscarp, or outer wall, supports the glacis. Long galleries, or passageways, run along the inside of the counterscarp.

The scarp and counterscarp are pierced with ventilators, loopholes, and embrasures (em BRAY shures). Ventilators allow air to circulate inside the fort. Soldiers fired muskets through narrow loopholes and cannon through wide embrasures.
audioDescription:
212 words.

This point is located at the top of the sloped earth at the edge of the outer wall of the fort near the northeast corner. This paved area is 15 feet deep and 6 feet wide. A metal railing extends along the south and east sides, where there is a steep drop off. On the north side, to the left, there is a bench. On the right, the south side, there are three slanted graphic panels.

Looking over the railing on the south side there is a clear view of the walls of the main fort extending away from you and to the right. The dry ditch extends to the right. The drawbridge is about halfway down the wall in that direction. The main walls of the fort itself are topped with mounds of protective dirt. Near the corner of the fort is a flag pole with the American flag.

Slight to the left, in front of the fort are the white walls of the Spanish Water Battery. Located down slope of the main fort, its "U" shaped walls look out over the bay. The entrance to Pensacola Bay is directly in front of you with low islands on either side of it.

End of Description.

quickFacts.value: Civil War, Black History, Confederates, Network to Freedom
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Fort Barrancas Tour: Stop 4

images.altText: Dry Ditch in Fort Barrancas
images.title: Dry Ditch Fort Barrancas
images.caption: Dry ditch in Fort Barrancas.

bodyText:
Dry Ditch


A dry ditch runs along the two landward sides of Fort Barrancas. Soldiers charging into the dry ditch would suffer heavy losses from muskets and cannon firing from the loopholes and embrasures.

Construction of Fort Barrancas began in June of 1840. No more than 60 enslaved people labored on the fort at any given time. They worked 10-hour days from spring to fall under the sweltering Florida sun. From fall to spring, they worked sunrise to sunset. They were allowed one hour for breakfast and dinner.

They began construction by digging this ditch into the bluff. They moved more than 16,000 tons of sand, or the equivalent of about 1,300 school buses.
audioDescription: A dry ditch runs along the two landward sides of Fort Barrancas. Soldiers charging into the dry ditch would suffer heavy losses from muskets and cannon firing from the loopholes and embrasures. Construction of Fort Barrancas began in June of 1840. No more than 60 enslaved people labored on the fort at any given time. They worked 10-hour days from spring to fall under the sweltering Florida sun. From fall to spring, they worked sunrise to sunset. They were allowed one hour for breakfast and dinner. They began construction by digging this ditch into the bluff. They moved more than 16,000 tons of sand, or the equivalent of about 1,300 school buses.

quickFacts.value: Civil War, Black History, Confederates, Network to Freedom
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Fort Barrancas Tour: Stop 5
listingDescription:
Sally Port



The main entrance to the fort was guarded by heavy oak doors. A small wicket gate allowed entry without opening the main doors.

images.altText: Two large, arched wooden doors stand at the front of a walkway.
images.title: Fort Barrancas Sally Port
images.caption: Fort Barrancas Sally Port

bodyText:
Sally Port

You are standing inside a covered walkway called a sally port. A sally port served as the main path into and out of a fort like Fort Barrancas.

Soldiers opened and closed heavy oak doors to secure the sally port. Look closely and you will see a smaller door in the bigger door. This wicket door allowed entry without opening the main doors.

The bricks around you supported different industries in West Florida. Local sawmill and brickyard owners relied on enslaved people to operate. To fire kilns for baking bricks, enslaved lumbermen harvested firewood from the region’s rich forests. To produce bricks, brickyard owners trained enslaved men in various brickmaking skills and shipped bricks to construction sites on Pensacola Bay and along the Gulf Coast.
audioDescription:
238 words.

This tour stop is in the entrance tunnel or sally port of the fort. It runs 40 feet through the center of the northern wall of the main fort. A wooden drawbridge slants down from the outer wall to the arched doorway. As you enter, the footing changes to brick paving for a few feet, then changes again to asphalt and begins to slope up to the parade ground in the middle of the fort.

On the wall on either side of the entrance, just where the footing changes from wood to brick, are two-foot-long heavy iron cylinders which were the cranks or winches for the drawbridge. Feel free to touch. There is no chain, but you can feel the guide grooves in the cylinder and the toothed ratchet at one end.

One the inside of this thick wall are the large wooden doors dotted with the square heads of the bolts holding it together. In the left-hand door there is a smaller rectangular door, just big enough for a person to squeeze through when the big doors were closed.

Just past the doors on the right is the low entrance to the guardroom. There are three steps down to the room. On the other side of the tunnel is a longer set of steps leading to a tunnel under the ditch which goes to the gallery under the outer wall.

End of Description.

quickFacts.value: Civil War, Black History, Confederates, Network to Freedom
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Fort Barrancas Tour: Stop 6
listingDescription:
Guard Room



This room had four bunks and a six-man guard detail. Soldiers rotated with two men on guard duty (2-hours on, 4-hours off, for 24-hours) while four men rested. The main barracks were to the east of the fort.

images.altText: A large green box mounted to the wall and several benches stand under an arched brick ceiling.
images.title: Fort Barrancas Guard Room
images.caption: Fort Barrancas Guard Room

bodyText:
Guard Room

In the 1800s, people in the United States believed that keeping a large army during peacetime was a threat to their nation. They preferred to rely on citizen-soldiers if war erupted, like their ancestors had in the American Revolution.

Of the forts, one Army engineer wrote: “When once constructed they require but little expenditure for their support. In time of peace they withdraw no valuable citizens from the useful occupations of life. Of themselves they can never exert an influence dangerous to public liberty; but as the means of preserving peace, and as obstacles to an invader, their influence and power are immense.”

To support this attitude and tradition, Army engineers did not design Fort Barrancas with living quarters for soldiers. Instead, professional soldiers serving in the small US Army lived nearby at Barrancas Barracks.

Even in peacetime, Fort Barrancas stored dozens of cannon and large quantities of ammunition that needed guarding. Soldiers stationed at the Army post took turns standing guard over the fort. They rotated with two men on duty (two hours on, four hours off, for 24 hours) while four men rested in this guard room.
audioDescription:
148 words.

This tour stop is in the guard room to the right of the entrance tunnel or sally port. It is a room with an arched ceiling, 15 feet wide and 23 feet deep. One end is along the outer wall with three narrow window openings overlooking the dry ditch. To reach the gallery under the fort's walls, move to that end of the room and turn left. A set of four steps leads down to the gallery.

At the other end of the room is the door off the sally port. One the wall there are two graphic panels. One the side wall nearest the sally port is a display of illustrations of the fort. Down the other side of the room are rows of short benches, facing the end of the room. A larger bench sits along the outside wall.

End of Description.

quickFacts.value: Civil War, Black History, Confederates, Network to Freedom
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Fort Barrancas Tour: Stop 7
listingDescription:
Scarp Gallery



A series of arches supported the sand fill and allowed access to the loopholes for muskets. Vertical vents above the loopholes allowed smoke from the guns to escape.

images.altText: Brick tunnel with a series of brick arches and loopholes.
images.caption: Fort Barrancas Scarp Gallery

bodyText:
Scarp Gallery

This covered walkway is a gallery. The gallery runs along the inside of Fort Barrancas and provided soldiers access to narrow loopholes. In a battle, soldiers would fire their muskets through these loopholes. Ventilators above the loopholes allowed gun powder smoke to escape.

Look closely down the length of the gallery and you will see a wall made up of arches supporting sand fill. Army engineers used this innovative technique because a curved surface can support more weight than a flat surface.

Like all buildings, Fort Barrancas required maintenance after its completion. In 1851, a slaveholder rented an enslaved man named Peter Dyson to Army engineers. Engineers forced Dyson to make masonry repairs to the fort. In 1861, the first year of the American Civil War, Peter and his wife Henrietta sailed to Fort Pickens and freedom on the Underground Railroad.
audioDescription:
138 words.

This tour stop is in the gallery under the main walls of the fort. The passageway runs through a series of arched rooms facing the outer wall. Each has two chest-high, narrow openings on the outer wall overlooking the dry ditch. At the peak of the arch between the window openings is a small vent hole. On the other side of the room is a five-foot high wall with the space behind filled with sand. You can reach over the wall to feel the sand.

The rooms are connected by three-foot-wide arched doorways through the walls in between the rooms which form one long corridor. The bricks forming the doorway arches has been cut to form the curved shape. Feel free to touch.

The flooring is brick and may be uneven.

End of Description.

quickFacts.value: Civil War, Black History, Confederates, Network to Freedom
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Fort Barrancas Tour: Stop 8
listingDescription:
Counterscarp Gallery



A tunnel under the ditch leads to this casemated area, containing loopholes for muskets, embrasures for cannon, and powder magazines to allow reverse fire into the ditch.

images.altText: A large arched wooden door stands in a brick wall adjacent to a wall with a hole for cannon.
images.title: Fort Barrancas Counterscarp Gallery
images.caption: Fort Barrancas Counterscarp Gallery

bodyText:
Counterscarp Gallery

A tunnel under the dry ditch leads to this casemated, or enclosed, gallery. Like the scarp gallery, the counterscarp gallery has loopholes for muskets and ventilators for air circulation and powder magazines for storing gun powder.

Unlike the scarp gallery, this gallery also has embrasures for cannon. At each embrasure, look down at the floor and you will find granite blocks, or traverse stones. With iron rails bolted on top, traverse stones made rolling cannon from side to side easier.

Today you can still see the remains of traverse stones around the fort.
audioDescription:
104 words.

This tour stop is in the counterscarp gallery, a long arched passageway or corridor that runs the length of the walls that face the main fort over the dry ditch. The gallery has an arched ceiling and is about six feet wide. The walls and ceiling are painted white. Along the wall facing the main fort are window openings with narrow vertical slits. The window ledges are four feet off the floor. Above the windows are small vent holes. In the corners of the gallery there are larger areas with larger openings where cannon could be placed.

End of Description.

quickFacts.value: Civil War, Black History, Confederates, Network to Freedom
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Fort Barrancas Tour: Stop 9
listingDescription:
Parade



This open area is where troops were inspected or drilled. The foundation in the corner indicates where a hot shot furnace, in which round shot was heated before firing, once stood.

images.altText: Several dirt ramps lead down to a grassy field with brick walls in the background.
images.title: Fort Barrancas Parade Field
images.caption: Image of Parade at Fort Barrancas in Florida.

bodyText:
Parade

This open area is a parade. Officers would assemble their men on the parade to deliver instructions or conduct inspections.

Three footpaths connect the parade to a barbette (bar BET), or earthen platform. Here 34 pieces of seacoast artillery, the heaviest cannon used in the 1800s, pointed over the fort’s brick walls. Today a 24-pounder cannon points toward Pensacola Bay. This cannon was cast in 1837 by McClurg, Wade and Company at the Fort Pitt Foundry in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

The entire area is about 150 feet across, with the 25 feet nearest the walls sloping upward to a flat space along the walls where cannon could be stationed. This outer wall is about four feet high. One cannon is in place near the north east corner mounted on a base with wheels that allow it to be pointed in different directions. Feel free to touch, but do not climb. 

A reconstructed brick floor can be seen in one corner of the parade. Enslaved bricklayers built a hot shot furnace on this spot in 1847. Soldiers used this furnace to turn solid cannonballs cherry red. These missiles were used to set targets like wooden ships on fire.
audioDescription:
213 words.

This tour stop is located in the parade ground which is the open space in the middle of the fort. This area is roughly triangular with the point in the north west and the entrance tunnel, or sally port, near the middle of the north side. The area is about 150 feet across, with the 25 feet nearest the walls sloping upward to a flat space along the walls where cannon could be stationed. This outer wall is about four feet high. One cannon is in place near the north east corner mounted on a base with wheels that allow it to be pointed in different directions. Feel free to touch. The flag pole flying the American flag is also in this corner.

A dirt path extends across the parade from the sally port to another tunnel on the south wall. This tunnel heads downward with alternating sets of steps and steep slopes and leads to the Spanish Water Battery. There are benches to the side of the path in the middle of the parade.

At ground level towards the southwest corner, just before the slope to the surrounding wall, is a 10-foot square of brick paving which formed the foundation for a hot shot furnace.

End of Description.

quickFacts.value: Civil War, Black History, Confederates, Network to Freedom
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Fort Barrancas Trench Remnant
listingDescription: Here is a remnant of the Barrancas Trench, a long trench dug out of the earth between Fort Barrancas and Advanced Redoubt during the Civil War. In 1863, a party of 60 US soldiers was split into squads of 20 men, who worked six hour shifts day and night, digging until the entrenchment was completed. This ditch was placed in front of a breast-high wall, which served as a formidable obstacle against attacking Confederate troops.

images.altText: An interpretive panel describes the remains of the trench that lie behind the vegetation.
images.caption: Fort Barrancas Trench with wayside

bodyText: Here is a remnant of the Barrancas Trench, a long trench dug out of the earth between Fort Barrancas and Advanced Redoubt during the Civil War. In 1863, a party of 60 US soldiers was split into squads of 20 men, who worked six hour shifts day and night, digging until the entrenchment was completed. This ditch was placed in front of a breast-high wall, which served as a formidable obstacle against attacking Confederate troops.
audioDescription:
273 words
This spot is near the middle of the Trench Trail which runs between Fort Barrancas and Advanced Redoubt. On one side the road is fairly close, so you may hear the sounds of passing vehicles. On that side, there can just be seen a earth mound running parallel to the trail and the road beyond. The mound is overgrown and hard to glimpse through the thick underbrush in the woods here. The dirt trail extends in either direction through the woods with patches of sunlight falling through the foliage overhead.

Text at the top of an interpretive panel reads,

"Here is a remnant of the Barrancas Trench, a long trench dug out of the earth between Fort Barrancas and Advanced Redoubt during the Civil War. In 1863, a party of 60 US soldiers was split into squads of 20 men, who worked six hour shifts day and night, digging until the entrenchment was completed. This ditch was placed in front of a breast-high wall, which served as a formidable obstacle against attacking Confederate troops."

At the bottom of the panel is a color illustration showing a cross section of the trench. Starting at the left is the wide ditch. Along the right side of the ditch is a wall made of vertical logs sunk deep into the ground. Against the wall on the right is a mound of dirt. A horizontal log buried in this mound is tied to the vertical log, helping to anchor it. On the right side of the mound a Union soldier dress in a blue jacket and holding a rifle with a bayonet stand guard.

End of Description.

title: Fort Barrancas Visitor Center
listingDescription:
Start here on your visit to the Fort Barrancas Area . Enjoy indoor exhibits about the history of the area and restrooms. The center is staffed by park rangers or volunteers.

On the exterior of the building there are three interpretive panels that help tell the story about Fort Barrancas, Pensacola Bay, and the coastal defensive strategy of the United States during the 1800s.

images.altText: Brown brick building with the text, "Fort Barrancas Visitor Center." Entrance doors below the text. A brown and green National Park Service arrowhead sign hangs on the right of the building. A wooden bench in the foreground.
images.caption: Fort Barrancas Visitor Center

bodyText:
Start here on your visit to the Fort Barrancas Area. Enjoy indoor exhibits about the history of the area. On the exterior of the building there are three interpretive panels that help tell the story about Fort Barrancas, Pensacola Bay, and the coastal defensive strategy of the United States during the 1800s.

Travel through the breezeway to begin your self-guided tour of Fort Barrancas and the Spanish Water Battery.
audioDescription: Fort Barrancas Visitor Center. 191 words.The visitor center is a one-story building with a brick and concrete facade with a concrete patio in front. The glass entrance is near the center of the building. To the left of the entrance a breezeway leads to the rear of the building where the walk to the fort is located. On the left side of the breezeway are the restrooms. On the rear of the building on the right is a water fountain and water bottle refill station.Five benches are located around the patio in front. In the middle of the patio is a nine-foot-long cannon resting on concrete mounts. Between the patio and the entrance drive is a grassy area with a flag pole and two more cannon.The parking area lies to the left of the patio. At the right a sidewalk borders the entrance drive. Along the walk is an artillery exhibit with additional cannon and two mortars. There are several graphic panels in this area, mounted on the wall near the entrance, in the breezeway, in a kiosk near the parking area and next to the artillery exhibit.The Draw of Pensacola. 190 words.The background of this panel features a satellite image of Pensacola Bay and its surroundings. Along the bottom is the long thin line of barrier islands on either side of the passage into the bay itself. The large bay extends east from the entrance with two arms that go to the north. Just north of the entrance the runways on the naval air base can be seen with the city of Pensacola lying to the north of the main part of the bay.At the bottom of the panel is a drawing of a three-masted sailing ship. Text at the bottom right reads, "Emerald waters, sandy beaches, and naval aviation bring visitors to Pensacola today. The attraction to Europeans 300 years ago was underwater: the 20- to 50-foot-deep bay. The largest sailing ships could get close to the shore and they had natural protection by the barrier islands. Colonists settled near the harbor because it was the gateway to the rest of the world. The coastal forts now protected by Gulf Islands National Seashore were the locks on that gate."Defending Pensacola Bay. 203 words.Text at the upper left of this panel reads, "In the sweeping plan to defend our coastline in the early 1800s, Pensacola Bay rated four state-of-the-art fortifications. Military planners decided it was worth the expense. The bay could hold a whole fleet in its wide and deep waters. And in 1825 the Navy chose Pensacola to locate a facility for building, repairing, and supplying its ships - the only such facility in the Gulf of Mexico."Below the text is a drawing of a ship at anchor with three masts and a paddlewheel along its side. Behind it is a fort on a small peninsula of land.At the bottom of the panel is attached an old map of the entrance to the bay with Fort Pickens at the western end of Santa Rosa Island and Fort McRee on the other side of the entrance. On the mainland to the north of this part of the bay is a corner of land showing two street grids, one labeled Warrington and the other labeled Woolsey. To the west of them is a Naval Hospital, U.S. Barracks, Fort San Carlos and Advanced Redoubt, and two lighthouse beacons.Third System Forts. 535 words.This large panel is divided into three vertical sections. The section at left has a quote from Lieutenant Henry W. Halleck from the Report on the Means of National Defense from 1843. It reads, "When once constructed they (forts) require but little expenditure for their support. In time of peace they withdraw no valuable citizens from the useful occupations of life. Of themselves they can never exert an influence dangerous to public liberty; but as a means of preserving the peace, and as obstacles to an invader, their influence and power are immense."Underneath the quote is a portrait of Halleck from circa 1860 when he was a Major General.Text in the middle section of the panel reads, "The United States built Fort Barrancas and 41 other fortifications as part of a grand system to protect the nation's 35,000-mile coastline. Built between 1816 and 1870, this was the third such system in the nation's history. The defense system focused on harbors and river mouths, the major gateways to the nation's people and resources. Coastal forts functioned as locks on these gates. The state-of-the-art forts were designed to withstand the worst an enemy navy could send against them: wooden sailing ships with smoothbore cannons. Of the 42 Third System forts, only Fort McRee has completely disappeared."Above the text is a photograph of men loading cannon lined up along the walls of a fort. The caption reads, "Fort Barrancas was one of four forts built to protect Pensacola Bay and the Navy Yard. It didn't see action until the Civil War, when Confederate troops briefly held it against the Union."At the bottom of this section is a color illustration of a five-sided fort with a last projecting bastion at each point. A large harbor lies in the background full of various sailing ships. The caption reads, "Fo

title: Fort Massachusetts
listingDescription: In 1855, Secretary of War Jefferson Davis, a native of Mississippi, advocated building fortifications on Ship Island. Davis recalled that the British used the Mississippi Sound near Ship Island in 1814 to attack New Orleans. Though the fort never received an official Army title, Major General Winfield S. Hancock, called the structure Fort Massachusetts in 1884. This report is the first time it has been known by that name in an official document. Later, the Fort on Ship Island

images.altText: Fort Massachusetts
images.title: Fort Massachusetts
images.caption: Fort Massachusetts

bodyText:
In 1855, Secretary of War, Jefferson Davis, a native of Mississippi, advocated for building fortifications on Ship Island. Davis recalled that the British used the Mississippi Sound near Ship Island in 1814 to attack New Orleans. Though the fort never received an official Army title, Major General Winfield S. Hancock, called the structure Fort Massachusetts in 1884.

This report is the first time it has been known by that name in an official document. Later, the fort on Ship Island became known as Fort Massachusetts, after the Union ship which retook in the island in the fall of 1861.
audioDescription: Fort Massachusetts tour stop 1. 153 words.At this point a boardwalk leading to the entrance to the fort intersects the main boardwalk that crosses the island. As you face the fort there are three large graphic panels in freestanding wooden frames along the left side of the walk. Directly ahead is the Sally Port, the arched tunnel that goes through the east side of the fort into the open central yard. On either side of the entrance are two vertical window openings. At either corner the wall extends towards you, forming bastions.As you pass the outer wall, the flooring changes from the boardwalk to worn brick paving, which can be somewhat uneven. Standing open is a set of heavy double doors which could be closed to secure the fort. They are made of wooden planks set on a diagonal and secured with square metal studs. Feel free to touch the doors.End of Description.
passportStampLocationDescription: During seasons when Fort Massachusetts is open to the public, National Park Passport cancellations can be obtained from the visitor contact station.

title: Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 1
listingDescription:
Sally Port



Secured with heavy doors, this is the only entrance to the fort. Although a drawbridge was planned, it was never completed.

images.altText: Large wooden doors swing open in a red brick fort.
images.title: Fort Massachusetts Sally Port
images.caption: Fort Massachusetts Sally Port

bodyText:
Sally Port

Secured with heavy doors, the sally port is the only entrance to the fort. The doors are made of heavy oak. A smaller rectangular, door is carved into the lower left hand corner. It allowed entry without opening the main doors. Although a drawbridge was planned, it was never completed.
audioDescription: Secured with heavy doors, the sally port is the only entrance to the fort. The doors are made of light colored wood with what looks like peg holes in them. In the lower left hand corner is a smaller door that would have been used for entrance and exit instead of opening the big doors. Although a drawbridge was planned, it was never completed.

title: Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 10
listingDescription:
Powder Magazines



Located next to the guardrooms, powder magazines stored the fort's supply of black powder. The magazines were lined with wood to keep the powder dry.

images.altText: Large green wooden door in a brick fort wall.
images.caption: Fort Massachusetts Tour Stop 10

bodyText:
Powder Magazines



Located next to the guardrooms, powder magazines stored the fort's supply of black powder. The magazines were lined with wood to keep the powder dry.
audioDescription:
91 words.

This stop is located in front of one of the arched openings that line the inner walls of the fort. All the surfaces are red brick. From the opening a 30-foot long room with an arched ceiling extends towards the outer wall. Both sides of the room are solid. Near the rear of the room are two rectangular blocks sitting end-to-end extending out from the wall. In the middle of the rear wall is an open niche. The rest of the room is bare.

End of Description.

title: Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 11
listingDescription:
Half Bastions



Projecting out at each end of the fort's east wall, half bastions were designed to provide cross fire to protect the entrance.

images.altText: Brick fort walls with a small opening about two feet from the ground in one of the walls.
images.caption: Fort Massachusetts Tour Stop 11

bodyText:
Half Bastions



Projecting out at each end of the fort's east wall, half bastions were designed to provide cross fire to protect the entrance.
audioDescription:
73 words.

This stop is located in the southeast corner of the fort. Here the fort's walls extend out a short distance on either side of the main entrance below, forming half bastions. Soil covers the roof here allowing grass and small shrubs to grow. The top of the bastion is reached by two large steps up from the near-circular cannon emplacement in this corner of the fort.

End of Description.

title: Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 12
listingDescription:
Casemates



These arched rooms on the lower level of the fort provided support for the upper levell, and a protected firing position for cannon. In 1873, thirteen 10-inch Rodman cannon were mounted in these casemates, and were situated to fire through the embrasures.

images.altText: Red brick arches support the lower level of a fort.
images.title: Fort Massachusetts Casemates
images.caption: Fort Massachusetts Casemates

bodyText:
Casemates



These arched rooms on the lower level of the fort provided support for the upper levell, and a protected firing position for cannon. In 1873, thirteen 10-inch Rodman cannon were mounted in these casemates, and were situated to fire through the embrasures.
audioDescription:
124 words.

This stop is located in front of one of the arched openings that line the inner walls of the fort. All the surfaces are red brick. From the opening a 30-foot long room with an arched ceiling, or casemate, extends to the outer wall of the fort, ending in a small rectangular opening, or embrasure, in the thick outer wall. There is a short step up to the floor of the room. Along each side wall are two other arches that lead into similar rooms on either side, a wider arch near the outer wall, and a more narrow one near the inner wall. These side arches form open galleries following the contours of the fort's walls.

End of Description.

title: Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 2
listingDescription:
Terreplain



In 1866, the west end of the island was 500 feet from the fort. Today, the west tip is almost a mile away. From the terreplain, soldiers operated ten cannon positions covering the pass.

images.altText: A metal handrail guards a grassy edge at the top of a fort.
images.title: Fort Massachusetts Terreplain
images.caption: Fort Massachusetts Terreplain

bodyText:
Terreplain

The terreplain is a flat, soil covered area on top of the curved outer wall of the western side of the fort. From here soldiers operated ten cannon positions covering the pass. In 1866, the west end of the island was 500 feet from the fort. Today, the west tip is almost a mile away.
audioDescription:
124 words.

This tour stop is on the terreplein, a flat soil covered area on top of the curved outer wall of the western side of the fort. A brick retaining wall supports mounds of soil along the outer curve. Spaced along the wall are 10 semicircular cannon positions. Each is formed by an outer stone ring, about 18 inches high and 20 feet across, with an iron track running along its top. In the center is a nine-foot square pad about one foot high. In its center is a metal plate with a six-inch high iron post set in the middle. Standing by the post, the waters of the gulf can be glimpsed over the grassy outer mound.

End of Description.

title: Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 3
listingDescription:
Traverses



The east side of the fort's upper level is divided by large earthen traverses, which provided additional protection to the cannon positions and storange for powder and ammunition.

images.altText: Brick scarp wall supporting a grassy mound. An American flag peeks over the top of the mound.
images.caption: Fort Massachusetts Traverse

bodyText:
Traverses

The east side of the fort's upper level is divided by large, earthen traverses. The traverses provided additional protection to the cannon positions and storage for powder and ammunition.
audioDescription:
104 words.

Here is a narrow passageway between the gun emplacements on the upper level of the eastern side of the fort. The brick walk passes between two retainer walls made of brick, each from eight to ten feet tall. The wall on the eastern side is about 20 feet long. It is flat on top in the middle, then slopes down to ground level on either side. The soil mounded behind the wall extends all the way to the outer wall of the fort, making an earthen barrier between the cannon positions along this part of the wall.

End of Description.

title: Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 4
listingDescription:
15- Inch Rodman



The 15-inch Rodman weighs 50,000 pounds and fired a 400 pound cannon ball three miles. In 1873, this cannon was raised over the fort's wall and mounted here.

images.altText: A large cannon peers over the wall on top of a grassy fort.
images.title: Fort Massachusetts 15-inch Rodman
images.caption: Fort Massachusetts 15-inch Rodman

bodyText:
15-inch Rodman

On top of the northeast corner of the fort is a mound covered with soil and vegetation. In the middle of this mound is a 15-foot-wide circular area with a square pad. This would have been home to a 15-Inch Rodman gun. The Rodman weighs 50,000 pounds and could fire a 400 pound cannon ball three miles. In 1873, this cannon was raised over the fort's wall and mounted here.

The Rodman gun is any of a series of American Civil War–era columbiads designed by Union artilleryman Thomas Jackson Rodman. The guns were designed to fire both shot and shell. These heavy guns were intended to be mounted in seacoast fortifications. They were built in 8-inch, 10-inch, 13-inch, 15-inch, and 20-inch bore.
audioDescription:
497 words
This tour stop is on top of the northeast corner of the fort where one of the half bastions extend out on either side of the main entrance. Retaining walls on all sides support mounded soil covered with vegetation. In the middle of this 15-foot-wide roughly circular area is a stone pad with four iron circular rails and a square pad in the middle that supports a large cannon. The cannon is black and sits on a metal carriage that is a rust-red color. The carriage has wheels that rest on the iron rails, allowing the carriage to pivot about its center to aim the cannon in different directions. If you stand in front of the metal carriage, the bottom of the cannon is about head-height. Feel free to touch the cannon and its carriage. An American flag flies from a pole on the mound at the left of the cannon.

Interpretive panel: 15 Inch Rodman

At the bottom of this panel is a historical photograph which shows a group of men around a large cannon mounted on a large metal carriage and pointing to the left. The caption reads,

"A gun crew at Fort Warren in Boston, Mass., loads a Rodman. The cannon, designed by Thomas Jefferson Rodman, was first cast in 1860.

Labels on the photograph identify the different elements. One stands at the rear of the large cannon, where its diameter is almost equal to his height. He leans over to look at a small rod sticking up for the top of the cannon. The label reads,

"Gunner using sight to aim cannon."

At the front of the cannon one man holds a long rod with a round black sponge on its end. Next to him two other men pass a white sack which holds the powder charge. Another man stands waiting below the cannon's bore holding the long ramrod. Near the rear of the canon four men hold a metal bar, two at each end, with a large cannon ball attached to the middle. A label reads,

""Shell hooks and carrying bar for moving cannonballs."

At lower left is a pyramid-shaped pile of cannon ball, four wide and four high. The top cannonball has a rectangular object sitting on top of it. The label reads,

"Cannonball attached to sabot, which prevented it from rolling in barrel."

Next to the stack is a square metal box called a pass box.

Text at the top reads,

"This 15-inch Rodman is the fort's only remaining cannon. Two of these guns-among the largest smoothbore cannon ever manufactured-were on the upper level in the early 1870s. The barrel alone weighed 50,000 pounds. With a maximum effective range of three miles, the Rodman could fire a 15-inch diameter explosive shell weighing about 300 pounds or a solid shot weighing over 400 pounds. The circular iron tracks allowed the cannon to be turned to fire in any direction. This gun was never fired in combat."

End of Description.

title: Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 5
listingDescription:
Parrott Rifles



Unlike smoothbore cannon, projectiles fired from rifled cannon had greater range, accuracy and destructive power. Two 100-pounder Parrott rifles, protected the fort's eastern flank.

images.altText: A concrete and brick installment for a Parrot rifle stands at the top of a fort.
images.title: Fort Massachusetts Parrot Rifle Stand
images.caption: Fort Massachusetts Parrot Rifle Stand

bodyText:
Parrott Rifles

You are standing directly over the entrance to the fort. Two 100-pounder Parrott rifles were mounted here in the 1870s to protect the fort's eastern flank. Unlike the smoothbore cannon, Parrot projectiles fired from the rifled cannon had greater range, accuracy and destructive power.

The Parrot barrel had spiral grooves, called rifling, that caused the projectile to spin. This made the Parrotts much more accurate and destructive than earlier smoothbore cannons that fired round shots. The Parrots were cast iron muzzle-loaders like the smoothbores and could penetrate masonry forts. In the 1890s and early 1900s steel, breech-loading rifles replaced the Parrotts, and concrete-and-earthwork batteries replaced masonry fortifications like Fort Massachusetts.
audioDescription:
276 words
This tour stop is directly over the entrance to the fort. Retaining walls on all sides support mounds of soil covered with vegetation forming a rectangular area facing east. Along the outer wall there are two side-by-side semicircular concrete rings, each with a flat iron track on top. In the middle of each ring is a square pad with a mounting pin in the center. A small sign on the mound in front of the rings reads "Keep Off Mounds." At the back of each ring is a broken piece from the end of a cannon.

Interpretive panel: 100 Pounder Parrott Rifles.

At the bottom of this panel is a photograph of four men on either side of a cannon. The gun in mounted on a base which raises the middle of the cannon to the height of the men's heads. The cannon points to the right over a low mound of vegetation-covered soil. THE caption reads,

"A gun crew at Fort Putnam fires a 100-pounder. This type of gun was designed by Robert P. Parrott and first produced in 1861."

Text at the top of the panel reads,

"Displayed here are pieces of two 100-pounder Parrott rifles that were mounted on these granite platforms in the 1870s. The barrel had spiral grooves, called rifling, that caused the projectile to spin. This made the Parrotts much more accurate and destructive than earlier smoothbore cannon that fired round shot. The Parrots were cast iron muzzle-loaders like the smoothbores and could penetrate masonry forts. In the 1890s and early 1900s steel, breech-loading rifles replaced the Parrotts, and concrete-and-earthwork batteries replaced masonry fortifications like Fort Massachusetts."

End of Description.

title: Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 6
listingDescription:
Cannon Debris



Although designed for 37 cannon, only 17 were mounted during the 1870s. In the early 1900s, many were sold for scarp. Due to their weight, most were broken apart before removal. The debris here, were never removed from the fort.
bodyText:
Cannon Debris

Fort Massachusettes was designed for 37 cannon, but only 17 were mounted during the 1870s. In the early 1900s, many were sold for scrap. Due to their weight, most were broken apart before removal. The debris here, was never removed from the fort. Scattered on top of the pad and on the grass around the pad are large broken pieces of a cannon. 

Feel free to touch these pieces, but please do not sit on anything.
audioDescription:
231 words
This tour stop is on top of the southeast corner of the fort where one of the half bastions extend out on either side of the main entrance. Retaining walls on all sides support mounded soil covered with vegetation. In the middle of this 15-foot-wide roughly circular area is a concrete pad with four iron circular rails on top. Scattered on top of the pad and on the grass around the pad are large broken pieces of a cannon. Feel free to explore these pieces.

Interpretive panel: Pieces of the Past.

The background of the panel has a photograph of a 15-inch Rodman cannon on a metal carriage sitting on a concrete pad like the one here. Wheels on the bottom of the carriage sit on the circular metal railings on the pad, allowing the cannon to rotate to point in different directions. Text at the top of the panel reads,

"These cannon fragments, which come from a 15-inch Rodman smoothbore barrel like the one pictured, reflect technological changes in coastal defense artillery in the late 1800s. This fort was designed for 37 cannon, but only 17-including two 15-inch Rodmans-were mounted. Rifled cannon made the fort's smoothbore guns obsolete, and except for one Rodman they were sold for scrap iron in 1901. Explosives were used to break up the cannon to make them easier to remove."

End of Description.

title: Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 7
listingDescription:
Stair Tower



Three spiral granite staircases were built to use less space and provide protection against enemy fire.

images.altText: A large brick tower stands in the middle of a flooded fort.
images.title: Fort Massachusetts Stair Tower
images.caption: Fort Massachusetts Stair Tower

bodyText:
Stair Tower

The round stair tower sits at the end of a brick walk directly across from the entrance to the fort. An arched doorway leads into the tower where a concrete staircase begins at the right and circles counterclockwise up to the top. The three spiral granite staircases were built to provide protection against enemy fire.
audioDescription:
118 words.

The round stair tower sits at the end of a brick walk directly across from the entrance to the fort. Brick walks circle around either side leading to the arched casemates behind the tower along the outer wall of the fort. An arched doorway leads into the tower where a concrete staircase begins at the right and circles counterclockwise up to the top. There is no handrail.

At the top of the circular staircase a set of five steps leads up to the grassy top of the fort walls. There is a metal railing on both sides of this set of steps and around the top of the stair tower itself.

End of Description.

title: Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 8
listingDescription:
Hot Shot Furnace



This coal-fired furnace was meant to heat cannon balls intended to set wooden ships on fire. Although common to coastal forts, this furnace was never used.

images.altText: A red brick furnace stands near archways in a fort.
images.title: Fort Massachusetts Hot Shot Furnace
images.caption: Fort Massachusetts Hot Shot Furnace

bodyText:
Hot Shot Furnace



This coal-fired furnace was built to heat cannon balls before firing them at ships. This furnace was never used.

This brick structure sitting in the middle of the fort is about 9 feet square with a large square chimney at the end facing the middle of the parade. Below the chimney is wide opening that tunnels all the way through the structure to a similar opening at the far end. Three iron pipes extend the length of the tunnel, forming a horizontal rack. On the wall are five star-like iron braces held in place by rods that pass through the structure to support the side walls. At lower left on this wall are two smaller openings giving access to the firebox.

Imagine what it was like for soldiers in the blazing sun to heat solid cannonballs in a furnace like this one.

One soldier maintained the coal fire and put up to 60 cannonballs on racks in the furnace. A second removed the heated balls with tongs. A third cleaned them with a rasp, and others carried them in ladles to the guns. 

This furnace was ordered as a kit and installed. Although common to coastal forts, this furnace was never used.
audioDescription:
276 words
This brick structure sits in the south corner of the open space or parade ground in the middle of the fort. It is about nine feet square with a large square chimney at the end facing the middle of the parade. Below the chimney is wide opening that tunnels all the way through the structure to a similar opening at the far end. Three iron pipes extend the length of the tunnel, forming a horizontal rack. In front of the opening there are two stone steps. Feel free to mount the steps and feel the iron rack.

From the front move around to the left side. On the wall are five star-like iron braces held in place by rods that pass through the structure to support the side walls. At lower left on this wall are two smaller openings giving access to the firebox.

Hot Shot Furnace.

A small sign mounted at the back right corner of the brick furnace structure reads,

"Hot Shot Furnace. Imagine what it was like for soldiers in the blazing sun to heat solid cannonballs in a furnace like this one, so gun crews could fire red-hot projectiles at wooden warships to set them ablaze. One soldier maintained the coal fire and put up to 60 cannonballs on racks in the furnace. A second removed the heated balls with tongs. A third cleaned them with a rasp, and others carried them in ladles to the guns. This furnace was ordered as a kit and installed. It was not the right size and was never used. The advent of ironclad ships in the Civil War rendered the furnaces obsolete."

End of Description.

title: Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 9
listingDescription:
Guardrooms



One on either side of the sally port, these rooms could house soldiers, but most lived outside the fort. The narrow opening in the wall permitted the soldiers to fire on enemy forces with rifles.

images.altText: Wooden benches stand in front of a wooden door and two windows in a red brick fort.
images.title: Fort Massachusetts Guardrooms
images.caption: Fort Massachusetts Guardrooms

bodyText:
Guardrooms



One on either side of the sally port, are rooms created to house soldiers. However, most of the soldiers lived outside the fort.

A narrow opening in the walls allowed the soldiers to fire on enemy forces with rifles. In the rear left corner there is a rack holding long cannon tools with a cannon ball and a smaller shot on the floor at the right.

Feel free to touch this display.
audioDescription:
628 words
This room is located next to the entrance passage or Sally Port. A narrow arched door leads into the room which has a wooden floor and brick walls. On either side of the door is a narrow arched window with wooden shutters on the inside. On the outer wall are three windows. The sides of the windows are slanted inward so that there is only a narrow slot open to the outside. These windows also have wooden shutters on the inside.

Down the right hand wall there are three large graphic panels mounted in free-standing wooden frames titled "Fight for Ship Island," "Ship Island Prisoners," and "Blacks Join Union Army." On the left wall there are two panels titled "Raising a Fort" and "Like a Small City." In the rear left corner there is a rack holding long cannon tools with a cannon ball and a smaller shot on the floor at the right. Feel free to touch this display.

In the middle of the room a small wood fence with vertical rails encloses a circular opening in the floor which is covered by a wooden grill. A graphic panel in front of the railing is titled "Collecting Rainwater."

Interpretive panel: Raising a Fort.

Text at the top of this panel reads,

"Delayed by hurricanes, a lack of funds, and the Civil War, Fort Massachusetts did not rise up out of the sands overnight. The U.S. Army started construction in March 1859 and finished the fort in October 1866. First a small crew built temporary quarters, office, storehouse, wharf, and a plank road to the building site. Then, amid summer's staggering heat and a series of fierce storms, workers dug deep in the sand to build the fort's concrete foundations. Masons laid the brick walls and arched casemates.

"Naming the Fort. The fort was called "The Fort on Ship Island" in military records. It was named "Fort Massachusetts" after the Union gunboat."

Across the middle of the panel is an 1862 "harper's Weekly" illustration shows six ships sailing past the west end of Ship Island. The ships have empty masts and tall smoke stacks with black smoke. On the island behind them the tall lighthouse is visible near the middle of the island. At the right, a flag flies over the fort, although the caption tells us the walls were not visible due to delays in construction.

At the left side under the illustration are portraits of two men, both in uniform. The man on the left has white hair. The other has dark hair. The caption below reads,

"Gen. Joseph G. Totten (left), chief of Army Engineers, argued that Fort Massachusetts had to be built to defend New Orleans and to serve as a Gulf Coast military supply depot. Between 1859 and 1862 four officers served as engineers in charge. Construction resumed earnestly under the fifth, Lt. John C. Palfrey (right). He focused first on building barracks, huts, storage sheds, and a new wharf, and then on finishing the fort."

To the right of the pictures is a plan view of the fort, showing its "D" shape with the closed rooms along the straight side.

At the bottom of the panel is a brown-toned photograph with a bird's eye view of the fort. The curve wall has soil mounded on top protecting the semicircular cannon emplacements behind. More soil cover the straight band across the front with the large cannon clearly visible in the lower left corner. A caption reads,

"The fort's D-shape design is unique among the Third System coastal fortifications built between 1816 and 1867."

To the left a quote from Alfred Parmenter, a musician in the 26th Massachusetts, reads,

"What a hell of a place to send 2,000 men 3,000 miles."

End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens
listingDescription: In 1821, the Third System of coastal forts was extended to include protecting Pensacola Bay and the communities that lined the mainland shore. Pensacola Bay had long been considered important by European powers that sought to colonize North America. With depths ranging between twenty and sixty-five feet and twelve-and-a-half miles long, the bay could afford excellent anchorage and protection for ships. Through the Adams-OnÃ­s Treaty of 1819 Spain ceded East and West Florida t

images.altText: Aerial image of Fort Pickens
images.title: Fort Pickens
images.caption: Fort Pickens

bodyText:
The United States Army built Fort Pickens in the 1800’s to help defend the Gulf Coast from overseas enemies. In 1821, the Third System of coastal forts was extended to include protecting Pensacola Bay and the communities that lined the mainland shore. Pensacola Bay had long been considered important by European powers that sought to colonize North America.

By 1825, legislation was passed to establish a navy yard and depot on the bay. Fortifications were needed to protect the new territory, its resources, and assets.

From Santa Rosa Island, the fort worked with Fort McRee on Perdido Key to guard the entrance to Pensacola Bay. Fort Barrancas and the Spanish Water Battery, staring down from a bluff facing the harbor’s entrance, added more protection. Fort Barrancas and Advanced Redoubt guarded the Pensacola Navy Yard from land attacks.

What many people don't know is that Fort Pickens was built on a bed of violence and cruelty. The Army forced enslaved Black men to build and later repair the fort. This didn't stop Fort Pickens from becoming a destination on the Underground Railroad during the Civil War and after. Freedom-seeking African Americans traveled to the fort to emancipate themselves.

Following the Civil War and after the Apache Wars ended in the 1880’s, the Army concentrated Chiricahua Apache at Fort Pickens. Prisoners of war like Geronimo, a leader and medicine man, labored at the fort for one and a half years. The Chiricahua Apache remained prisoners of war for another 27 years.

However, new technologies made Fort Pickens outdated. The Army continued using the fort until the end of World War II. In the 1890s, the fort supported an underwater minefield. Soldiers kept supplies for Battery Pensacola inside the fort's brick rooms. In the early 1900's, the Army set up a power plant in the fort to create electricity for the base.

Fort Pickens joined the National Park Service's Gulf Islands National Seashore in 1971. Today the fort stands as a monument to military technology and as a memorial to past injustices.
audioDescription: Fort Pickens. A wide sidewalk leads from the corner of the parking lot to a rounded arch entrance in the side of the weathered brick fort. A sign to the left of the walk indicates that the bookstore is located straight ahead and the restrooms are to the left in a small brick building next to the fort walls. Near the entrance a sidewalk curves around to the left towards building. Left of the entrance the fort's walls rise tall. Small openings covered by iron bars are spaced along the walls. To the right of the entrance a section of the fort's walls is missing giving a glimpse of the arched gallery along the inside of the far wall. A wooden rail fence runs along the missing wall section. End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Area
listingDescription: The Fort Pickens Area is located on the western end of Santa Rosa Island and preserves over a century of American coastal defensive structures. The area features many beach access points to visit the incredible white-sand beaches and enjoy the blue-green waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Take a hike on one of the many trails through, including the Florida National Scenic Trail. In the historic district; explore the historic fortifications with a ranger or with one of the self-g

images.altText: Brown sign with white text that reads, "Fort Pickens Area, Gulf Islands National Seashore." A brown and green National Park Service Arrowhead sign is to the right of the text. White sand and green plants in the foreground and background.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Signature Sign

bodyText:
The Fort Pickens Area is located on the western end of Santa Rosa Island and preserves over a century of American coastal defensive structures.

The area features many beach access points to visit the incredible white-sandy beaches and enjoy the blue-green waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Take a hike on one of the many trails, including the Florida National Scenic Trail.

In the historic district, explore the historic fortifications with a ranger or with one of the self-guiding tours. The Fort Pickens Discovery Center offers fun, interactive exhibits for all ages about the history of the site as well as its natural wonders. A bookstore open year round at historic Fort Pickens.
audioDescription: Fort Pickens area entrance sign. 179 words. The sign at the entrance to the Fort Pickens Area sits at the right side of the road just past the entrance station. It is made of two horizontal sections attached to five wooden posts. Lettering reads, "Fort Pickens Area, Gulf Islands National Seashore, National Park Service, Department of the Interior." The right side of the sign has a section of vertical boards with the National Park Service arrowhead logo attached. The ground on the right side of the road here is flat, covered with grasses and sea oats, and with a view of the waters of Pensacola Bay. On the other side of the road, the land rises in a series of low sand dunes with patches of vegetation. The dunes block the view of the gulf on that side. A pullout is on the side of the road in front of the sign. Behind a row of metal posts are two freestanding kiosks holding six graphic panels with a variety of information about the seashore and the Fort Pickens Area. End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Area Entrance Station
listingDescription: Entrance fees are charged for most of the Florida areas of the national seashore. Passes are good for seven days and can be purchased at the park entrance stations or online. For more frequent visitors, the national seashore offers an annual pass providing 12-months of unlimited entries into all of the park's areas.The Federal Lands Recreation Enhancement Act (FLREA) allows the park service to collect and retain revenue and requires that fee revenue be used to enhance the

images.altText: A car enters an entrance station gate at sunset.
images.title: Fort Pickens Area Entrance Station
images.caption: Fort Pickens Area Entrance Station

bodyText:
The Fort Pickens Area is located on the western end of Santa Rosa Island and preserves over a century of American coastal defensive structures.

The area features many beach access points to visit the incredible white-sandy beaches and enjoy the blue-green waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Take a hike on one of the many trails, including the Florida National Scenic Trail.

In the historic district, explore the historic fortifications with a ranger or with one of the self-guiding tours. The Fort Pickens Discovery Center offers fun, interactive exhibits for all ages about the history of the site as well as its natural wonders. A bookstore open year round at historic Fort Pickens.

Entrance fees are charged for most of the Florida areas of the national seashore. Passes are good for seven days and can be purchased at the park entrance stations or online. For more frequent visitors, the national seashore offers an annual pass providing 12-months of unlimited entries into all of the park's areas.

Know before you go:
- Dogs are not allowed on the beach or in the fort
- Obey speed limit signs, 25 miles per hour or less
- Do not enter marked off areas on dunes

title: Fort Pickens Area Orientation Kiosk
listingDescription: The Fort Pickens Area Orientation Kiosk is located along Fort Pickens Road just inside the park, but before the entrance station. Here visitors can learn about the national seashore, the Fort Pickens Area, beach safety, and the park's interpretive themes. There are several parallel parking spots at this kiosk which is also located at the area's signature entrance sign - the perfect spot for a family vacation photo.

images.altText: National Park Service signs under small, kiosk structures. Fort Pickens entrance sign in the background.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Area Orientation Kiosk Site

bodyText:
Stop here for a great photo opp with the Fort Pickens Area Entrance Sign or to learn more about the seashore from the kiosk. 

The Fort Pickens Area Orientation Kiosk is located along Fort Pickens Road just inside the park, but before the entrance station. There are several parallel parking spots at this kiosk.
audioDescription: Six panels:Fort Pickens Area. 302 words. Beach Safety. 406 words.Sea...Sand...Salt Marshes...Woodlands. 159 words.Forts and Firepower. 153 words.Location and Legacy. 251 words.Gulf Islands National Seashore. 417 words.Fort Pickens Area. 302 words. At the top of this panel is a photograph of the south wall of Fort Pickens. The view looks over a bank of yellow flowers in the foreground towards the Tower Bastion extending out from the wall with a large cannon sitting on top.At the bottom of the panel is a photograph of people fishing from the pier. It looks out over the turquoise waters to the square platform at the end of the pier where people lean against the railings, many with fishing rods in their hands.Text at the left side of the panel reads, "The national seashore's Fort Pickens Area offers an idyllic setting to reflect on the past and enjoy recreational activities. Tour the fort and learn about its role as a Union stronghold during the Civil War in the 1860s, then tour a series of fortifications that protected Pensacola Bay from the 1890s to the 1940s. Swim, beachcomb, walk trails, or try your luck fishing."To the right of the text is a small map showing the area around Pensacola Bay. Along the gulf west of the entrance into the bay is Perdido Key Area with Rosamond Johnson Beach at its western end. Fort Pickens sits on the western end of Santa Rosa Key where the boundary of the National Seashore stretches back east almost to the bridge leading to Gulf Breeze. Just east of Gulf Breeze is the Naval Live Oaks Area. Just below is a larger map showing the Fort Pickens Area with more details. Fort Pickens Road extends down the center of the island then makes a loop around the island's end just west of Fort Pickens. Locations of the many batteries, campgrounds, parking areas, and other facilities are marked.A label reads, "For camping information call 850-934-2600."Beach Safety. 406 words.This panel is 2 feet wide and three feet tall and has text in both English and Spanish. Text at the top reads, "In just a few minutes a wonderful day at the beach can turn into a disaster. Stay alert for sudden storms and marine life that could sting or bite. Watch your children. In emergencies, dial 911."At the bottom is a photograph with labels showing the smooth water of a rip current as it flows away from shore between two sandbars covered by white frothy waves. On the far side arrows point sideways in both directions with a label reading "Swim to the side." Text below the picture reads, "Rip Currents Kill. Rip currents commonly form after storms. If you are caught in a rip current, stay calm. Do not try to swim against the current. Swim right or left to escape the flow."Down the left side of the panel are specific warnings, each with a small photograph as illustration. Text reads, "Avoid overexposure to the sun, especially between 10 am and 2 pm. Use sunscreen, sunglasses, hats, and long sleeves to protect skin. Drink plenty of water to help prevent dehydration." (Picture of the sun.)"Thunderstorms develop quickly. If swimming or fishing, get out of the water immediately and seek shelter." (Picture of lightning.)"Jellyfish and sea nettles can inflict painful stings. To reduce pain apply vinegar and do not touch." (Picture of a jellyfish.)"Sharks are present in park waters. Do not swim at dawn, dusk, or night. Avoid schools of fish." (Picture of a shark.)"Be aware of stingrays. Shuffle your feet while wading. Avoid grass beds and murky water. Soak puncture wounds in hot water." (Picture of a stingray.)Down the right side of the panel are images of the various flags that may be posted on the beach along with their meanings. At top are two red flags, one with the silhouette of a swimmer with a line drawn through it. The label reads, "Two Flags Mean Water Closed to Public Highly dangerous surf and/or strong currents."Next is a single red flag which means "High Hazard. High surf and/or strong currents."Next is a yellow flag which means "Medium Hazard. Moderate surf and/or currents."Next is a green flag which means "Low Hazard. Calm conditions, exercise caution.At bottom is a purple flag which means "Dangerous Marine Life. Stinging organisms or sharks."Sea...Sand...Salt Marshes...Woodlands. 159 words.Text at the top of this panel reads, "Explore the extensive beaches, salt marshes, and woodlands of the ever-changing northern Gulf Coast. Discover how the waves and wind shape and reshape offshore islands that shield the mainland in fierce storms. Visit salt marshes that serve as nurseries for crabs, fish, and other marine life. Walk trails that meander through coastal forests-habitats for a variety of plants and animals. The National Park Service protects these special places for you and future generations to enjoy."The top half of the panel has a photograph of a dead tree branch, half buried in the sand at the edge of the beach. The branch cast long shadows to the right and the sand is tinged a rosy pink.The bottom half of t

title: Fort Pickens Bay Trail
listingDescription: Walk down to the bay and observe birds and other wildlife on this 0.15 mile sand trail.

images.altText: A bald eagle sits on a sand dune.
images.title: Bald Eagle on Dune
images.caption: Bald Eagle on Dune

bodyText:
The Bay Trail is a 0.15 mile trail beginning at the north side of Fort Pickens Campground Loop E. Visitors may park at overflow parking located directly in front of the trailhead, or walk from their campsite. The Florida National Scenic Trail can be found a few feet to the right.

A gently inclined, sandy slope will bring visitors up over the dunes, past coastal vegetation, and down to the Pensacola Bay. A variety of birds can frequently be seen flying overhead, including bald eagles, ospreys, great blue herons, and more.

Duration: 15-30 minutes
audioDescription: A wide, sandy path gently inclines, beckoning visitors to hike down to the bay. Behind you lies campground Loop E, and to your right lies the Florida National Scenic Trail.

title: Fort Pickens Campground: Loop A
listingDescription: Loop A (43 total sites) of the Fort Pickens Campground is the most popular at the national seashore. Live oaks and other trees provide excellent shade over nearly all sites. The loop is located east of the main campground loops. There is a beach access point directly across the street from the entrance to the campground loop. To the north of the loop is the Blackbird Marsh Trail, a nature trail with interpretive panels. The trail connects to the Florida Trail providing acces

images.altText: Metal sign with the text, "Happy Camper." Picnic tables and RV trucks in the background.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Campground

bodyText:
Loop A Fort Pickens Campground is the most popular at the national seashore with 43 total sites to choose from. Live oaks and other trees provide excellent shade over nearly all sites and there is a beach access point directly across the street from the entrance to the campground loop.

The loop is located east of the main campground loops. To the north of the loop is the Blackbird Marsh Trail, a nature trail with interpretive panels. The trail connects to the Florida Trail providing access to the rest of the Fort Pickens Area.

Know Before You Go!
audioDescription: Loop A Fort Pickens Campground is the most popular at the national seashore with 43 total sites to choose from. Live oaks and other trees provide excellent shade over nearly all sites and there is a beach access point directly across the street from the entrance to the campground loop. The loop is located east of the main campground loops. To the north of the loop is the Blackbird Marsh Trail, a nature trail with interpretive panels. The trail connects to the Florida Trail providing access to the rest of the Fort Pickens Area.

title: Fort Pickens Campground: Loop A Dump Station
listingDescription: Campground dump stations are for the use of registered campers only.

images.altText: A white metal sign with black text that reads, "Dump Station." Below the text is an arrow pointing to the left. Mobile campers and trees in the background.
images.caption: "Dump Station" Sign

bodyText: Fort Pickens Campground RV dump stations are for the use of registered campers only. Non-campers must pay a $5 fee at the campground office to use the dump stations.
audioDescription: Fort Pickens Campground RV dump stations are for the use of registered campers only. Non-campers must pay a $5 fee at the campground office to use the dump stations.

title: Fort Pickens Campground: Loop A Dumpster
listingDescription: There are two dumpsters at this location; one is for normal waste, the other is for recycling.

images.altText: Grey metal bin next to a green metal bin. Both are standing on a cement pad with a wooden fence surrounding them. Green trees in the background.
images.caption: Campground A Dumpsters

bodyText: There are two dumpsters at this location; one is for normal waste, the other is for recycling.
audioDescription: There are two dumpsters at this location; one is for normal waste, the other is for recycling.

title: Fort Pickens Campground: Loop A Restrooms
listingDescription:
This facility features men's and women's restrooms and showers.

Coin-operated laundry machines are available at the Loop C Restroom building.

Facilities for registered campers only.

images.altText: A grey stone building with four brown metal doors. Next to each door are brown metal shower and restroom signs. The second door from the left has a handicap sign.
images.caption: Campground A Restrooms and Showers

bodyText:
This facility features men's and women's restrooms and showers. Coin-operated laundry machines are available at the Loop C Restroom building.

Facilities for registered campers only.
audioDescription: This facility features men's and women's restrooms and showers. Coin-operated laundry machines are available at the Loop C Restroom building. Facilities for registered campers only.

title: Fort Pickens Campground: Loop B
listingDescription: Loop B (13 sites total) is reserved for soft-sided, on the ground tents only. Each campsite has a grill/fire ring and picnic table. There are no site hook-ups, but there are centralized water stations. Generators are not permitted in this loop. There is a beach access point directly across the street from the entrance to the campground loop. The Florida Trail runs through the loop providing access to the rest of the Fort Pickens Area including the historic district.Know Befo

images.altText: Two tents sit under trees in the background with camping gear on a picnic table in the foreground.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Campground Loop B

bodyText:
Loop B is reserved for soft-sided, on the ground tents only. With 13 sites total, each campsite has a grill/fire ring and picnic table. There are no site hook-ups, but there are centralized water stations. Generators are not permitted in this loop.

There is a beach access point directly across the street from the entrance to the campground loop. The Florida Trail runs through the loop providing access to the rest of the Fort Pickens Area including the historic district.

Know Before You Go!
audioDescription: Loop B is reserved for soft-sided, on the ground tents only. With 13 sites total, each campsite has a grill/fire ring and picnic table. There are no site hook-ups, but there are centralized water stations. Generators are not permitted in this loop. There is a beach access point directly across the street from the entrance to the campground loop. The Florida Trail runs through the loop providing access to the rest of the Fort Pickens Area including the historic district.

title: Fort Pickens Campground: Loop C
listingDescription: Loop C (60 total sites) of the Fort Pickens Campground is one of the larger loops at the national seashore. There are limited sites with shade, tree replanting efforts are underway. The loop is located on the eastern end of the campground. There is a beach access point directly across the street from the entrance of the campground loop.
