title: Fort Pickens Dune Trail
listingDescription: Traverse through protected, sandy dunescape on a boardwalk trail leading to the emerald waters of the Gulf of Mexico.

images.altText: A boardwalk leads into a sandy dunescape.
images.title: Dune Nature Trail
images.caption: Dune Nature Trail

bodyText:
The Dune Trail is a 0.15 mile boardwalk trail through primary and secondary dunescape. It is located in the Fort Pickens area, directly south of campground Loop A. Visitors may walk or bike to the trailhead, or park in the lot directly in front. Please stay on the trail and do not walk in the dunes, to preserve our coastal vegetation.

The boardwalk traverses through foredune communities, which are home to many different animal and plant species. Foredunes are created by sand blowing inland from the beach, forming a line that runs adjacent to the coast. Foredunes help shelter plant life from exposure to and create pockets where less salt-tolerant floral communities can form. 

A rest bench is provided along the trail, but no shade will be found on sunny days, so bring water and pack accordingly.

Duration: 15-30 minutes
audioDescription: The Dune Trail hosts many different animal and plant species. This boardwalk trail located in the Fort Pickens Area is 1600 feet long and tours through foredune communities. Foredunes are created by sand blowing inland from the beach, forming a line that runs adjacent to the coast. Foredunes help shelter plant life from exposure to and create pockets where less salt-tolerant floral communities can form. Please do not walk in the dunes, and stay on the trail. End of description.

title: Fort Pickens Fishing Pier
listingDescription: You do not need a license if you are fishing for recreational purposes from a pier that has a valid saltwater pier fishing license. The Fort Pickens Area Fishing Pier is a licensed pier. Fishing Pier Rules Limit two poles or one pole, one cast net per person. Prohibited Fishing by bow, spear gun or Hawaiian slings. Alcohol, pets, glass, generators, texts, canopies, or any other shelter. All Florida state laws apply. Safety The sun can be intense, wear sunblock. Be mindfu

images.altText: Wooden pier full of people fishing stretches over blue water. A Great Blue Heron walks on white sand in the foreground. Blue sky in the background.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Fishing Pier

bodyText:
Known as the most popular place to fish in the Fort Pickens area. The fishing pier stretches out 200 feet into Pensacola Bay. It is a great place to catch fish, view dolphins, or watch the sunset.

The Fort Pickens Area Fishing Pier is a licensed pier. You do not need a license if you are fishing for recreational purposes from a pier that has a valid saltwater pier fishing license. Please abide by Florida state fishing regulations and practice leave no trace.

Fishing Pier Rules:
- Limit two poles or one pole, one cast net per person.

Prohibited:
-  Fishing by bow, spear gun or Hawaiian slings.
- Alcohol, pets, glass, generators, texts, canopies, or any other shelter.
audioDescription: Fort Pickens fishing pier. 220 words. The fishing pier stretches out 200 feet into Pensacola Bay from the shore. The pier may be reached through an opening in the four-foot wide concrete wall that extends around the end of the island from Fort Pickens to the west. From the entrance platform a ramp leads to the right down to the beach. To the left a boardwalk with a board railing parallels the beach for about 200 feet to reach the end of the pier. Here at the entrance platform is a panel titled "Fishing Pier Rules."Along the boardwalk to the left are two more graphic panels titled "Anglers. What should you do?" and "What Did I Catch?" Along the left side of the boardwalk are a couple of places with benches. Sets of steps lead down to the beach near the graphic panels and also at the end of the pier itself. The pier is 20 feet wide. At the end is a 35-foot square platform. Seabirds, such as gulls and pelicans, are common around the pier. You may hear them calling or the splash of water as they dive for fish. Out in the water to the right of the pier is an open rectangular structure on pylons which is a common perch for many of the birds.End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Group Campsite
listingDescription: The Fort Pickens Group Campsite is located on Santa Rosa Island west of Pensacola Beach. Throughout the year, this area can be reserved for groups with a minimum of ten and maximum of forty people. Tents only.

images.title: Fort Pickens Group Camping

Throughout the year the Fort Pickens group campsite area is reservable for groups with a minimum of ten and maximum of forty people. Only tents are allowed at this location.

The Fort Pickens group campsite is located within the Fort Pickens Area, west of Pensacola Beach.

title: Fort Pickens Jetties
listingDescription: Located near the western tip of Santa Rosa Island, this area is one of the most popular scuba and snorkeling spots at the national seashore. Currents and tides can be intense in this area, please use extreme caution when wading, swimming, or diving. No lifeguard on duty. Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Camping and overnight parking is not permitted. Pets, glass, and driving are not permitted on beach. Marine Debris Kills Many animals includin

images.altText: Wooden walkway and railings leading down to a white sand beach and blue water. Blue sky in the background.
images.caption: Walkway at Fort Pickens Jetties

bodyText:
Known as one of the most popular scuba and snorkeling spots at the national seashore. Located near the western tip of the Fort Pickens Area on the sound side, it is a great place to snorkel, scuba or lauch a kayak. It also provides a great view of the Pensacola Lighthouse and dolphins.

This is a protected wildlife area. Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Pets, glass, and driving are not permitted on beach.
audioDescription: Fort Pickens Jetties. 145 words. There is a beach access point here at the northwest corner of the sea wall that encircles the Fort Pickens area. The concrete sea wall here is four feet high and four feet wide. From the road a set of six steps leads up to the top of the wall. On the other side a wooden ramp leads down to the sandy shoreline along Pensacola Bay. On the beach directly in front of the ramp is a jumble of black stones extending out into the water. The beach extends in both directions. The tall Pensacola lighthouse is visible directly across the bay from here. End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Park Store
listingDescription: Purchase park merchandise and obtain passport stamps at this bookstore located directly inside Fort Pickens.

images.altText: An array of t-shirts and books is available for purchase at the Gulf Islands park store.
images.title: Fort Pickens Bookstore
images.caption: Fort Pickens Bookstore

bodyText:
The Gulf Islands National Seashore park store is found on the right side of the sally port, or large entrance archway, of Fort Pickens. It is operated by Eastern National, an official non-profit partner of the National Park Service dedicated to supporting our educational mission. 

The park store has a wide range of books, clothing, replica historical items, educational games, posters, and other items available for retail sale. No food is sold, and only bottled water is available. These products complement the interpretive themes you experience when visiting the park. Over the years, funds from bookstore sales have funded special events, signage for trails and exhibits, publications, interpretive programs, research grants, internships, the purchase of historical artifacts, park programs for kids, reenactments, interpretive exhibits, and much more.

The park store is located in Fort Pickens, Florida, or you can purchase Gulf Islands products from the online park store at Americas National Parks.
audioDescription: The Fort Pickens park store is located on the right inside the main entrance to the fort. It is filled with a variety of items for purchase including t-shirts, mugs, books, replica historical items, park passports, and bottled water.

title: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 1
listingDescription:
Sally Port



Secured with heavy doors, this is the main entrance to the fort. Tracks were later installed to move ammunition and heavy equipment to Battery Pensacola.

images.altText: Brick archway in the side of the brick Fort Pickens scarp wall. A man in a dark blue uniform stands to the left of the archway.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Sally Port

bodyText:
Sally Port


You are standing inside a covered walkway called a sally port. A sally port served as the main path into and out of a fort like Fort Pickens.To enter Fort Pickens in the early 1800s, soldiers marched across a wooden bridge.

The bridge stretched 180 feet over a dry ditch. When they reached the sally port, soldiers found several sets of heavy wooden doors. Now missing, these wooden doors allowed soldiers to control access to the fort.

The Army changed the sally port in the late 1800s. In 1896, work crews began laying railroad tracks on Santa Rosa Island. Workers used the railroad to move building materials. Soldiers used the railroad to move weapons, ammunition, and supplies around the post.

To help build Battery Pensacola, the Army ran railroad tracks from a dock on Pensacola Bay. The tracks passed through the sally port and ran to the middle of Fort Pickens. Deep, narrow grooves cut into the granite are one trace of the old railroad.

Turn left to begin your self guided tour.
audioDescription:
517 words
You are standing inside a covered walkway called a sally port. A sally port served as the main path into and out of a fort like Fort Pickens. To enter Fort Pickens in the early 1800s, soldiers marched across a wooden bridge. The bridge stretched 180 feet over a dry ditch. When they reached the sally port, soldiers found several sets of heavy wooden doors. Now missing, these wooden doors allowed soldiers to control access to the fort. The Army changed the sally port in the late 1800s. In 1896, work crews began laying railroad tracks on Santa Rosa Island. Workers used the railroad to move building materials. Soldiers used the railroad to move weapons, ammunition, and supplies around the post. To help build Battery Pensacola, the Army ran railroad tracks from a dock on Pensacola Bay. The tracks passed through the sally port and ran to the middle of Fort Pickens. Deep, narrow grooves cut into the granite are one trace of the old railroad.

End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 10
listingDescription:
Postern



Soldiers could use this opening as a doorway in peacetime. When battle loomed, soldiers could lay brick to create an embrasure for a cannon.

images.altText: A tunnel leads through a brick wall
images.caption: Fort Pickens Self-guided Tour Stop 10

bodyText:
Bastion A

You are entering a bastion through a side door called a postern. A bastion is a projection from the main wall of a fort. It allowed defenders to fire along a fort’s wall. Soldiers called this bastion Bastion A.

Like Bastion E, which you passed through earlier in this self-guided tour, Bastion A has casemates and embrasures for cannon. It also has a countermine with three tunnels and a powder magazine. The interior of this bastion looks much as it did in the 1800s.
audioDescription:
124 words.

You are entering a bastion through a side door called a postern. A bastion is a projection from the main wall of a fort. It allowed defenders to fire along a fort’s wall. Soldiers called this bastion Bastion A. Like Bastion E, which you passed through earlier in this self-guided tour, Bastion A has casemates and embrasures for cannon. It also has a countermine with three tunnels and a powder magazine. The interior of this bastion looks much as it did in the 1800s.

End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 11
listingDescription:
Battery Pensacola Tunnel



This tunnel allowed access to the south side of the fort. Although the reason is unknown today, it was sealed by 1923.

images.altText: A concrete tunnel is barely higher than an average person's height
images.caption: Fort Pickens Self-guided Tour Stop 11

bodyText:
Battery Pensacola Tunnel

The Army built Battery Pensacola between 1898–1899. Shortly after construction began, it decided to add a tunnel to the project.

This tunnel extended from the south side of the battery, where you are standing, to the north side. This tunnel allowed soldiers to use the casemates that once existed inside the fort’s south wall.

In the early 1920s, a work crew built a new power station to provide electricity to the battery. They placed the power station in a location that closed the north entrance to the tunnel.
audioDescription:
The Army built Battery Pensacola between 1898–1899. Shortly after construction began, it decided to add a tunnel to the project. This tunnel extended from the south side of the battery, where you are standing, to the north side. This tunnel allowed soldiers to use the casemates that once existed inside the fort’s south wall.In the early 1920s, a work crew built a new power station to provide electricity to the battery. They placed the power station in a location that closed the north entrance to the tunnel.

End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 12
listingDescription:
Cisterns



Cisterns were designed to collect rainwater from the upper level of the fort for drinking, a crucial need for the fort's soldiers.

images.altText: Two brick fort tunnels. A brown metal sign with the number, "12" hangs between the tunnels.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Self-guided Tour Stop 12

bodyText:
Cisterns

These are the remains of Bastion B’s two cisterns. These cisterns stored rainwater that fell on Fort Pickens. Soldiers used this water to drink, cook, and wash their uniforms.

Two more cisterns were once located in the fort’s northwest bastion, Bastion D. Together, these four cisterns stored 193,392 gallons of water. With this supply, 1,200 soldiers could survive in the fort for up to 161 days.

The Bastion B cisterns sustained damage between 1915–1916. The Bastion D cisterns were destroyed in an accidental explosion in 1899.

Help protect Fort Pickens. Please stay off the walls and do not pick up loose bricks
audioDescription:

With this supply, 1,200 soldiers could survive in the fort for up to 161 days. The Bastion B cisterns sustained damage between 1915–1916. The Bastion D cisterns were destroyed in an accidental explosion in 1899. Help protect Fort Pickens. Please stay off the walls and do not pick up loose bricks.

End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 13
listingDescription: Reverse ArchTo support the weight of the fort on a foundation of sand, engineers used arches. Just as the arches overhead distribute weight to the piers, the reverse arches of the foundation spread the weight of the entire structure to minimize settling. Look closely at the file marks made by enslaved men who hand cut the bricks for a proper fit. Notice that this arch is really a double arch-above and below the floor of this gun chamber. Since ancient times humans have used

images.altText: Three fort interior brick archways. A brown metal sign with the number, "13" hangs on one brick wall.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Self-guided Tour Stop 13

bodyText:
Reverse Arch

There is a whole substructure supporting Fort Pickens. Hidden underfoot is a web of wooden beams and reverse brick arches.

Enslaved Black laborers broke ground on Fort Pickens in 1829. They began by digging into the island. They then installed a heavy framework of wooden beams called grillage. Using lumber from local Pensacola mills, the laborers installed grillage to create a foundation.

Engineers used arches to support the weight of the fort on this grillage foundation. Overhead arches spread the weight to the piers. The reverse arches distributed the weight across the grillage structure to limit settling.
audioDescription:
There is a whole substructure supporting Fort Pickens. Hidden underfoot is a web of wooden beams and reverse brick arches. Enslaved Black laborers broke ground on Fort Pickens in 1829. They began by digging into the island. They then installed heavy framework of wooden beams called grillage. Using lumber from local Pensacola mills, the laborers installed grillage to create a foundation. Engineers used arches to support the weight of the fort on this grillage foundation. Overhead arches spread the weight to the piers. The reverse arches distributed the weight across the grillage structure to limit settling.

End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 14
listingDescription:
Tower Bastion



The walls south of Battery Pensacola were lowered by 1916 so that its guns could have open views of targets. Today, the exposed arches help us to understand how the fort was built.

images.altText: View of a series of exposed brick arches going vertically down the center of the image. The Gulf of Mexico and blue sky in the background.
images.caption: Exposed Fort Pickens Tower Bastion Walls

bodyText:
Tower Bastion

This is Tower Bastion. From the barbette above, soldiers fired cannon over the fort’s wall. Inside the casemates below, defenders fired cannon along the fort’s wall.

From the barbette you can see the Gulf of Mexico, Pensacola Pass, and Pensacola Bay. Here a 15-inch Rodman gun, capable of firing a 450-pound solid shot up to five miles away, stands guard over the Emerald Coast.

Looking south toward the Gulf of Mexico, you can see damaged walls with exposed arches. Engineers demolished these walls between 1915–1916. Upon completion, soldiers at Battery Pensacola had better views of targets. Today, the exposed arches help us understand how the fort was built.

Help protect Fort Pickens. Please stay off the walls and do not pick up loose bricks.
audioDescription:
652 words
This is Tower Bastion. From the barbette above, soldiers fired cannon over the fort’s wall. Inside the casemates below, defenders fired cannon along the fort’s wall. From the barbette you can see the Gulf of Mexico, Pensacola Pass, and Pensacola Bay. Here a 15-inch Rodman gun, capable of firing a 450-pound solid shot up to five miles away, stands guard over the Emerald Coast. Looking south toward the Gulf of Mexico, you can see damaged walls with exposed arches. Engineers demolished these walls between 1915–1916. Upon completion, soldiers at Battery Pensacola had better views of targets. Today, the exposed arches help us understand how the fort was built. Help protect Fort Pickens. Please stay off the walls and do not pick up loose bricks.

End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 15
listingDescription:
Battery Pensacola



This reinforced concrete battery was built to defend against new technologies. Steel-built, steam powered warships and more powerful and accurate cannon made Battery Pensacola essential until 1933, when it was declared surplus.

images.altText: Black battery building and blue sky in the background. Green grass in the foreground.
images.caption: Battery Pensacola

bodyText:
Battery Pensacola

Engineers designed and built an elaborate defense system on Pensacola Bay between 1895–1943. Completed in 1899, Battery Pensacola once played a major role in this system. Four amazing technologies made Battery Pensacola revolutionary.

A newer construction material, reinforced concrete made the structure stronger than Fort Pickens. The concrete was painted black to reduce glare from the intense Florida sun. Newly invented electrical distribution provided the electricity to make loading and firing the battery’s guns easier.

The newly invented telephone allowed soldiers to communicate information more quickly and over greater distances. Steel guns capable of withstanding the extreme forces allowed soldiers to hit targets with deadly precision.

Like Fort Pickens, Battery Pensacola became obsolete. The Army stopped using the battery in 1933 and removed its guns in 1934.Visit Battery Cooper and its 6-inch disappearing gun to see an example of an armed battery on Pensacola Bay.
audioDescription:
Engineers designed and built an elaborate defense system on Pensacola Bay between 1895–1943. Completed in 1899, Battery Pensacola once played a major role in this system. Four amazing technologies made Battery Pensacola revolutionary. A newer construction material, reinforced concrete made the structure stronger than Fort Pickens. The concrete was painted black to reduce glare from the intense Florida sun. Newly invented electrical distribution provided the electricity to make loading and firing the battery’s guns easier. The newly invented telephone allowed soldiers to communicate information more quickly and over greater distances. Steel guns capable of withstanding the extreme forces allowed soldiers to hit targets with deadly precision. Like Fort Pickens, Battery Pensacola became obsolete. The Army stopped using the battery in 1933 and removed its guns in 1934. Visit Battery Cooper and its 6-inch disappearing gun to see an example of an armed battery on Pensacola Bay.

End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 16
listingDescription: Bastion DThis damaged pier and arch is the result of an accidental explosion in 1899, which destroyed Bastion D and created the large opening. US soldiers hung the American flag over this bastion after watching state militia capture the navy yard in January 1861.On the night of June 20, 1899, a fire broke out near a gunpowder magazine on the fort's northwest side. A bucket brigade fought the flames, but the blaze grew in intensity, forced the soldiers away from the cistern, a

images.altText: Bricks missing from the side of Fort Pickens where the explosion happened.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Bastion D

bodyText:
Bastion D

This damaged pier and arch are the result of an accidental explosion in the late 1800s. The explosion destroyed Bastion D and created this large gap.

In the early morning hours of June 20, 1899, soldiers discovered a fire near the sally port. Here, casemates housed large wooden blocks for moving guns and artillery supplies. The officer in charge, Second Lieutenant Robert H. C. Kelton, 1st US Artillery, led his 60 men in fighting the fire. As the fire spread toward Bastion D, it moved closer to a powder magazine holding 8,000 pounds of explosives. Unable to control the fire, Kelton withdrew his men before the magazine exploded.

The explosion wounded Private Henry Hopgood and killed another, Private Earle F. Welles. Today Private Welles rests across the bay at Barrancas National Cemetery.

The fire's cause remains unknown to this day. Eleven soldiers, including Kelton, were recognized for their “. . . heroic and energetic efforts . . .”
audioDescription:
This damaged pier and arch are the result of an accidental explosion in the late 1800s. The explosion destroyed Bastion D and created this large gap. In the early morning hours of June 20, 1899, soldiers discovered a fire near the sally port. Here, casemates housed large wooden blocks for moving guns and artillery supplies. The officer in charge, Second Lieutenant Robert H. C. Kelton, 1st US Artillery, led his 60 men in fighting the fire. As the fire spread toward Bastion D, it moved closer to a powder magazine holding 8,000 pounds of explosives. Unable to control the fire, Kelton withdrew his men before the magazine exploded.

End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 2
listingDescription:
Quarters



This plaster-lined room is where officers lived. Furniture, such as a bed to sleep on and a desk to write letters, made a soldier's life away from his family easier.

images.altText: White, plaster lined walls with a small brick opening in the wall. A brown metal sign with the number, "2" hangs on the wall.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Quarters

bodyText:
Officer's Quarters


You are inside an officers’ living quarters. An officer used a room like this for sleeping, an office, and sometimes as headquarters. Fort Pickens once had six officers’ quarters in the north wall and seven in the south wall. Most officers’ quarters no longer exist. In 1861, the first year of the Civil War, some of these rooms served as a hospital for Union troops.

At this hospital surgeons and their assistants cared for the sick, wounded, and dying. Those who died in defense of the United States were laid to rest in a temporary cemetery outside the fort.

Later, around 1888, soldiers used rooms like these to house Chiricahua Apache prisoners of war, including Geronimo and his family.
audioDescription:
125 words.

You are inside an officers’ living quarters. An officer used a room like this for sleeping, an office, and sometimes as headquarters. Fort Pickens once had six officers’ quarters in the north wall and seven in the south wall. Most officers’ quarters no longer exist. In 1861, the first year of the Civil War, some of these rooms served as a hospital for Union troops. At this hospital surgeons and their assistants cared for the sick, wounded, and dying. Those who died in defense of the United States were laid to rest in a temporary cemetery outside the fort. Later, around 1888, soldiers used rooms like these to house Chiricahua Apache prisoners of war, including Geronimo and his family.

End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 3
listingDescription: CasematesThese arched rooms provided protected artillery positions and a foundation for the barbette. Traverse stones, the granite semicircles in the floor, allowed cannon to roll left and right. Slots under the embrasures (the windows) locked gun carriages into the wall, providing a pivot point. Vents over the embrasures allowed smoke to escape, while chimneys in the rear provided fresh air from above.Cover your ears and imagine the thundering noise and tremendous shock wave

images.altText: A black metal cannon points out a small window in the white, brick, fort wall. A long hallway of brick arches extends from the right of the cannon.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Casemates

bodyText:
Casemates

The arched rooms around you are casemates. Casemates protected soldiers and cannon. They also supported the upper level, or barbette, of Fort Pickens. Each casemate in the fort had one or two windows, or embrasures. Soldiers fired cannon through these embrasures.

This cannon is a 32-pounder. It sits on top of an oak carriage. The carriage is connected to the brick wall. Look under the embrasure and you will discover an opening. A metal plate, called a tongue, connects the carriage to a metal pin in the wall.

This system locked the cannon to the wall and helped soldiers point their weapon. Look down at the floor and you will find granite blocks, or traverse stones. With iron rails bolted on top, travers stones made rolling cannon from side to side easier. Today you can still see the remains of traverse stones and rails around the fort. Cannon like this 32-pounder made a lot of smoke.

Vents above embrasures allowed the smoke to escape. When a cannon fired, fresh air entered a casemate through a chimney or a diamond-shaped opening in the ceiling.

Help protect Fort Pickens. Do not climb on the cannon.
audioDescription:
579 words

Each casemate in the fort had one or two windows, or embrasures. Soldiers fired cannon through these embrasures. This cannon is a 32-pounder. It sits on top of an oak carriage. The carriage is connected to the brick wall. Look under the embrasure and you will discover an opening. A metal plate, called a tongue, connects the carriage to a metal pin in the wall. End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 4
listingDescription:
Mine Battery Room



In 1894, this area was converted for electric batteries that powered a minefield across the channel. The minefield was deployed during the Spanish-American War, and remained in use until 1926.

images.altText: White brick interior fort wall and arch. A brown metal sign with the number, "4" is posted on the wall.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Tour Stop 4: Mine Battery Room

bodyText:
Mine Casemate

This doorway leads into the first mine casemate at Fort Pickens. Completed in 1894, this room became one of several onshore buildings used by soldiers to operate an underwater minefield. Long ago, the Army considered underwater mines one of the main weapons needed to defend a harbor.

When engineers began updating Pensacola Bay’s defenses in the late 1800s, they made sure to include mines in their plans. A mine casemate was the heart of a controlled mine system.

This area held batteries that powered the mines. It also housed the controls for setting off the mines. From the mine casemate, electrical cables ran underground, entered the bay, and extended to the minefield.

When an officer gave the command, a soldier at the operating panel flipped a switch and detonated a mine. Because of high humidity, engineers built a new mine casemate outside the fort in 1907. This brick building still stands today. The Army eliminated Pensacola Bay’s mine defense system in 1926.
audioDescription:
116 words.

This doorway leads into the first mine casemate at Fort Pickens. Completed in 1894, this room became one of several onshore buildings used by soldiers to operate an underwater minefield. Long ago, the Army considered underwater mines one of the main weapons needed to defend a harbor. This brick building still stands today. The Army eliminated Pensacola Bay’s mine defense system in 1926.

End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 5
listingDescription:
Mine Chambers



This tunnel system has three chambers, each designed to hold 1,027 pounds of gunpowder. If the fort was breached, defenders could blow up the chambers as a last resort, collapsing the walls on the enemy.

images.altText: Two long, narrow, and brick tunnels extend back to a light at the end of each tunnel.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Mine Chambers

bodyText:
Countermine

Soldiers had many options to defend Fort Pickens. You are outside one of those options called a countermine. Fort Pickens has two countermines. The countermines are on the fort’s landward side and next to powder magazines. Both have three narrow chambers that extend into the wall.

During a battle, soldiers in the fort could move kegs of gun powder from a powder magazine to a chamber. Each chamber could hold 1,027 pounds of gun powder.

When an attacker charged the fort, the defenders would ignite the gun powder and explode a chamber. The explosion would wreck the fort but stop an attack.
audioDescription:
71 words.

The countermines are on the fort’s landward side and next to powder magazines. Both have three narrow chambers that extend into the wall.bDuring a battle, soldiers in the fort could move kegs of gun powder from a powder magazine to a chamber. Each chamber could hold 1,027 pounds of gun powder. When an attacker charged the fort, the defenders would ignite the gun powder and explode a chamber. The explosion would wreck the fort but stop an attack.

End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 6
listingDescription:
Powder Magazine



This is one of three rooms that stored the fort's gunpowder supply. Magazines were lined with wood to keep the powder dry. Anyone who entered a magazine had to remove their shoes or put socks over them to prevent sparks.

images.altText: Small room with brick walls. Two of the walls have a small opening showing more of the interior of the fort.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Powder Magazine

bodyText:
Powder Magazine

Engineers designed Fort Pickens to hold 205 cannon. To fire cannon, soldiers needed gun powder. This small doorway opens into the only remaining powder magazine.

Fort Pickens originally had three powder magazines. The magazines were lined with wood to help keep gun powder dry. Anyone who entered a magazine had to remove their shoes or put socks over them to prevent sparks.

This is because the soles of shoes were sometimes attached with nails. Fort Pickens’ three magazines could hold more than 272,000 pounds of powder. This large quantity allowed soldiers to defend the fort during a long siege.
audioDescription:
67 words.

Engineers designed Fort Pickens to hold 205 cannon. To fire cannon, soldiers needed gun powder. This small doorway opens into the only remaining powder magazine. Fort Pickens originally had three powder magazines. The magazines were lined with wood to help keep gun powder dry. Anyone who entered a magazine had to remove their shoes or put socks over them to prevent sparks. This is because the soles of shoes were sometimes attached with nails. Fort Pickens’ three magazines could hold more than 272,000 pounds of powder. This large quantity allowed soldiers to defend the fort during a long siege. Take a deep breath through your nose, you can still smell the gunpowder.

End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 7
listingDescription:
Shelf Supports



Still a mystery, these concrete shelf supports may have been for equipment for the minefield or Battery Pensacola.

images.altText: White interior brick fort walls with several small stone shelves built from the ground into the side of the wall . A brown metal sign with the number, "7" hangs on the wall.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Shelf Supports

bodyText:
Gallery and Shelf Supports

This covered walkway is a gallery. A gallery protected soldiers and supplies while moving around a fort in a battle. The Army added concrete stalls to the gallery in the late 1800s.

The original use remains unclear. Soldiers may have used these stalls as shelf supports to store equipment. They could have kept equipment here for the underwater minefield. Or they could have used the supports for a fort inside Fort Pickens named Battery Pensacola.
audioDescription:
81 words.

This covered walkway is a gallery. A gallery protected soldiers and supplies while moving around a fort in a battle. The Army added concrete stalls to the gallery in the late 1800s. Their original use remains unclear. Soldiers may have used these stalls as shelf supports to store equipment. They could have kept equipment here for the underwater minefield. Or they could have used the supports for a fort inside Fort Pickens named Battery Pensacola.

End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 8
listingDescription:
Central Power Station



These concrete pads supported generators, engines, a switchboard, and storage batteries installed in 1903. Coal-powered generators provided additional electricity for lighting.

images.altText: White brick interior walls and archways of Fort Pickens. A brown metal sign with the number, "8" posted on the wall.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Self-guided Tour Stop 08

bodyText:
Central Power Station

Engineers had a bright idea in 1903. They decided to install a central power station at Fort Pickens. You are standing in the power station. It provided outdoor and indoor lighting for the military post. The three casemates in front of you were originally meant for cannon.

In 1903, engineers turned these rooms into a central power station. Here they installed one 50-kilowatt Skinner-Willey generator. It also had one 8- and one 10-kilowatt General Electric generators. The station housed three engines, a switchboard, and three storage batteries. To power the generators, engineers built a boiler house outside the power station.

This building housed a 103-horsepower Babcock and Wilcox boiler, a feed pump, and heater. Coal was stored in a casemate near the sally port. By the 1920s, the Army no longer needed the central power station. The equipment was sold, and the boiler house demolished.

Help protect Fort Pickens. Please stay off the walls and do not pick up loose bricks.
audioDescription:
91 words.

Engineers had a bright idea in 1903. They decided to install a central power station at Fort Pickens. You are standing in the power station. It provided outdoor and indoor lighting for the military post. The three casemates in front of you were originally meant for cannon. In 1903, engineers turned these rooms into a central power station. Here they installed one 50-kilowatt Skinner-Willey generator. It also had one 8- and one 10-kilowatt General Electric generators. The station housed three engines, a switchboard, and three storage batteries. To power the generators, engineers built a boiler house outside the power station. By the 1920s, the Army no longer needed the central power station. The equipment was sold, and the boiler house demolished. Help protect Fort Pickens. End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 9
listingDescription:
Counterscarp, Dry Ditch, & Bastions



The outer wall (counterscarp), located opposite the main wall (scarp), shielded the ditch. Protrusions (bastions) on the fort's corners allowed cannon to fire along the scarp. Attackers who reached the ditch would be caught in a terrible crossfire. This portion of the ditch was filled in about 1915. Before that time, the embrasures were ten feet above the ground.

images.altText: Grassy field surrounded by brick fort walls. Blue sky and water in the background.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Counterscarp and Dry Ditch

bodyText:
Counterscarp, Scarp, and Dry Ditch

You are standing in front of an outer wall called a counterscarp. The counterscarp supports a man-made hill called a glacis.

Like a shield, the counterscarp protected Fort Pickens’ main wall, called the scarp.In the 1800s, the counterscarp and scarp measured about 40 feet tall. Wrapping around Fort Pickens, a dry ditch separated these towering walls.

Attackers who reached the dry ditch would be caught in a deadly crossfire. By the summer of 1915, Army engineers filled the dry ditch to better protect the area from hurricanes. They also spread compost and planted grass to hold and fix the sand and to reduce the glare from the sun.
audioDescription:
128 words.

You are standing in front of an outer wall called a counterscarp. The counterscarp supports a man-made hill called a glacis. Like a shield, the counterscarp protected Fort Pickens’ main wall, called the scarp. In the 1800s, the counterscarp and scarp measured about 40 feet tall. Wrapping around Fort Pickens, a dry ditch separated these towering walls. Attackers who reached the dry ditch would be caught in a deadly crossfire. By the summer of 1915, Army engineers filled the dry ditch to better protect the area from hurricanes. They also spread compost and planted grass to hold and fix the sand and to reduce the glare from the sun.

End of Description.

title: Fort Pickens Tram Service: Stop 1
listingDescription:
The Fort Pickens Tram Service provides free access to all visitors to the most popular places at the Fort Pickens Area including the historic fort, the campground, and Langdon Beach.

Stop 1 is located at the Pensacola Bay Cruises : Fort Pickens Departure Point. At this stop there are restrooms, a water filling station, shade shelter, and the Mine Storeroom where visitors can purchase tour boat tickets, food, and beverages.

images.altText: Metal sign with green and white text and the number, "1." Brick buildings in the background.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Tram Stop Sign

bodyText:
The Fort Pickens Tram Service provides free access to all visitors on Friday and Saturday to the most popular places in the Fort Pickens Area including the historic fort, the campground, and Langdon Beach.

Stop 1 is located at the Pensacola Bay City Ferry Fort Pickens Departure Point. At this stop there are restrooms, a water filling station, a shaded shelter, and the Mine Storeroom where visitors can purchase ferry boat tickets and beverages.

listingDescription:
The Fort Pickens Tram Service provides free access to all visitors to the most popular places at the Fort Pickens Area including the historic fort, the campground, and Langdon Beach.

Stop 1 is located at the Fort Pickens Campground . There is also a beach access point at this stop.

images.altText: Metal sign with green and white text and the number, "2." White wooden sided building in the background.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Tram Stop 2 Sign

The Fort Pickens Tram Service provides free access to all visitors on Friday and Saturday to the most popular places in the Fort Pickens Area including the historic fort, the campground, and Langdon Beach.

title: Fort Pickens Visitor Center
listingDescription: Explore indoor exhibits on the natural environment, wildlife, and history of the Fort Pickens Area .

images.altText: A white and green building stands with cannons in the foreground.
images.title: Fort Pickens Discovery Center
images.caption: Fort Pickens Discovery Center

bodyText: Discover the wonders of Santa Rosa Island inside the Fort Pickens Visitor Center. The miles of sandy quartz beaches provide beach, dune, and forest area habitats for many plants and animals. Historic forts and buildings tell the stories of United States coastal defense.
audioDescription: Fort Pickens Discovery Center. 168 words.From the front the Discovery Center is a one-story white frame building. A wide covered porch runs the entire 200-foot length of the building. The entrance is through a set of double doors in the middle of the building. The doors and the window trim are painted dark green. The entrance and the porch are several feet off the ground and may be reached by either a set of five steps or a zig-zag ramp. Another set of steps is near the left end. The porch's roof is support by square white columns, but there is no railing. There are a couple of benches against the wall. Also there are two graphic panels mounted on the wall, one to either side of the main entrance. The one on the left is titled "From the Fort to these Wooden Buildings." The other one is titled "Fort Pickens Area."Restrooms are located in a separate building across from the left end of the building. End of Description.

title: Fort Within a Fort
listingDescription: Fort Pickens was past its prime. New rifled artillery could penetrate its brick walls. The US Army resuscitated the antiquated brick fort in 1898 with reinforced concrete Battery Pensacola. This fort within a fort had two 12-inch rifles on carriages that could disappear behind the walls after firing 1,070-pound shells at ships eight miles away. The Army built several other batteries on this end of Santa Rosa Island in the late 1800s and early 1900s.

images.altText: Black and white photo of soldiers loading a rifle on top of Battery Pensacola.
images.caption: Historic Photo Battery Pensacola

bodyText: Fort Pickens was past its prime. New rifled artillery could penetrate its brick walls. The U.S. Army resuscitated the antiquated brick fort in 1898 with reinforced concrete Battery Pensacola. This fort within a fort had two 12-inch rifles on carriages that could disappear behind the walls after firing 1,070-pound shells at ships eight miles away. The Army built several other batteries on this end of Santa Rosa Island in the late 1800s and early 1900s.
audioDescription:
404 words
Here in the middle of the parade ground is a rectangular concrete structure which stretches almost the entire width of the space. The floor of the upper level overhangs the lower level here along this side, forming a long gallery. Doorways open into rooms and tunnel in the structure, some closed with gates made of iron bars. Near each end are stairs that lead to the second level. Each set of stairs is made of two separate staircases that lie parallel to the building, forming an "A" and providing access from either direction.

Each set of stairs opens onto a flat area with high walls on the opposite side. In the middle of the upper level are more rooms with a square central tower that extends one more level high.

To the right is the western wall lined on the inside with a series of arched openings. Behind you is the sidewalk leading back to the entrance on the north wall.

Interpretive panel: Fort within a Fort.

At the bottom of this panel is a historic photograph of a long artillery gun, its barrel extending off to the left. At the rear of the gun, on the right, a group of almost 20 men are lined up on either side of a long pole which they push into the gun. Other men stand on the walls behind and around the mechanism underneath the gun. The caption reads,

"Protected by the steel-reinforced wall, soldiers load one of the 12-inch rifles. Lead counterweights then raised the weapon to the firing position."

At upper left is a smaller picture showing a group of men posed around the bore-end of an artillery gun, standing and leaning on either side and sitting on the ground in front. One man sits inside the end of the end of the gun. The caption reads,

"Artillerymen-including one inside the tube-pose with a 12-inch rifle at Battery Pensacola."

Text at upper left reads,

"Fort Pickens was past its prime. New rifled artillery could penetrate its brick walls. The US Army resuscitated the antiquated brick fort in 1898 with reinforced concrete Battery Pensacola. This fort within a fort had two 12-inch rifles on carriages that could disappear behind the walls after firing 1,070-pound shells at ships eight miles away. The Army built several other batteries on this end of Santa Rosa Island in the late 1800s and early 1900s."

End of Description.

title: Gator Pond
listingDescription: Life in a Gator PondWho would live with an alligator? Gator ponds like this one attract birds, fish, turtles, and frogs that feed on the large numbers of minnows, snails, and aquatic insects. They, in turn, are fed upon by alligators. Female alligators build a nest of plant debris and mud on the edge of the pond, dig a hole, and lay and bury about 30 eggs that incubate for 60 days before hatching. Their clearing of the vegetation helps keep the water open, and that attracts o

images.altText: A metal framed National Park Service sign with the title text, "Life in a Gator Pond." A wooden railing and green plants in the background.
images.caption: Life in a Gator Pond Wayside

bodyText:
Do you see or hear any signs of life?

It is a cirlce of life. Gator ponds like this one attract birds, fish, turtles, and frogs that feed on the large numbers of minnows, snails, and aquatic insects. They, in turn, are fed upon by alligators.

Female alligators build a nest of plant debris and mud on the edge of the pond, dig a hole, and lay and bury about 30 eggs that incubate for 60 days before hatching. Their clearing of the vegetation helps keep the water open, and that attracts other animals.

Warning: Never get closer than 15 feet to alligators. Do not feed alligators or any wildlife.
audioDescription: Gator Pond. 114 words.At the side of the road here is a wooden platform that extends out over the bank of a pond. Wooden railings enclose the platform on three sides. A small sign at the front of the platform reads, "Do not feed or disturb the alligators."The pond is surrounded by woods with shrubs and trees coming right to the edge of the still water. Fallen logs and branches provide a great place to spot turtles as they sun themselves. Other wildlife may be seen; in particular, alligators, either sunning themselves, or gliding quietly along in the water with only their eyes and the tip of their snout above the surface.End of Description.

title: Gulf Islands National Seashore Park Headquarters
listingDescription:
The park headquarters building is located within the Naval Live Oaks Area . From this parking lot you can explore outdoor exhibits, interpretive waysides, and over 7.5 miles of nature trails.

The park headquarters building is an administrative building, there are no visitor services inside the building.

images.altText: A light brown brick building with a dark brown roof. The National Park Service orange and green arrowhead logo on the building. Black text reads, "Gulf Islands National Seashore Park Headquarters" on the building.
images.caption: GUIS Headquarters

bodyText:
The Gulf Islands National Seashore park headquarters is located in the Naval Live Oaks Area of the park. The facility is an administrative building only, there are no visitor services inside. 

From this parking lot you can explore outdoor exhibits, water access, and over 7.5 miles of nature trails. Parking, covered pavilions, and a scenic overlook are also avaliable here.
audioDescription: The Gulf Islands National Seashore park headquarters is located in the Naval Live Oaks Area of the park. The facility is an administrative building only, there are no visitor services inside. From this parking lot you can explore outdoor exhibits, water access, and over 7.5 miles of nature trails. Parking, covered pavilions, and a scenic overlook are also avaliable here.

title: High Ground
listingDescription: You are standing on the top of an old sand dune. On the Florida coast a change in elevation of a few feet can make the difference between high, dry ground like this and wet, marshy areas. Here water quickly filters down through the sand. Notice that the types of plant species change as you walk downhill along the trail.

images.altText: Florida rosemary, pines, and other plants cover sandy dunes.
images.caption: Dune Plants

bodyText: You are standing on the top of an old sand dune. On the Florida coast a change in elevation of a few feet can make the difference between high, dry ground like this and wet, marshy areas. Here water quickly filters down through the sand. Notice that the types of plant species change as you walk downhill along the trail.
audioDescription: 143 words. The panel is 24 inches wide and set to overlook a small rise in the sand. A dead tree stands in the middle of a bare patch of sand. The top of the panel features a photograph of rolling, sparsely vegetated dunes. The bottom of the panel features a closeup photograph of vegetation, some dried and some hardy species like pine. The middle of the panel has an illustrated diagram. It depicts an elevated dune on the left sloping down to a depressed marsh on the right. Following the elevation change from left to right, the illustration represents nine species of vegetation: Florida rosemary, Conradina, Live oak, Sand pine, Yaupon holly, Waxmyrtle, Saw palmetto, Sawgrass, Arrowleaf. The illustrated vegetation grows thin and short on the higher elevation on the left. The vegetation grows thicker and taller toward the lower elevation to the right. End of description.

title: Hiking in the Naval Live Oaks Area
listingDescription:
This is a great spot to start your visit to the bayside of the Naval Live Oaks Area . From this trailhead, you can access most of the trails in the area. Discover the variety of oak and pine woodlands that have taken root on this sandy peninsula between Santa Rosa Sound and Butcherpen Cove. Many small reptiles and mammals live here.

Brackenridge Trail Enjoy exhibits about wildlife, live oaks, and other woodland plants along this 0.8-mile trail.
Andrew Jackson Trail Walk a 2.4-mile section of the Pensacola-St. Augustine Road planned as the first road to connect East and West Florida.
Beaver Pond Trail Hike 1 mile through areas of longleaf pine and oak stands to a beaver pond.Old Borrow Pit Trail. Walk 0.9 mile through longleaf and sand pine communities. Sand from the borrow pit was used in building
U.S. 98. Multi-Use Trail Hike or bike a 2.5-mile section of a paved 40-mile trail along the south side of U.S. 98.

Mileage of Other Trails Fishing 1.2, Boy Scout 0.3, North Bay 0.3, Old Quarry 0.5, Brown's Pond 0.4.

Safety Precautions Wear a hat and sunglasses. Drink plenty of water. Be aware of venomous snakes, insects, and poison ivy. Stay on the trails. Watch children closely. In emergencies call 911.

Park Regulations : Do not disturb or remove any natural, historical, or archeological objects. Metal detectors are prohibited. Do not feed wildlife.

images.altText: A woman jogging on a sandy trail that cuts through tall trees.
images.caption: Naval Live Oaks Trails

audioDescription: Naval Live Oaks trails. 83 words.This dirt trail begins at the side of a maintenance drive. It heads into the thick woods filled with small trees, shrubs, and saw palmettos. As you face the trail, there is a park maintenance area to the right with a chain link gate. To the left is the park road which heads back to the highway to the south and to a Youth Campground to the north. Behind you is a small parking area for visitors.End of Description.

title: Historic Fire Station Restrooms
listingDescription: Public restrooms between the Fort Pickens Fishing Pier and the Discovery Center.

images.altText: A white building with green trim. On the building hangs a brown and white restroom sign and a handicap parking sign. A cement walkway with metal railings in front of the building. Blue sky in the background.
images.caption: Discovery Center Restrooms

bodyText: Public restrooms are located directly across from the Discovery Center entrance and south of the Fort Pickens Fishing Pier. The building white and green building is a historic Fire Station built in 1940.
audioDescription: Public restrooms are located between the Fort Pickens Fishing Pier and the Discovery Center.

title: Historic Life-Saving Station
listingDescription:
This red-roofed building in the park's Fort Pickens Area is one of the most iconic buildings at the national seashore. When constructed this building served as the Santa Rosa Island Life-Saving Station and housed the U.S. Life-Saving Service on this island.

Today the building serves as a ranger station and campground registration.

images.altText: A black and white photo of a white wood sided two-story building with many windows and white doors. A wooden boardwalk in the foreground. Two people standing on the left in the background.
images.caption: Historic Image of the Life-Saving Station

bodyText:
This building is one of the most iconic buildings in the national seashore. It was orginally constructed in 1885 to serve as the Santa Rosa Island Life-Saving Station. It was one of the two first life-saving stations in all of the state of Florida, and was home to the U.S. Life-Saving Service.

The original structure was a two-story building topped with an enclosed lookout tower that had windows on each side. The keeper, his family, and the crew lived on the second story. In 1907, the current building replaced the destroyed structure.

ith the establishment of the U.S. Coast Guard in 1915, the Santa Rosa Life-Saving Station became Coast Guard Station 212.

In 1986, the U.S. Coast Guard relocated to Naval Air Station Pensacola. The old life-saving station became a part of Gulf Islands National Seashore. Today the building serves as a ranger station and campground registration in the Fort Pickens Area.
audioDescription: Historic Lifesaving Station. 163 words.The exterior of this small building is covered in wood shingles painted a cream color. It has a steep peaked roof with red shingles. Two windows at the gable end and dormer windows along both sides of the roof indicate a second floor. The east side and part of the north side is wrapped by a wide covered porch with gray railings and white posts. There is a short ramp giving access from the parking area on the north side. To the right of the ramp is a concrete patio area with a picnic table.Another porch extends along the west side of the building, also with gray railings and a low ramp. Along that wall is a door for campground registration, then a bench, and then another door to a unisex bathroom.A wide brick chimney extends from the middle of the roof along the south side. Mounted to the left of the chimney are solar panels.End of Description.

title: Horn Island
listingDescription: In 1978 Congress designated Horn Island - among the few undeveloped barrier islands on the Gulf Coast - as a Wilderness area . Uncommon species of birds, animals, and marine life are protected here. These areas also preserve the land's natural conditions and provide opportunities for solitude and primitive recreation; benefiting generations to come.Before visiting Horn Island , ask a ranger about wilderness area regulations and the difficulties of visiting places without wa

images.altText: Spare vegetation dots the sand dunes on a remote island.
images.title: Horn Island
images.caption: Horn Island Wilderness

bodyText:
Before Horn Island became part of Gulf Islands National Seashore, it was a refuge for Walter Inglis Anderson. Known by the locals as “that crazy artist,” his family called him “Bob.” In the later years of his life, Bob rowed to Horn Island as often as possible. He created thousands of paintings and sketches inspired by the Mississippi island wilderness.
 
Today is it protect as designated Wilderness area. In 1978 Congress designated Horn Island - among the few undeveloped barrier islands on the Gulf Coast - as a Wilderness area. Uncommon species of birds, animals, and marine life are protected here. These areas also preserve the land's natural conditions and provide opportunities for solitude and primitive recreation, benefiting generations to come.

Before visiting Horn Island, ask a ranger about wilderness area regulations and the difficulties of visiting places without water, shelter, facilities, or communication.
audioDescription: Before Horn Island became part of Gulf Islands National Seashore, it was a refuge for Walter Inglis Anderson. He created thousands of paintings and sketches inspired by the Mississippi island wilderness.   In 1978 Congress designated Horn Island - among the few undeveloped barrier islands on the Gulf Coast - as a Wilderness area. Uncommon species of birds, animals, and marine life are protected here. These areas also preserve the land's natural conditions and provide opportunities for solitude and primitive recreation, benefiting generations to come. Before visiting Horn Island, ask a ranger about wilderness area regulations and the difficulties of visiting places without water, shelter, facilities, or communication.

title: Hurricane Ivan
listingDescription: On September 16, 2004, Hurricane Ivan roared across the Gulf of Mexico with 130-mile-per-hour winds and struck Santa Rosa Island and the national seashore's Fort Pickens Area nearly head-on. A 14-foot storm surge washed across the island, destroying piers and roads, flooding the fort, and damaging most of the park buildings, including the Discovery Center. Curators, conservators, and other specialists quickly went to work sorting, washing, and preserving over 300,000 cultural artifacts that had been on display or in storage on the island. The Discovery Center was put on new footings in 2007.

images.altText: Dark water flooding around the brick structures of the fort in the foreground. A black cannon is mounted on top of the fort. Green trees and blue sky in the background.
images.caption: Fort Pickens after Ivan1

bodyText: On September 16, 2004, Hurricane Ivan roared across the Gulf of Mexico with 130-mile-per-hour winds and struck Santa Rosa Island and the national seashore's Fort Pickens Area nearly head-on. A 14-foot storm surge washed across the island, destroying piers and roads, flooding the fort, and damaging most of the park buildings, including the Discovery Center. Curators, conservators, and other specialists quickly went to work sorting, washing, and preserving over 300,000 cultural artifacts that had been on display or in storage on the island. The Discovery Center was put on new footings in 2007.
audioDescription: Hurricane Ivan. 114 words. This spot is located behind the long white-frame building that houses the Discovery Center. Here at the back a short wing extends out from the middle of the building. The entire building is circled by a wide covered porch. The porch and building are slightly elevated, sitting on square concrete supports. Square white columns support the roof over the porch, which has no railings. A zig-zag ramp provides access to the porch at this rear corner. Windows along the walls have dark green trim. The several doors located along the building are also painted dark green. At the end of the wing a brick chimney extends above the green-shingled roof.End of Description.

title: Langdon Beach Access 16A
listingDescription: This beach access point is located on the Gulf-side and provides access for swimming, wading, fishing, beach-combing and more. Park in designated spaces only. Pets, glass, and driving are not permitted on bea

images.caption: Lifeguard Station

bodyText:
This beach access point is located on the Gulf-side within the Fort Pickens Area. It provides access for swimming, fishing, beach-combing and more. Lifeguards are on duty between May and September.

Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Camping and overnight parking is not permitted. Pets, glass, and driving are not permitted on beach.
audioDescription: This beach access point is located on the Gulf-side within the Fort Pickens Area. It provides access for swimming, wading, fishing, beach-combing and more. Lifeguards are on duty between May and September.

title: Life in a Gator Pond
listingDescription: Who would live with an alligator? Gator ponds like this one attract birds, fish, turtles, and frogs that feed on the large numbers of minnows, snails, and aquatic insects. They, in turn, are fed upon by alligators. Female alligators build a nest of plant debris and mud on the edge of the pond, dig a hole, and lay and bury about 30 eggs that incubate for 60 days before hatching. Their clearing of the vegetation helps keep the water open, and that attracts other animals. Do you

images.altText: A small alligator and five turtles rest on a log. The alligator's head balances on one of the turtles' shell.
images.caption: Alligator and Turtles

bodyText:
Gator ponds like this one attract birds, fish, turtles, and frogs that feed on the large numbers of minnows, snails, and aquatic insects. They, in turn, are fed upon by alligators. It's what is known to some as the food chain. If you stand here long enough you are bound to see an alligator. 

Warning. Never get closer than 15 feet to alligators. Do not feed alligators or any wildlife.
audioDescription:
299 words.

Text at the top of this panel reads,

"Who would live with an alligator? Gator ponds like this one attract birds, fish, turtles, and frogs that feed on the large numbers of minnows, snails, and aquatic insects. They, in turn, are fed upon by alligators. Female alligators build a nest of plant debris and mud on the edge of the pond, dig a hole, and lay and bury about 30 eggs that incubate for 60 days before hatching. Their clearing of the vegetation helps keep the water open, and that attracts other animals. Do you see or hear any signs of life? Warning. Never get closer than 15 feet to alligators. Do not feed alligators or any wildlife.

The background of the panel has a photograph of an alligator stretched on grassy tufts in the sun. Marsh grasses and reeds surround him. Across the bottom of the panel are five smaller photographs. Beginning at the left there is a southern leopard frog sitting on a palmetto frond. It is brown with blackspots, each with a lighter-colored dot in the middle.

The next picture shows a snapping turtle sitting on wet sand. It back is divided into rectangular shapes, all black.

The third picture shows a green-backed heron. The wading bird is greenish-gray on its back with a rosy-colored throat and a black patch on top of its head.

The next picture shows a racoon with its iconic black mask around its eyes. It sits in grass, its front legs in the water.

The last picture shows a gulf coast salt marsh snake coiled on a bare log. The snake is black with dotted line of tan running down the length of its body and tan rectangles on its thickest section.

End of Description.

title: Life of a Salt Marsh
listingDescription: The salt marsh, despite its starkness, is one of the most productive habitats in the world. Here at high tide, water from the sound flows into the marsh, bringing fresh nutrients, young fish, and larval shrimp and crabs. Plants and animals flourish in this murky mix of salt and fresh water. Spartina and needlerush grow tall, die, and enrich the dark soil. Herons and clapper rails patrol the shallows spearing fish and crabs. At night raccoons and opossums stalk the edges feedi

images.altText: Reflective water flowing through saw grass and trees. A light blue morning sky above.
images.caption: Davis Bayou Marsh at Sunrise

bodyText: The salt marsh, despite its starkness, is one of the most productive habitats in the world. Here at high tide, water from the sound flows into the marsh, bringing fresh nutrients, young fish, and larval shrimp and crabs. Plants and animals flourish in this murky mix of salt and fresh water. Spartina and needlerush grow tall, die, and enrich the dark soil. Herons and clapper rails patrol the shallows spearing fish and crabs. At night raccoons and opossums stalk the edges feeding on worms, fish, frogs, and turtles-and watching out for alligators.
audioDescription:
Interpretive panel: Life of a Salt Marsh. 500 words.

Text at the top of this panel reads,

"The salt marsh, despite its starkness, is one of the most productive habitats in the world. Here at high tide, water from the sound flows into the marsh, bringing fresh nutrients, young fish, and larval shrimp and crabs. Plants and animals flourish in this murky mix of salt and fresh water. Spartina and needlerush grow tall, die, and enrich the dark soil. Herons and clapper rails patrol the shallows spearing fish and crabs. At night raccoons and opossums stalk the edges feeding on worms, fish, frogs, and turtles-and watching out for alligators."

At upper right is a quote from John and Mildred Teal in "Life and Death of the Salt Marsh" which reads,

"Salt marshes ... are economically valuable in providing fish nursery grounds, ... feeding grounds for birds, and sources of shellfish."

The background of the panel has a color illustration of a salt marsh, open water in the middle with grasses and reeds on either side and in the background. In the foreground the view is cutaway showing the underwater scene as well. The various plants and animals are identified by numbers corresponding to a legend at upper left. Beginning at the left, there are small periwinkle snails, attached near the base of reeds growing out of the mud. Sitting on the mud next to that are two fiddler crabs, each with one large claw and one small one.

Next, underwater, is the larger blue crab, its shell with blue highlights along its claws and legs. Flying just above the water's surface is an osprey, its talons ready as it swoops towards a fish jumping out of the water.

Just below the water's surface are several mullet, gray fish with horizontal stripes and two, equal-sized fins on top.

At the right side of the drawing is a great blue heron, standing at the edge of the water. It has a blue-gray body and a long, pointed yellow beak. Hiding behind some reeds behind the bird is an American alligator, floating along the surface of the water.

Under water there is a comb jelly, almost oval-shaped with tentacles trailing below it. Flat on the bottom is a flounder, its body almost blending with the sandy bottom and both eyes on top.

Just above the water at the base of more reeds is a cluster of mussels. The two halved shells are elongated and irregular in shape.

Underwater near the heron's feet is a gulf killifish with a specked body and a single dorsal fin near its tail.

Standing behind the heron is a clapper rail, a smaller wading bird with a brown-speckled body. The reeds that the bird hides in is Spartina cordgrass, with flat pointed blades. Under water at the far right is a grass shrimp, a small crustacean with long feelers. On the bottom is a hermit crab, peeping out of the shell it uses as its house.

End of Description.

title: Massive Smoothbore
listingDescription: A 15-inch Rodman like this gun-one of the largest smoothbore cannon ever developed-was installed here in 1868 but never fired in combat. Though gradually replaced by rifled, breech-loading artillery, 8-, 10-, and 15-inch Rodmans remained the primary armament at Fort Pickens and other coastal forts until the late 1880s. The barrel of the 15-inch Rodman weighed 50,000 pounds. With a maximum effective range of three miles, it could fire a 15-inch diameter explosive shell weighin

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service sign with the title text, "Massive Smoothbore" in front of an open field and brick archways.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Interpretive Panel: Massive Smoothbore

bodyText: A 15-inch Rodman like this gun-one of the largest smoothbore cannons ever developed. It was installed here in 1868, but never fired in combat. Though gradually replaced by rifled, breech-loading artillery, 8, 10, and 15-inch Rodmans remained the primary armament at Fort Pickens and other coastal forts until the late 1880's. The barrel of the 15-inch Rodman weighed 50,000 pounds. With a maximum effective range of three miles, it could fire a 15-inch diameter explosive shell weighing about 300 pounds or a solid 450-pound shot. The circular iron tracks allowed the cannon to be turned to fire in any direction.
audioDescription:
466 words
Along the dirt path near the south wall of the fort there is a slanted graphic panel mounted on the side away from the wall. Standing facing the panel gives a view back across the remaining bit of the original open space at this end of the fort which is now partially taken up by the long mound which is the sand and vegetation-covered front of Battery Pensacola. Along the left is the line of arched openings along one of the fort's south walls, ending at the bastion located at the west-facing point. Sitting on top there, pointing to the west, is a huge black cannon mounted on a rust-red metal carriage.

At the bottom of this panel is a historical photograph showing a group of men around a large cannon mounted on a large metal carriage and pointing to the left. The caption reads,

"A gun crew at Fort Warren in Boston, Mass., loads a Rodman. The cannon, designed by Thomas Jefferson Rodman, was first cast in 1860.

Labels on the photograph identify the different elements. One stands at the rear of the large cannon, where its diameter is almost equal to his height. He leans over to look at a small rod sticking up for the top of the cannon. The label reads,

"Gunner using sight to aim cannon."

At the front of the cannon one man holds a long rod with a round black sponge on its end. Next to him two other men pass a white sack which holds the powder charge. Another man stands waiting below the cannon's bore holding the long ramrod. Near the rear of the canon four men hold a metal bar, two at each end, with a large cannon ball attached to the middle. A label reads,

""Shell hooks and carrying bar for moving cannonballs."

At lower left is a pyramid-shaped pile of cannon ball, four wide and four high. The top cannonball has a rectangular object sitting on top of it. The label reads,

"Cannonball attached to sabot, which prevented it from rolling in barrel."

Next to the stack is a square metal box called a pass box.

Text at the top reads,

"A 15-inch Rodman like this gun-one of the largest smoothbore cannon ever developed-was installed here in 1868 but never fired in combat. Though gradually replaced by rifled, breech-loading artillery, 8-, 10-, and 15-inch Rodmans remained the primary armament at Fort Pickens and other coastal forts until the late 1880s. The barrel of the 15-inch Rodman weighed 50,000 pounds. With a maximum effective range of three miles, it could fire a 15-inch diameter explosive shell weighing about 300 pounds or a solid 450-pound shot. The circular iron tracks allowed the cannon to be turned to fire in any direction."

End of Description.

title: Nature's Way Trail
listingDescription: This scenic loop trail provides views of the bayou and wildlife.

images.altText: A trailhead sign reading "Nature's Way Trail".
images.title: Nature's Way Trail
images.caption: Nature's Way Trail

bodyText:
This trail is located off of Hanley Road and connects to the Davis Bayou Trail. There are 2 trailheads, both located on Hanley Road. The 0.5 mile loop features views of the bayou and opportunities to view wildlife such as herons and alligators.

There is no parking at either end of the trailhead. Visitors may park and walk to the trail from the campground or visitor center, located on the main park road. 

Duration: 15-30 minutes

title: Naval Live Oaks Area
listingDescription: Located outside of Gulf Islands National Seashore's headquarters building on the sound-side of the Naval Live Oaks Area, this kiosk provides general information about the seashore and the Naval Live Oaks Area. Not far from here, is a trailhead for the Brackenridge Accessible Trail that leads to an overlook, and separate path to a picnic area. The park headquarters building is not open to the public.

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service signs on a small structure. Park headquarters brick building in the background.
images.caption: Naval Live Oaks Orientation Kiosk Site

bodyText:
Located outside of Gulf Islands National Seashore's headquarters building on the sound-side of the Naval Live Oaks Area, this kiosk provides general information about the seashore and the Naval Live Oaks Area.

Not far from here, is a trailhead for the Brackenridge Accessible Trail that leads to an overlook, and separate path to a picnic area.

This area also features a group campground, small boat launch, and water access to Santa Rosa Sound and Pensacola Bay.

The park headquarters building is not open to the public.

title: Naval Live Oaks Pavilion
listingDescription: The Naval Live Oaks Area picnic pavilion is located near the park's headquarters building. The pavilion includes access to picnic tables, charcoal grills, restrooms and drinking water. The pavilion and picnic tables are on a first come, first served basis. Not far from here are trails that lead to the water of the Santa Rosa Sound. A great place to launch a kayak, fish, or look for wildlife.   Parking is available. Pets are not permitted under the pavilion or in any facilit

images.altText: A brick pavilion stands on a concrete pad amongst a forest.
images.title: Naval Live Oaks Pavilion
images.caption: Pavilion in the Group Camping area of Naval Live Oaks

bodyText:
The Naval Live Oaks Area picnic pavilion is located near the park's headquarters building on the north side of Highway 98. The pavilion includes access to picnic tables, charcoal grills, restrooms, and drinking water. The pavilion and picnic tables are on a first come, first served basis, unless prior reservation takes place by a group using the campsite, or another group.

Not far from here are trails that lead to the water of the Santa Rosa Sound. A great place to launch a kayak, fish, or look for wildlife.  

Important: Pets are not permitted under the pavilion or in any facilities. Please dispose of grill materials and waste properly.

listingDescription: These restrooms are located near the Naval Live Oaks Picnic Area and Pavilion. In addition to men's and women's restrooms there are beach showers on the north side of this facility.

images.caption: Naval Live Oaks Restrooms

title: Naval Live Oaks Small Boat Launch
listingDescription:
Paddlers may access the launch site after a 60 yard level walk across a sand trail.

Camping and overnight parking is not permitted. Pets, glass, and driving are not permitted on beach.

Beach Safety In just a few minutes a wonderful day at the beach can turn into a disaster. Visit our Safety web page for more information.

images.altText: On the right, a white sand shore with green trees touches blue water on the right. A grey bridge, buildings, and a blue sky in the background.
images.caption: NLO Beach Access

bodyText: Access the calm water of the sound after walking on the tranquil trails in the Naval Live Oaks Area. This is a great place to launch a kayak, canoe, or paddle boat. The launch site is located 60 yards after the sand trail.
