title: Naval Live Oaks Youth Campground
listingDescription: The Naval Live Oaks Youth Group Campground is available by reservation throughout the year for organized youth groups comprised primarily of young people under the age of 18. This group camping area is located near Gulf Breeze, Florida and has direct access to Pensacola Bay for water recreation. The campsite features restrooms, outdoor showers, a picnic shelter, and campfire ring. The Naval Live Oaks Area has over 7.5 miles of trails for campers to explore.

images.altText: Wooden bench underneath trees overlooking blue water and sky.
images.caption: NLO Youth Campground Beach Access

bodyText:
The Naval Live Oaks Youth Group campground is available for reservation seasonally by organized groups comprised of youth under the age of 18.


This group camping area has direct access to Pensacola Bay for water recreation and trailheads. It features restrooms, outdoor showers, a picnic shelter, and campfire ring.
audioDescription: The Naval Live Oaks Youth Group campground is available for reservation seasonally by organized groups comprised of youth under the age of 18. This group camping area has direct access to Pensacola Bay for water recreation and trailheads. It features restrooms, outdoor showers, a picnic shelter, and campfire ring.

title: Nervously Vigilant
listingDescription: All alone in the glaring sun ... scanning the horizon ... looking for but hoping not to see an enemy ship or plane-guard duty was no picnic for the Coast Artillery Corps during World War II. Soldiers stood guard round the clock in three- or four-hour shifts. At night "you'd hear something moving," one soldier said, "and you couldn't tell if it was a German off of a U-boat or not." The battery, built in 1898 for two 4.72-inch Armstrong rifles, was converted into a range-findin

images.altText: National Park Service sign with the title, "Nervously Vigilant." Battery Van Swearingen in the background.
images.caption: Nervously Vigilant Site

bodyText: The Battery Van Swearingen was built in 1898 for two 4.72-inch Armstrong rifles. It was converted into a range-finding station for Battery Payne in 1922 and used throughout World War II. A U-shaped concrete structure featured two levels: the upper level with two gun emplacements (4.7 inch guns), and the lower level was used to store ammunition and equipment.
audioDescription: The Battery Van Swearingen was built in 1898 for two 4.72-inch Armstrong rifles. It was converted into a range-finding station for Battery Payne in 1922 and used throughout World War II. A U-shaped concrete structure featured two levels: the upper level with two gun emplacements (4.7 inch guns), and the lower level was used to store ammunition and equipment.

title: North Bay Trail
listingDescription: A sandy, 0.3 mile there-and-back trail leads visitors to the Pensacola Bay.

images.altText: A sign for the North Bay Trail stands next to a sandy trail into the forest.
images.title: North Bay Trail
images.caption: North Bay Trailhead

bodyText:
Also known as the Group Camp Trail, the 0.3 mile there-and-back North Bay Trail begins on the Andrew Jackson Trail and follows a sandy path down to the Pensacola Bay.

Duration: 15-30 minutes
audioDescription: A sandy path leads down to the Pensacola Bay.

title: North South Trail
listingDescription: Like the name suggests, this 2.2 mile out-and-back trail runs directly from the North to the South end of Naval Live Oaks.

images.altText: A wooden gate bars a sandy trail into the forest.
images.title: North South Trail
images.caption: North South Trailhead

bodyText:
As the name suggests, this trail runs from the North to South end of Naval Live Oaks. The trail can be started from the end of Reservation Road, but this area is residential and parking is extremely limited. A side trail at the beginning will take visitors down to the Pensacola Bay. If completed as an out-and-back, the trail is 2.2 miles total and takes visitors all the way to Highway 98.

The trail also intersects with the Beaver Pond and Andrew Jackson Trails for visitors wishing to extend their hike.

Duration: 1.5-2 hrs
audioDescription: A sandy trail near residential houses disappears into the pine and scrub forest.

title: Okaloosa Area
listingDescription: The Okaloosa Area features an excellent opportunity for swimming in the calm waters of Choctawhatchee Bay. There are restrooms and a boat launch in this area. Picnicking and swimming are the major highlights of this area. Be sure to check weather and surf conditions before visiting. There are picnic tables with charcoal grills, restrooms, and beach showers in this area toward the center of the parking lot. Visitors to this area must have a park pass or pay the entrance fee.

images.altText: A short sandy path leads to the beach.
images.title: Okaloosa Area
images.caption: Okaloosa Area

bodyText:
The Okaloosa Area features an excellent opportunity for access to the calm waters of Choctawhatchee Bay. Located between Fort Walton Beach and Destin, this area is a great place for parasailing, boating, and swimming. There are picnic tables with charcoal grills, restrooms, and beach showers in this area toward the center of the parking lot.

Visitors to this area must have a park pass or pay the fee at the box at the entrance.

Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Camping and overnight parking is not permitted. Pets, glass, and driving not permitted on beach.
audioDescription: The Okaloosa Area features an excellent opportunity for access to the calm waters of Choctawhatchee Bay. There are picnic tables with charcoal grills, restrooms, and beach showers in this area toward the center of the parking lot.

title: Okaloosa Area Boat Launch

Pets, glass, and driving are not permitted on beach. Marine Debris Kills Many animals including birds and turtles die when they become entangled in nets and fishing lines or ingest plastic trash. images.altText: A ramp leads down into a shallow bay
images.caption: Okaloosa boat launch

bodyText:
The Okaloosa Area features an excellent opportunity for access to the calm waters of Choctawhatchee Bay. Located between Fort Walton Beach and Destin, this area is a great place to picnic, boat, and swim. 

The boat launch is the perfect place to launch a kayak, canoe, or paddleboard. Trailer launching is not recommended.

Trailer launching is not recommended.

title: Okaloosa Area Orientation Kiosk
listingDescription: The Okaloosa Area Orientation Kiosk is centrally located near the restrooms. Here visitors can learn about the national seashore, beach safety, and the park's interpretive themes.

images.altText: Small, kiosk station with National Park Service signs at Okaloosa Area.
images.caption: Okaloosa Area Orientation Kiosk

bodyText: The Okaloosa Area Orientation Kiosk is centrally located near the restrooms. Here visitors can learn about the national seashore, beach safety, and the park's interpretive themes.
audioDescription:
Five panels:
Gulf Islands National Seashore. 417 words.
Beach Safety. 223 words.
Location and Legacy. 251 words.
Forts and Firepower. 153 words.
Sea...Sand...Salt Marshes...Woodlands. 159 words.

Gulf Islands National Seashore. 417 words.

This panel is four feet wide and three feet tall. Across the middle is a map showing the various areas of the park. The map includes most of the Mississippi coastline, the Alabama coastline and the westernmost part of the Florida panhandle. Areas included in the park are outlined in green - several off-shore islands near Biloxi, Mississippi and other islands off the Florida coast from Perdido Key in the west to Okaloosa at the eastern end. Park areas on the mainland include Davis Bayou near Biloxi, Fort Barrancas in Pensacola and Naval Live Oaks south of Pensacola.

Text on the panel is in both English and Spanish. At the top text reads,

"This national seashore protects our historical heritage and ever-changing features of the Gulf Coast-salt marshes, marine woodlands, sparkling white beaches, and coastal waters. Walk the trails, photograph seashore plants and wildlife, swim and boat in the emerald green waters, learn the stories of early inhabitants, or just relax and enjoy the solitude."

To the right of the text is a photograph of a white sandy beach stretching into the distance, wispy dune grass on the right and water at upper left.

Text below the map reads,

Gulf Islands National Seashore includes several islands and portions of the mainland. Here you can boat, fish, and swim in the gulf waters. On land the national seashore provides campgrounds, primitive camping areas, and trails that pass through dunes, woodlands, and marshes-habitats of a variety of mammals, reptiles, and birds. For information, exhibits, and bookstores, stop at the visitor centers."

Across the bottom of the panel are five photographs. Beginning at the left, the first one shows an alligator stretched out on a log in bright sunshine. The label reads, "Wildlife."

The next picture shows a group of people looking out over a grassy area surrounded by red brick walls. The back wall has large arched openings into dark spaces behind. In the middle are three uniformed men standing with rifles at their sides. At the right is a man dressed in a park uniform. The label reads, "Tours."

The middle photograph shows crooked live oak tree branches dripping with long Spanish moss. The label reads, "Nature."

The fourth picture shows three children in swim suits splashing in shallow water. The label reads, "Recreation."

The last picture shows a view down a structure made of a series of rounded arches, light coming from openings on the left. The label reads, "History."

Beach Safety. 223 words.

At the bottom of this panel is a photograph of four children of different races running and splashing in shallow water at the edge of a beach. Text on the panel is in both English and Spanish. Text reads,

"In just a few minutes a wonderful day at the beach can turn into a disaster. Stay alert for sudden storms and marine life that could sting or bite. Watch your children. In emergencies, dial 911.

Across the middle of the panel are specific warnings, each with a small photograph as illustration. Text reads,

"Avoid overexposure to the sun, especially between 10 am and 2 pm. Use sunscreen, sunglasses, hats, and long sleeves to protect skin. Drink plenty of water to help prevent dehydration." (Picture of the sun.)

"Thunderstorms develop quickly. If swimming or fishing, get out of the water immediately and seek shelter." (Picture of lightning.)

"Jellyfish and sea nettles can inflict painful stings. To reduce pain apply vinegar and do not touch." (Picture of a jellyfish.)

"Sharks are present in park waters. Do not swim at dawn, dusk, or night. Avoid schools of fish." (Picture of a shark.)

"Be aware of stingrays. Shuffle your feet while wading. Avoid grass beds and murky water. Soak puncture wounds in hot water." (Picture of a stingray.)

Location and Legacy. 251 words.

Text at the left side of this panel reads,

"Immerse yourself in the cultural history of Gulf Islands National Seashore. Visit Gulf Coast bays and harbors that have attracted humans since American Indians settled here between 5,000 and 10,000 years ago. Delve into the adventures of Spanish, French, British, and American explorers and settlers. Learn the stories of soldiers, sailors, slaves, and Apache prisoners. Ship Island, Santa Rosa Island, Barrancas, Naval Live Oaks-visit these places along the Gulf of Mexico that helped shape America's national heritage."

Across the top of the panel is a 1743 engraving which depicts the Spanish settlement on Santa Rosa Island that was destroyed in a hurricane in 1752. The engraving shows a walled fort at the left with buildings inside the wall and a large flag flying overhead. The rest of the land stretching to the right has a large number of small buildings along with two larger buildings with cupola-topped towers. Several small ships with bare mast float on the water in the foreground.

Across the bottom is a brown-toned photograph showing Victorian era beachgoers - dressed in their Sunday best- on the Beach at Santa Rosa Island. A group of 20 to 30 men, women and children are on the beach, waves lapping on the shore at the left. Most stand, but some sit on wooden benches in a line at the right, facing the water. The men wear dark suits. The women wear long dress. Everyone wears hats.

Forts and Firepower. 153 words.

Text at the top of this panel reads,

"Take a trip back in time by touring the many coastal fortifications in the national seashore. These historic structures, preserved by the National Park Service, symbolize European colonization, American expansionism, and the evolution of military technology to deter invasions. Visit Forts Massachusetts, Pickens, Barrancas, and Advanced Redoubt and learn about the roles they played in the Civil War. Tour coastal batteries that helped protect Pensacola Bay from the 1890s through World War II."

The panel features a photograph of a large black cannon from Fort Massachusetts on Ship Island. Pointing over a low brick wall at the gulf waters beyond, the cannon rests on a dark red metal base with wheels. The front wheels sit on a circular metal track, allowing the gun to pivot. At upper right an American flag flies at the top of a tall flag pole.

Sea...Sand...Salt Marshes...Woodlands. 159 words.

Text at the top of this panel reads,

"Explore the extensive beaches, salt marshes, and woodlands of the ever-changing northern Gulf Coast. Discover how the waves and wind shape and reshape offshore islands that shield the mainland in fierce storms. Visit salt marshes that serve as nurseries for crabs, fish, and other marine life. Walk trails that meander through coastal forests-habitats for a variety of plants and animals. The National Park Service protects these special places for you and future generations to enjoy."

The top half of the panel has a photograph of a dead tree branch, half buried in the sand at the edge of the beach. The branch cast long shadows to the right and the sand is tinged a rosy pink.

The bottom half of the panel has a photograph of rippling water flowing through a wide area of thick marsh reeds and sedges. A tree line is in the background.

End of Description.

title: Okaloosa Area Restrooms
listingDescription: These restrooms are centrally located in the Okaloosa Area and feature men's and women's restrooms as well as a beach shower.

images.altText: Cement building with one grey metal door in the center. A parking lot in the foreground.
images.caption: Okaloosa Area Restrooms

bodyText: The Okaloosa Area features a restroom facility with beach showers.
audioDescription: Halfway through the park entrance the restrooms will be located on the right hand side, mens and womens. There are also beach showers.

title: Old Borrow Pit Trail
listingDescription: The 1.8 mile Old Borrow Pit Trail is a sandy, winding way to see the Naval Live Oaks area. Parking at the trailhead is not available.

images.altText: A sandy trail leads pass sparse grass into the forest.
images.title: Old Borrow Pit Trail
images.caption: Old Borrow Pit Trailhead

bodyText:
If completed round-trip, the Old Borrow Pit Trail is 1.8 miles total. This there-and-back trail begins at a trailhead behind residential property at Reservation Road and leads to Highway 98. There is no parking available at the trailhead as the area is residential, but visitors may park at the dirt pulloff further down Reservation Road.

Sand from the borrow pit was used for the construction of U. S. Highway 98. The trail is sandy with little shade, so be sure to bring appropriate footwear and water. It also intersects with the Old Quarry, Beaver Pond, and Andrew Jackson Trails for visitors wishing to extend their hike.

Duration: 1-1.5 hours
audioDescription: A sandy trail is surrounded by sparse vegetation behind residential property. It leads into a vegetated area with grasses and trees.

title: Old Quarry Trail
listingDescription: The 1.7 mile Old Quarry Trail offers roadside parking and many side trails for visitors wishing to extend their hike.

images.altText: A wooden gate blocks the entrance of a sandy trail into the woods.
images.title: Old Quarry Trail
images.caption: Old Quarry Trailhead

bodyText:
The Old Quarry Trail begins from the trailhead on Bayshore Boulevard where limited roadside parking is available. This is a 1.7-mile out-and-back trail that ends where it joins the North-South Trail. You will find several other main trails that connect to the Quarry trail for visitors who wish to extend their hike, including the Old Borrow Pit Trail, Brown's Pond Trail, and North South Trail. There is also a small loop available almost immediately after the trail begins.

The trail is sandy with little shade, so be sure to bring water and appropriate footwear.

Duration: 45-90 minutes
audioDescription: A sandy trail barred by a wooden gate leads into a vegetated area filled with palmettos and trees.

title: Opal Beach Area
listingDescription: The Opal Beach Complex is situated along Highway 399 between Pensacola Beach and Navarre Beach. Gulf-side and sound-side parking, restrooms, and beach showers are available. Visitors must pay an entrance fee or display a park pass to use this area. Passes are good for seven days and can be purchased at the park entrance stations or online. For more frequent visitors, the national seashore offers an annual pass providing 12-months of unlimited entries into all of the park'

images.altText: People sitting on towels and under umbrellas on a white sand beach. Turquoise water and blue sky in the background.
images.caption: Opal Beach

bodyText:
Gulf Islands National Seashore protects historical heritage and ever-changing features of the Gulf Coast-salt marshes, marine woodlands, sparkling white beaches, and coastal waters. The seashore includes several islands and portions of the mainland. 

The Opal Beach Complex is located along Highway 399 between Pensacola Beach and Navarre Beach, provides access to one of the park's greatest treasures, Opal Beach. This is a great place to fish, swim, and picnic. Parking, restrooms, pavilions, and beach showers are available both Gulf-side and sound-side.

Visitors must pay an entrance fee or display a park pass to use this area. Passes are good for seven days and can be purchased at the park entrance stations or online. For more frequent visitors, the national seashore offers an annual pass providing 12-months of unlimited entries into all of the park's areas.
audioDescription:
Opal Beach. 105 words.

A small concrete block building serves as the entrance and fee station to the Santa Rosa Area. Directly across from the fee station on the gulf side is a small building with restrooms and water fountains and covered shelters with picnic tables. Parking areas lie to the right as you face the gulf. Other small buildings with facilities and covered shelters are farther to the left on the beach. Low white sand hillocks cover the area with tufts of dune grasses scattered about.On the other side of the road lies more parking and the waters of the Santa Rosa sound.

End of Description.

title: Opal Beach Cluster A
listingDescription: Cluster A is the western-most cluster of pavilions on the Gulf-side of the Opal Beach Complex. There is a restroom facility open during the summer months here with outdoor beach showers. Lifeguards are on duty in this area during the summer season. The Opal Beach Complex is open 8:00 am to sunset. Entrance fee required. One of the four pavilions may be reserved by visiting our website . Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Camping and overnight parki

images.altText: A light grey stone building with the letter, "A" on a brown metal sign. Two light brown pavilions to the left. White sand and a sidewalk in the foreground. Blue water and sky in the background.
images.caption: Opal Beach Cluster A

bodyText:
Enjoy the white sands and emerald green waters of the gulf or the calm waters of the sound. The Opal Beach Complex located in the Santa Rosa Area of Gulf Islands National Seashore is a great place to boat, fish, and swim.

Cluster A is the western-most cluster of pavilions on the Gulf-side of the Opal Beach Complex. This is one of four pavilions in the complex that can be reserved by visiting the permits page. 

Lifeguards are on duty in this area May through September. Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Camping and overnight parking is not permitted. Pets, glass, and driving not permitted on the beach.

title: Pensacola Bay City Ferry: Downtown Pensacola Departure Point
listingDescription: Pensacola Bay Cruises tour boats link downtown Pensacola, Pensacola Beach, and the Fort Pickens Area of Gulf Islands National Seashore. HMS Ferries, Inc., operating as Pensacola Bay Cruises, a private, nonsubsidised, for-profit company has signed a concessions contract to operate the service.

images.altText: A cement walkway leads up to metal structures and an interpretive wayside. Two white tour boats are docked in the water on the left side.
images.caption: Downtown Pensacola Tour Boat Departure Point

bodyText:
Pensacola Bay City Ferry tour boats link downtown Pensacola, Pensacola Beach, and the Fort Pickens Area of Gulf Islands National Seashore seasonally. While onboard the vessels visitors will enjoy beautiful views of the coastline and historic structures. The ride is about 45 minutes between each departure point location. 

The City of Pensacola is one of America's oldest settlements, built on 450 years of European-influenced history and architecture. The city celebrates a diversity of culture, customs, and geography in its parks, plazas, and old oak-lined streets. Downtown features 40 square blocks of museums, monuments, cultural centers, and gardens. Visitors enjoy the rich and evolving arts scene, and the local charm and flavor of Pensacola's restaurants, main street shops, and seasonal festivals.

HMS Ferries, Inc., operating as Pensacola Bay City Ferry, a private, nonsubsidized, for-profit company has signed a concessions contract to operate the service.
audioDescription: Tour Boat pier - Pensacola. 186 words. The ferry boat landing consists of two small square buildings covered by a flat roof supported by metal columns. A wide set of nine steps leads down from the walkway between the buildings to the water level where a single dock extends out between two ferry boat slips. A metal rail fence runs the front of the docking area and down each side. A gate in the middle provides access for passengers to board. A separate roof structure covers the wide paved walkway along the front of the water.With your back to the water, the ticketing office is in the building on the right. The building on the left has restrooms and a drinking fountain. On the far side of the building there is a ramp in addition to steps. Along this side of the building on either side of the steps there two levels of concrete, which may be used for sitting. Parking is available along the street that runs along the left. To the right are commercial docks where ships or container vessels may be moored.End of Description.

images.altText: Two deck white boat in water next to a wooden dock structure.
images.caption: Fort Pickens Tour Boat Dock

bodyText:
Pensacola Bay City Ferry tour boats link downtown Pensacola, Pensacola Beach, and the Fort Pickens Area of Gulf Islands National Seashore seasonally. While onboard the vessels visitors will enjoy beautiful views of the coastline and historic structures. The ride is about 45 minutes between each departure point location. 

Fort Pickens is a historic U.S. Army fort on Santa Rosa Island in the Pensacola area. The fort is the largest of four forts built to defend Pensacola Bay and its navy yard from foreign powers.

HMS Ferries, Inc., operating as Pensacola Bay City Ferry, a private, nonsubsidized, for-profit company has signed a concessions contract to operate the service.
audioDescription: Approaching the pier from land, one passes between the historic mine sheds. As the path rises, Pensacola Bay comes into view, spanning the entire horizon. The opposite shore is visible in the distance, with marine traffic frequently passing crossways. Dune vegetation creeps over the sides and through the cracks of the boardwalk. At the top of the rise, a path to the left leads to the sandy beach and a path to the right leads to a boat dock. As one progresses down the slope, the boardwalk continues over plain white sand and then blue water. The boardwalk's entire length is roughly 40 yards. Returning from the boat dock, Fort Pickens rises into view beyond the mine sheds as one ascends the boardwalk.

images.altText: Small yellow building and wooden benches on a wooden and cement boardwalk. Pensacola Bay in the background.
images.caption: Tour Boat Pier Pensacola Beach

bodyText:
Pensacola Bay City Ferry tour boats link downtown Pensacola, Pensacola Beach, and the Fort Pickens Area of Gulf Islands National Seashore seasonally. Whionboardard the vessels visitors will enjoy beautiful views of the coastline and historic structures. The ride is about 45 minutes between each departure point location. 

No matter what the season, beachgoers can relax on the sunny, peaceful shores of the Pensacola Beach area's emerald-green coastline. Pensacola Beach also offers an array of shopping, lodging, restaurants, and entertainment.

HMS Ferries, Inc., operating as Pensacola Bay City Ferry, a private, nonsubsidized, for-profit company has signed a concessions contract to operate the service.
audioDescription: Tour Boat pier - Pensacola Beach. 196 words. A small rectangular kiosk building here forms the ticket office for the ferry boats. A boardwalk area extends in either direction for the ticket office lined with retail stores and restaurants. The Ticket office sits at the end of a wide boardwalk which leads from the parking lot. At one side of that walk is a free-standing triangular kiosk with a graphic panel on each side. Providing information on Pensacola, the ferry boats, and the Fort Pickens Area of the National Seashore.Behind the ticket office on the edge of the beach is a small amphitheater with semicircular seating facing a small stage area with a backdrop formed by a large shell structure. The beach and the pier may be reached by circling the amphitheater on either side. Stairs are on the left side and a ramp is on the right side.The pier behind the amphitheater forms a "T" shape, running almost 300 feet out into the water to a 500-foot long dock that parallels the beach. The pier running away from the beach is made of boards with a metal grill running down the middle for drainage.End of Description.

title: Perdido Key Area
listingDescription: Welcome to the Perdido Key Area ! The area features many beach access points to visit the incredible white-sand beaches and enjoy the blue-green waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Enjoy the white sands and emerald green waters of the gulf or the calm waters of the sound. Restrooms, beach showers, parking, and picnic shelters are available at Rosamond Johnson Beach.

images.altText: Brown National Park Service sign with white text, "Perdido Key Area, Gulf Islands National Seashore." The brown arrowhead is posted on the right.
images.caption: Perdido Key Entrance Sign

bodyText: Welcome to the Perdido Key Area! This area features access to the white-sand beaches and blue-green waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Visitors can also enjoy bird watching along this accessible Perdido Key Discovery Trail or launch a kayak at the small boat launch area. Discover history behind Rosamond Johnson Beach and memorial. Restrooms, showers, parking, and picnic shelters are available at Rosamond Johnson Beach.

title: Perdido Key Area Entrance Station
listingDescription: Entrance fees are charged for most of the Florida areas of the national seashore. Passes are good for seven days and can be purchased at the park entrance stations or online. For more frequent visitors, the national seashore offers an annual pass providing 12-months of unlimited entries into all of the park's areas.The Federal Lands Recreation Enhancement Act (FLREA) allows the park service to collect and retain revenue and requires that fee revenue be used to enhance the

images.altText: A park ranger wearing a tan hat leans out of a grey stone building on the left. A black stopped car with a person's elbow sticking out the driver's window on the right. Green grass on a sand dune and a bright blue sky in the background.
images.caption: Perdido Key Entrance Station 01

bodyText:
Visit the Perdido Key Area of Gulf Islands National Seashore. This area features historic structures, a memorial, trails, covered pavilions with picnic tables, and access to one of most popular attractions, Johnson Beach. Lifeguards are on duty Memorial Day through Labor Day. 

This area only has one entrance station and is very busy in the peak season (March - October). Traffic information is featured on digital signs prior to the entrance station. 

Entrance fees are charged at this Florida location of the national seashore. Passes are good for seven days and can be purchased at the park entrance stations or online. For more frequent visitors, the national seashore offers an annual pass providing 12-months of unlimited entries into all of the park's areas.

title: Perdido Key Discovery Trail
listingDescription: Take a hike around the 0.36 mile accessible boardwalk and discover a variety of habitats and wildlife.

images.altText: A boardwalk path extends into a coastal forest.
images.title: Perdido Key Discovery Trail
images.caption: Perdido Key Discovery Trail

bodyText:
Note: This trail is currently closed to the public due to sustained hurricane damage. We apologize for the inconvenience.

Walk along this boardwalk loop in the Perdido Key area and discover a variety of habitats, including a salt marsh, wooded wetland, and sand dunes. From herons to woodpeckers, raccoons to otters, and frogs to snakes, these barrier island habitats attract a diversity of birds, small mammals, and reptiles. Take your time, look high and low, and listen carefully.

The 0.36 mile accessible trail loops back to Johnson Beach Road about 0.1 mile away. Visitors may park across the street at Johnson Beach Road parking and cross over to access the trail.

Trailhead locations:

  • North loop - near Johnson Beach ramp/boat launch
  • South loop - first left on Johnson Beach Road

Duration: 15-30 minutes
audioDescription: Perdido Key Discovery west trailhead. 114 words.This trail is a board walk made of all-weather boards with a wooden railing on either side. It starts at the side of the park road. The trail heads off through thick vegetation consisting of a variety of shrubs and bushes, dune grasses, and small pine trees.A dog waste station is at the left side of the start of the trail along with a small sign indicating bicycles are not allowed.Down the road to the left is an intersection with the main park road. On the other side of that is a beach access with parking, picnic pavilions and buildings with restrooms and water fountains.End of Description.

Take your time, look high and low, and listen carefully. The 0.36 mile accessible trail loops back to this road about a tenth of a mile away.

images.caption: Perdido Key Discovery Trail

Note: This trail is currently closed to the public due to sustained hurricane damage. We apologize for the inconvenience.

Walk along this boardwalk loop in the Perdido Key area and discover a variety of habitats, including a salt marsh, wooded wetland, and sand dunes. From herons to woodpeckers, raccoons to otters, and frogs to snakes, these barrier island habitats attract a diversity of birds, small mammals, and reptiles. The 0.36 mile accessible trail loops back to Johnson Beach Road about 0.1 mile away. Visitors may park across the street at Johnson Beach Road parking and cross over to access the trail.

audioDescription: Perdido Key Discovery trail east trailhead. 101 words.This trail is a board walk made of all-weather boards with a wooden railing on either side. This end lies at the end of a small parking lot. A boat launch for canoes and kayaks is to the right on the shore of Pensacola Bay. There are a couple of picnic tables at the far end of the parking lot.The trail heads off through thick vegetation - tall shrubs, small trees, dune grasses and a few taller pine trees.A small sign attached to the left railing indicates that bicycles are not allowed.End of Description.

title: Perdido Key Small Boat Launch
listingDescription: This small boat launch is the trail-head for the Perdido Key Blueway. This launch is not suitable for trailer boat launching. Parking is limited at this launch, you may need to unload and then park in the larger Rosamond Johnson Beach parking lots. Perdido Key BluewayThis twelve mile round trip scenic water trail through Big Lagoon exploring the rich history, abundant wildlife, and beautiful scenery. Running from here to the historic military ruins at Pensacola Pass, this blu

images.altText: Dark blue water with green grass sticking out in various places. Green trees and a bright blue sky in the background.
images.caption: PK Boat Ramp

bodyText:
Lauch your kayak or paddleboard here for access to historical points of interest, extensive seagrass beds, and interesting wildlife. This small boat launch is the trail-head for the Perdido Key Blueway. This Perdido Key Blueway comprises the first 5.5 mile portion of the 1,515 mile Florida Circumnavigational Saltwater Paddling Trail. 

This launch is not suitable for trailer boat launching. Parking is limited at this launch, you may need to unload and then park in the larger Rosamond Johnson Beach parking lots.

Do not enter historic military ruins near the site of Fort McRee or remove any historic artifacts on land or in the water.

This small boat launch is the trail-head for the Perdido Key Blueway. This Perdido Key Blueway comprises the first 5.5 mile portion of the 1,515 mile Florida Circumnavigational Saltwater Paddling Trail.This launch is not suitable for trailer boat launching. title: Petit Bois Island
listingDescription: In 1978 Congress designated Petit Bois Island - among the few undeveloped barrier islands on the Gulf Coast - as Wilderness areas . Uncommon species of birds, animals, and marine life are protected here. These areas also preserve the land's natural conditions and provide opportunities for solitude and primitive recreation; benefiting generations to come.Before visiting Petit Bois Island , ask a ranger about wilderness area regulations and the difficulties of visiting places

images.altText: Dark brown and green plants growing out of white sand. A bright blue sky and green pine trees in the background.
images.caption: Petit Bois 2

bodyText:
A great place to see fish, bird watch, or camp on an undistrubed beach, this island is only accessible by boat. Petit Bois Island is a barrier island located off the coast of Mississippi, Southeast of Davis Bayou. The island is designated a wilderness area which provides protection for plants and animals to thrive undisturbed.

Petit Bois Island is shrinking. In order to preserve it, the U.S. Army Corp of Engineers dredged sand from the island's shipping channel to create a new island, called West Petit Bois Island. As West Petit Bois Island continues to grow, plant and animal life are finding its way to the island. The impermanence and ever-changing environments of barrier islands are what make them so unique.   

Before visiting Petit Bois Island , ask a ranger about wilderness area regulations and the difficulties of visiting places without water, shelter, facilities, or communication.
audioDescription: A great place to see fish, bird watch, or camp on an undistrubed beach, this island is only accessible by boat. title: Pine Scrub Loop
listingDescription: A sandy 0.5 mile loop that brings visitors down to the Pensacola Bay.

images.altText: A sandy trail leads into the woods.
images.title: Pine Scrub Trail
images.caption: Pine Scrub Trailhead

bodyText:
This 0.5 mile trail will take you down to the Pensacola Bay, where you may sit and look out on the water before turning around and continuing the loop. The trail both starts on the Andrew Jackson Trail, and is found adjacent to the North Bay (Group Camp) Trail.

Duration: 15-30 minutes
audioDescription: A sandy trail leads through vegetation down to the bay.

title: Primary Dunes-1
listingDescription: Looking towards the gulf, the woody plants are replaced by sea oats, our local dune grass. Closer to the gulf, a plant is exposed to more environmental stresses. These conditions with which living plants must content are wind-carried salt particles, sand shifted by water and winds, differing amounts of nutrients in the soil, the drying effect of wind and sometimes being overwashed by the sea itself.

images.altText: Brown boardwalk ends in front of white sand dunes with green plants and blue water in the background.
images.caption: Dune Nature Trail View From Sign 5

bodyText: Looking towards the Gulf of Mexico, woody plants are replaced by sea oats, also known as the local dune grass. Closer to the gulf, a plant is exposed to more environmental stresses. These conditions with which living plants must content are wind-carried salt particles, sand shifted by water and winds, differing amounts of nutrients in the soil, the drying effect of wind and sometimes being overwashed by the sea itself.
audioDescription: 84 words. The panel contains only text and is set close to the ground facing west directly into the side of a tall dune. The dune breaks here where the trail cuts through, and then continues to the east. To the south, the trail ends on the beach, with a few small vegetated dunes scattered about. The Gulf of Mexico fills the entire horizon in that direction. Only the rises are vegetated with grasses and the occasional shrub, with pure white sand filling the flatter elevations. End of description.

title: Restoring a Fort
listingDescription: Fort Barrancas and the Spanish Water Battery deteriorated after the US Army closed its base here in 1947. A hard freeze in 1950 caused the parapet of the water battery's rifle gallery to collapse, and plants overgrew the structure. Debris filled Fort Barrancas tunnels and passageways. When the fort and battery became part of Gulf Islands National Seashore, the National Park Service obtained funds to restore them, and staff historians conducted extensive research. Using 90,000

images.altText: National Park Service sign in front of the white walls of the Spanish Water Battery.
images.caption: Restoring A Fort Site

bodyText: Fort Barrancas and the Spanish Water Battery deteriorated after the U.S. Army closed its base here in 1947. A hard freeze in 1950 caused the parapet of the water battery's rifle gallery to collapse, and plants overgrew the structure. Debris filled Fort Barrancas tunnels and passageways. When the fort and battery became part of Gulf Islands National Seashore, the National Park Service obtained funds to restore them, and staff historians conducted extensive research. Using 90,000 new bricks, masons repaired the brickwork. Carpenters rebuilt doors, gates, and a drawbridge. The fort was opened to the public in 1980.
audioDescription:
363 words
This tour stop is located on the level space where the cannon were placed on top of the walls enclosing the water battery. All along the outside of this space is a five-foot high outer wall. Spaced against that wall are half-circles made of stone blocks, each circle marking the position of a cannon.

Turning your back to the outer wall, you face the main part of the battery, a gleaming white structure on the other side of the small parade or open space in the middle. The wall you are standing on rises about 10 feet above the parade ground and there is no railing on that side. The parade may be reached by a stair case located in the center of the outer wall.

Behind the white water battery are the red brick walls of Fort Barrancas topped with a protective earth berm.

Interpretive panel: Restoring a Fort.

Text on the upper part of this panel reads,

"Fort Barrancas and the Spanish Water Battery deteriorated after the US Army closed its base here in 1947. A hard freeze in 1950 caused the parapet of the water battery's rifle gallery to collapse, and plants overgrew the structure. Debris filled Fort Barrancas tunnels and passageways. When the fort and battery became part of Gulf Islands National Seashore, the National Park Service obtained funds to restore them, and staff historians conducted extensive research. Using 90,000 new bricks, masons repaired the brickwork. Carpenters rebuilt doors, gates, and drawbridge. At one point a Navy explosives crew removed a live cannon ball fired in the Civil War era. The fort was opened to the public in 1980."

At bottom left are two small photographs. The one on the left shows the front of the Spanish Water Battery in 1935. The walls of the fort are dirty with most of the paint gone and stained patches. To the right is the front undergoing restoration by the National Park Service in the 1970s. Scaffolding stretches across the front. Several men with buckets bend to work on the wall.

The background of the panel has a photograph of the fort after restoration, its walls now gleaming white.

End of Description.

title: Rosamond Johnson Beach
listingDescription: This is the primary swim beach at the Perdido Key Area. During the summer months, lifeguards are on duty. Fishing is not permitted within the flagged swim beach. Two large parking lots provide convienent access to the beach, picnic pavilions, restrooms, water fountains, and beach showers. Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Camping and overnight parking is not permitted. Pets, glass, and driving are not permitted on beach. Marine Debris Kills Many

images.altText: Johnson Beach
images.title: Johnson Beach
images.caption: Johnson Beach

bodyText:
Visit Rosamond Johnson Beach for access to the pristine emerald coast waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Great for water activities, beach combing, and most popular as a swim beach. During the summer months (May to September), lifeguards are on duty and fishing is not permitted within the flagged swim beach.

Two large parking lots provide convenient access to the beach, picnic pavilions, restrooms, water fountains, and beach showers.

Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Pets, glass, and driving are not permitted on the beach. Overnight parking is not permitted.

Traffic does back up at this location and is monitored. Traffic updates can be found on the digital reader boards before reaching the entrance stations.
audioDescription: Rosamond Johnson Beach. 132 words.This recreational area is located on the beach on the gulf side of the key. As you face the water, the large parking lot lies behind you. Ahead is a sidewalk that goes between two sets of buildings with a covered walkway on the far side. On the beach side of that walk way are benches. The buildings themselves have restrooms and water fountains with water bottle refill stations. On the far side of the buildings are two large covered pavilions with many picnic tables. Past the pavilions is the beach itself, a wide stretch of white sand with the water of the gulf beyond.To the right of the complex is a smaller parking area. On the sidewalk there are freshwater showers and feet washing stations.End of Description.

title: Rosamond Johnson Beach East Pavilion
listingDescription:
This picnic pavilion is located on the eastern end of Rosamond Johnson Beach overlooking the beach and the Gulf of Mexico. There are restrooms, drinking fountains, beach showers and grills located immediately adjacent to the pavilion.

This pavilion may be reserved by visiting our website . Reservations should be made at least two weeks in advance.

images.altText: A wooden structure on white sand with a wooden ramp in front and a bright blue sky in the background.
images.caption: Johnson's Beach East Picnic Pavilion

bodyText: This picnic pavilion is located on the eastern end of Rosamond Johnson Beach overlooking the beach and the Gulf of Mexico. A ramp leads up to the pavilion from the parking lot. There are accessible restrooms, drinking fountains, beach showers, and grills located immediately adjacent to the pavilion.
audioDescription: This picnic pavilion is located on the eastern end of Rosamond Johnson Beach overlooking the beach and the Gulf of Mexico. A ramp leads up to the pavilion from the parking lot. There are accessible restrooms, drinking fountains, beach showers, and grills located immediately adjacent to the pavilion.

This picnic pavilion is centrally located at Rosamond Johnson Beach overlooking the beach and the Gulf of Mexico. There are restrooms, drinking fountains, beach showers and grills located immediately adjacent to the pavilion.

images.altText: Wooden pavilion structure on a white sand beach with wooden picnic tables underneath.
images.caption: Johnson's Beach West Pavilion

title: Rosamond Johnson Memorial
listingDescription: This memorial was established by the National Park Service to recognize the service and sacrifice of the beach's namesake, Private Rosamond Johnson. The memorial features a plaque, flag pole, and two interpretive exhibits (waysides) which illustrate the inequities of access to public beaches by people of color and the service and sacrifice of Private Johnson.

images.altText: Three waysides for a fallen soldier stand as a memorial on the beach.
images.title: Rosamond Johnson Memorial
images.caption: Rosamond Johnson Memorial at Perdido Key

bodyText:
This memorial was established by the National Park Service to recognize the service and sacrifice of the beach's namesake, U.S. Army Private Rosamond Johnson. He was killed in action during the Korean War.

The memorial features a plaque, flag pole, and two interpretive exhibits. While places like Pensacola Beach were designated “whites only”, the eastern end of Perdido Key became a refuge where black citizens could enjoy the beauty and recreational opportunities of the beach and the Gulf. The exhibits illustrate the inequities of access to public beaches by people of color and the service of Johnson.
audioDescription: Rosamond Johnson memorial plaque. The sidewalk here runs along the parking lot at the end of the pavilions and restroom areas. At the edge of the sidewalk is a gray granite pillar standing about three feet high. On its slanted top is a two-foot-square bronze memorial plaque for Private Rosamond Johnson, Jr. who was killed in action during the Korean War. As you face the memorial, the beach and the gulf surf lie to the right. To the left is a boardwalk that leads onto one of the large picnic pavilions. To the left of that are four tall freshwater showers with two shorter ones for washing feet. There is a board platform in front of the showers a short step up. Past the shower section is a sidewalk to the right that leads to the buildings with restrooms, water fountains and water bottle refill stations

title: Rugged Casemates
listingDescription: You are standing in one of the fort's 21 gun chambers known as casemates. Thirteen casemates on this level housed 10-inch Rodman cannon in the 1860s, but they were never fired in combat. Notice the arched ceiling, which was designed to transfer the massive weight of the brick and cannon above to the vertical piers and to withstand the shock waves from cannon when fired. Between firings the gun crew could close the embrasure-the opening in the wall-with iron shutters to protec

images.altText: Metal sign in front of brick fort walls.
images.caption: Fort Massachusetts: Rugged Casemates

bodyText: You are standing in one of the fort's 21 gun chambers known as casemates. Thirteen casemates on this level housed 10-inch Rodman cannon in the 1860s, but they were never fired in combat. Notice the arched ceiling, which was designed to transfer the massive weight of the brick and cannon above to the vertical piers and to withstand the shock waves from cannon when fired. Between firings the gun crew could close the embrasure-the opening in the wall-with iron shutters to protect themselves from enemy fire.
audioDescription:
90 words.

This stop is located in front of one of the arched openings that line the inner walls of the fort. All the surfaces are red brick. From the opening a 30-foot long room with an arched ceiling extends to the outer wall of the fort, ending in a small rectangular opening in the thick outer wall. There is a short step up to the floor of the room. Along each side wall are two other arches that lead into similar rooms on either side.

End of Description.

title: Rustling Creatures
listingDescription: Listen carefully for the rustle of leaf litter on the forest floor. You may hear skinks and salamanders foraging for insects in the leaves beneath saw palmettos, sweet bay, and other plants. Early in the day or after a rain, listen for box turtles plodding along looking for earthworms, berries, and mushrooms. Barely audible as they slither their way through the underbrush, snakes hunt for frogs, lizards, and mice. On spring and summer nights a chorus of barking tree frogs ech

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service panel with the title, "Rustling Creatures." Boardwalk through trees in the background.
images.caption: Rustling Creatures Site

bodyText: Listen carefully for the rustle of leaf litter on the forest floor or at night, for a chorus of barking tree frogs. You may hear skinks and salamanders foraging for insects in the leaves beneath saw palmettos, sweet bay, and other plants. Early in the day or after a rain, listen for box turtles plodding along looking for earthworms, berries, and mushrooms. Barely audible as they slither their way through the underbrush, snakes hunt for frogs, lizards, and mice.
audioDescription:
474 words
The boardwalk here continues through the woods on either side. On the south side, there are fewer trees, just tall shrubs and saw palmetto so the sunlight peers through the foliage overhead. On this side of the walk there is a slanted graphic panel with touchable models of small animals.

With the panel on your right, there is a bench 30 feet down the walk on the left.

This panel has two parts. The top half is a graphic panel with text and photographs. The bottom half has touchable models of small animals along with labels in raised lettering and in braille.

Text at the top left of the panel reads,

"Listen carefully for the rustle of leaf litter on the forest floor. You may hear skinks and salamanders foraging for insects in the leaves beneath saw palmettos, sweet bay, and other plants. Early in the day or after a rain, listen for box turtles plodding along looking for earthworms, berries, and mushrooms. Barely audible as they slither their way through the underbrush, snakes hunt for frogs, lizards, and mice. On spring and summer nights a chorus of barking tree frogs echoes through the forest."

On the right side of the panel are photographs of six reptiles and amphibians. At upper right is a picture of an Eastern box turtle nestled in dry leaves. Its domed shell is marked in a dappled brown pattern. To the left of that is a slimy salamander on a wide green leaf. Its lizard-shaped body is shiny black and covered with small tan dots.

Below those pictures are four more. Beginning at the left there is a barking tree frog clinging to tree bark. The tiny frog is bright green.

To the right is a pigmy rattlesnake on a palmetto frond. Its long body is covered with circular and rectangular patterns in brown and tan.

Next is a five-lined skink on a birch log. Its lizard-like body has lengthwise stripes in shades of brown with small dots on top. Its head is a rust color.

The last picture is a six-lined roadrunner. This lizard is brown with thin yellow stripes running down its length.

A label at lower left reads,

"Feel the different shapes of these woodland reptiles and amphibians."

Across the bottom of the panel are touchable models of these creatures, all with their heads to the left and tails to the right. Beginning at the left end is the five-lined skink with its very long tail.

Next is the six-lined roadrunner, very similar in shape.

Next is the tiny tree frog with the slimy salamander below it. The salamander has a shorter tail than the other two lizards.

Next is the pygmy rattlesnake, its long body in tight curves.

The final model is the eastern box turtle. Feel the patterns on its back.

End of Description.

title: Safer than Brick
listingDescription: Fort Pickens' brick walls and cast-iron guns had become obsolete by the end of the Civil War. Harbor defenses now called for steel guns in low-lying concrete batteries. Trueman's 3-inch, rapid-fire guns, mounted in 1905, guarded the inner channel and minefield against fast torpedo boats and minesweepers, the latest threats of the day. Trueman's guns and equipment were moved to Battery Cullum in 1943.From the water Battery Trueman's 3-inch rifles did not appear very threatenin

images.altText: National Park Service sign with the title, "Safer than Brick." Battery Trueman in the background.
images.caption: Safer than Brick Site

bodyText:
Walk to the top of this earthen mound to see Battery Trueman's concrete walls and a scenic view of the harbor entrance. Fort Pickens' brick walls and cast-iron guns had become obsolete by the end of the Civil War. Harbor defenses now called for steel guns in low-lying concrete batteries.

Trueman's 3-inch, rapid-fire guns, mounted in 1905, guarded the inner channel and minefield against fast torpedo boats and minesweepers, the latest threats of the day. From the water Battery Trueman's 3-inch rifles did not appear very threatening, but they could fire up to 10 rounds a minute. Trueman's guns and equipment were moved to Battery Cullum in 1943.
audioDescription:
253 words.

At the top of the panel is a photograph showing the barrels of two artillery guns extending just above the top of the sandy mound that encloses them on the front and sides. Labels identify each as a 3-inch rifle. The caption reads,

"From the water Battery Trueman's 3-inch rifles did not appear very threatening, but they could fire up to 10 rounds a minute."

Across the bottom of the panel is a photograph looking down onto one of the concrete gun platforms from the top of the surrounding wall as it is seen today. Beyond the battery are low grass-covered dunes with the inlet into Pensacola Bay beyond that. The caption reads,

"Walk to the top of this earthen mound to see Battery Trueman's concrete walls and a scenic view of the harbor entrance."

Text on the left side of the panel reads,

"Fort Pickens' brick walls and cast-iron guns had become obsolete by the end of the Civil War. Harbor defenses now called for steel guns in low-lying concrete batteries. Trueman's 3-inch, rapid-fire guns, mounted in 1905, guarded the inner channel and minefield against fast torpedo boats and minesweepers, the latest threats of the day. Trueman's guns and equipment were moved to Battery Cullum in 1943."

To the left of the text is a small map showing this western end of the island with Fort Pickens. Your current location at Battery Trueman on the bayside of the island near the western tip is marked.

End of Description.

title: Santa Rosa Area Entrance Sign
listingDescription: Welcome to the Santa Rosa Area ! The area features many beach access points to visit the incredible white-sand beaches and enjoy the blue-green waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Continue your hike on Florida National Scenic Trail along the beach. Enjoy the white sands and emerald green waters of the gulf or the calm waters of the sound. Restrooms, beach showers, parking, and picnic shelters are available at the Opal Beach Complex.

images.altText: Brown, metal National Park Service Sign with the text, "Santa Rosa Area, Gulf Islands National Seashore." The green and brown National Park Service arrowhead sign is on the right.
images.caption: Santa Rosa Area entrance sign

bodyText: Welcome to the Santa Rosa Area! This area features access to the white-sand beaches and blue-green waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Visitors can continue to hike on the Florida National Scenic Trail along the beach or enjoy the scenery from a boardwalk trail. Restrooms, showers, parking, and picnic shelters are available at the Opal Beach Complex.

title: Secondary Dunes
listingDescription: You are about two and a half miles from the west end of Santa Rosa Island. The Island is low and narrow and lies almost parallel to the mainland. Santa Rosa is 43 miles long, and here at the western end we find the widest section. It is here that we also find a well-developed maritime forest of slash pine, live oak and other species commonly found on the mainland. You will be walking directly across to the Gulf of Mexico. During the walk you should notice several changes in y

images.altText: Green and brown plants in the foreground. Pine trees against a blue sky far off in the distance.
images.caption: Dune Nature Trail View From Sign 2

bodyText: Santa Rosa Island is 43 miles long, and here about two and a half miles from the west end of the island, you find the widest section. You will also see a well-developed maritime forest of slash pine, live oak and other species commonly found on the mainland.

title: Ship Island Entrance Sign
listingDescription: Welcome to Ship Island ! Explore historic Fort Massachusetts, have a picnic, go for a hike, swim in the Gulf of Mexico, spot wildlife, or just sit back and enjoy the salt air on the beach.

images.altText: A sign welcoming visitors to Ship Island stands behind a boardwalk in the middle of a grassy plain.
