images.caption: Ship Island Entrance Sign

bodyText: Welcome to Ship Island ! Explore historic Fort Massachusetts, have a picnic, go for a hike, swim in the Gulf of Mexico, spot wildlife, or just sit back and enjoy the salt air on the beach.
audioDescription: Entrance sign photo opportunity. 129 words.Forty to fifty feet to the left of the boardwalk south of the fort is the official entrance sign for Ship Island. It is made of two horizontal sections attached to five wooden posts. Lettering reads, "West Ship Island, Gulf Islands National Seashore, National Park Service, Department of the Interior."The right side of the sign has a section of vertical boards with the National Park Service arrowhead logo attached. The ground here is flat, covered with grasses and sea oats with a few scattered palmetto palms.Farther down the boardwalk on the right side is a picnic pavilion area. Behind you as you face the sign the sand rises in grass covered mounds with the southeast corner of the fort just beyond.End of Description.

title: Ship Island Excursions: Gulfport Departure Point
listingDescription: Ship Island Excursions provides public ferry service to Gulf Islands National Seashore's Ship Island between mid-March and October each year. Visit the Ship Island Excursions website for schedules and ticket prices.

images.altText: A sidewalk with signs and a ticket counter leads toward a busy harbor full of boats.
images.caption: Ship Island Excursions: Gulfport Pier

bodyText:
Catch a ferry to Ship Island with Ship Island Excursions. Ship Island Excursions provides public ferry service from Biloxi and Gulfport to Gulf Islands National Seashore's Ship Island between mid-March and October each year.

Ship Island is one of the most popular of Coastal Mississippi’s six barrier islands. Located approximately 11 miles south of Gulfport and Biloxi, its beautiful beaches are a part of the Gulf Islands National Seashore.

Arriving on the north shore of the island, you’ll witness the beautifully preserved Fort Massachusetts, a brick fortification completed in 1868. With a strategic deep-water harbor located near the island, Ship Island was used in battle as far back as the War of 1812. Rangers and volunteers lead free guided tours for those interested in learning more about its incredible history.

The north shore also features a boardwalk that extends to the more-popular south shore of the island, where you’ll find beautiful beaches, pristine waters, public restrooms, and a snack bar.
audioDescription: Ship Island Excursions - Gulfport pier. 198 words.The ticket office for the ferry is located in a rectangular building next to the pier where the boat is docked. There is a raised deck in front of the office which is reached by a set of six steps in front or by a ramp on the water side, which is to the left as you face the building. A large patio area in front of the building is covered by a roof supported by square concrete columns spaced around the perimeter. As you face the ticket office, there are several backless benches on the left side of the patio. At the right is a small gift shop with open racks along the right side of the patio. Behind you is a very large covered pavilion. Past it on the right is a small wooden lighthouse.The wide wooden pier for the ferry boat extends out to the left of the ticket office. The boat docks to the left of the pier. In the water beyond is a marina with rows of boat slips. Public restrooms are located along the concrete wharf to the right of the ferry pier.End of Description.

title: Ship Island Lighthouses
listingDescription: Dan McColl served as lighthouse keeper from 1877 to 1899. Despite having lost a leg, he climbed the stairs twice a day to tend the light.Life on an island might be too lonely for some people, but it was an adventure for the McColl and Stone families. Between them Dan McColl and Claude H. Stone, Sr., tended the Ship Island Lighthouse for 40 years. Their wives and children helped them fuel the lanterns, clean the glass lenses, and maintain the boats and buildings, but the child

images.altText: Black and white photo of a tall wooden lighthouse and a small house attached on the right.
images.caption: Historic Photo of Ship Island Lighthouse

bodyText:
The first lighthouse was completed in 1853 and survived the fighting at Ship Island during the Civil War. Eventually, the harsh environment took its toll on the lighthouse and it was abandoned in 1885. A new lighthouse was constructed in 1886. For nearly a century this lighthouse signaled the safety of Mississippi Sound until 1957. After surviving numerous storms and strong hurricanes, the wooden tower was accidentally set on fire by campers and destroyed in 1972.

Area residents mourned the loss of the historic structure a proposal was initiated and approved to build a replica-styled exhibit. Construction of the new exhibit started in 1998 and was capped off when a Coast Guard helicopter placed the new cupola a top the tower in February 2000. Unfortunately, Hurricane Katrina’s intense winds and waves destroyed the exhibit just five years after its dedication.
audioDescription:
Ship Island pier - Ship Island Lighthouses. 399 words.

The Background of this panel has a brown-toed photograph showing a lighthouse on top of a tower made of open wooden truss. To the left is a one-story square house with a covered porch on the front and side. A man and a woman stand on the steps leading to the porch, the man with crutches and only one leg. A rectangular house with a covered porch along the front sits to the right. The caption reads,

"Dan McColl (right, on porch) served as lighthouse keeper from 1877 to 1899. Despite having lost a leg, he climbed the stairs twice a day to tend the light."

Text at the top left reads,

"Life on an island might be too lonely for some people, but it was an adventure for the McColl and Stone families. Between them Dan McColl and Claude H. Stone, Sr., tended the Ship Island Lighthouse for 40 years. Their wives and children helped them fuel the lanterns, clean the glass lenses, and maintain the boats and buildings, but the children had plenty of time to play and explore the island. The first lighthouse, built in 1853, guided ships traveling between New Orleans and Mobile away from shallow waters in the Mississippi Sound and into the deep-water channel west of the island. Over a century, Confederates and a fire damaged or destroyed the original brick tower and its wooden successor."

Below the text a quote from Recollections and Memories of a Lighthouse Family by Rev. Claude Howard Stone, Jr. reads,

"Were we going fishing, walking on the beach, swimming, boating or just playing in the cool shade of the porch? Boy! What a terrible decision we had to make as ... kids."

On the right side are three smaller photographs of the light house at various times. The top picture shows a solid white round tower with a cylindrical lamp on top. The middle picture shows a square white wooden tower with a many-sided lamp on top. The bottom picture shows a similar-looking lighthouse as viewed from the water. The caption reads,

"The 1853 brick lighthouse (below, top) was replaced in 1886 by the wooden tower (large image). The tower was later enclosed (below, middle). Fire destroyed it in 1972. A replica of the wooden lighthouse was built in 2000 (below, bottom), but Hurricane Katrina destroyed it in 2005."

End of Description.

title: Ship Island Pier
listingDescription:
Ferries embark and disembark here for the mainland. Make sure to board the correct ferry (Gulfport bound or Biloxi bound) at the correct time. Fishing is not permitted from the ferry pier.

A portion of the pier is open to loading and unloading from private vessels, look for signs on the pier to direct you to the appropriate locations. Private vessels may not be left unattended at the pier.

images.altText: A pier with a ferry docked on the left extends out over the water.
images.title: Ship Island Pier
images.caption: The Ship Island Excursion ferry docks on the left side of the pier.

bodyText:
Catch a ferry to Ship Island with Ship Island Excursions. This pier is located on Ship Island, and can take visitors to Biloxi or Gulfport.

Ship Island is one of the most popular of Coastal Mississippi’s six barrier islands. Located approximately 11 miles south of Gulfport and Biloxi, its beautiful beaches are a part of the Gulf Islands National Seashore.

Arriving on the north shore of the island, you’ll witness the beautifully preserved Fort Massachusetts, a brick fortification completed in 1868. With a strategic deep-water harbor located near the island, Ship Island was used in battle as far back as the War of 1812. Rangers and volunteers lead free guided tours for those interested in learning more about its incredible history.

The north shore also features a boardwalk that extends to the more-popular south shore of the island, where you’ll find beautiful beaches, pristine waters, public restrooms, and a snack bar.

A portion of the pier is open to loading and unloading from private vessels, look for signs on the pier to direct you to the appropriate locations. Private vessels may not be left unattended at the pier.
audioDescription: Ship Island pier. 90 words. The pier where the ferry docks stretches 750 feet out from the north shore of the island. The composite board pier is about 10 feet wide. There is no railing, but square concrete supports extend three feet up on either side about every eight feet. At the end where the ferry docks, the pier is wider. The boats dock on both sides. On shore the pier crosses the narrow beach where it connects with the boardwalk that crosses to the south side of the island. End of Description.

title: Ship Island Swim Beach
listingDescription: This swim beach is located on the Gulf-side and provides access for swimming, wading, fishing, beach-combing and more. There are restrooms, beach showers, water fountains, a pavilion, and concession operated snack bar located nearby. Lifeguards are on duty during the summer months.Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Camping and overnight parking is not permitted. Pets, glass, and driving are not permitted on beach. Marine Debris Kills Many animals i

images.altText: Two rows of wood and blue fabric chairs rest on a white sand beach.
images.title: Ship Island Swim Beach
images.caption: Chairs and umbrellas are available for rent on the swim beach.

bodyText:
The Ship Island swim beach is located on the southside of the island and provides access for swimming, wading, fishing, beach-combing and more.

There are restrooms, beach showers, water fountains, a pavilion, and concession stand located nearby. This beach is accessable by private boat. Lifeguards are on duty during the summer months.
audioDescription: Ship Island Beach. The Ship Island swim beach is located on the southside of the island and provides access for swimming, wading, fishing, beach-combing and more. End of Description.

title: Shoot and Duck
listingDescription: Battery Cooper's rifles popped up, disappeared, and reappeared like a jack-in-the-box. The battery, built in 1906, had two 6-inch rifles mounted on disappearing carriages. When the guns were fired, the recoil automatically lowered them behind the concrete wall, which protected the crews while they reloaded the guns. Counterweights returned them to the firing position. During World War I, the US Army removed the guns for possible use as railway guns in France. The gun you see

images.altText: National Park Service sign with the title, "Shoot and Duck." Battery Copper in the background.
images.caption: Shoot and Duck Site

bodyText: Battery Cooper's rifles popped up, disappeared, and reappeared like a jack-in-the-box. The battery, built in 1906, had two 6-inch rifles mounted on disappearing carriages. When the guns were fired, the recoil automatically lowered them behind the concrete wall, which protected the crews while they reloaded the guns. Counterweights returned them to the firing position. During World War I, the US Army removed the guns for possible use as railway guns in France. The gun you see here today came from the Smithsonian Institution.
audioDescription:
247 words.

At the top of this panel is the long barrel of an artillery gun pointed over a high concrete wall, a man in uniform standing on a platform at its rear. At the right is an inset with a drawing showing the gun having been folded back and lying below the top of the wall. The caption reads,

"The gun carriage arms swung back and lowered the gun."

Across the bottom is a photograph showing a blackened concrete structure with a metal platform on top. The space below the platform is filled with machinery. The caption reads,

"The 6-inch gun has been removed, but the gun carriage remains in this photo taken at Battery Cooper."

Text on the left side of the panel reads,

"Battery Cooper's rifles popped up, disappeared, and reappeared like a jack-in-the-box. The battery, built in 1906, had two 6-inch rifles mounted on disappearing carriages. When the guns were fired, the recoil automatically lowered them behind the concrete wall, which protected the crews while they reloaded the guns. Counterweights returned them to the firing position. During World War I, the US Army removed the guns for possible use as railway guns in France. The gun you see here today came from the Smithsonian Institution."

To the right is a small map showing the end of the island with Fort Pickens. Battery Cooper's position lying to the east of the fort and towards the gulf shoreline is marked.

End of Description.

title: Standing Tall
listingDescription: Oaks, magnolias, and hickory trees have withstood strong winds and salt spray to produce a dense forest canopy in this old dune area between Santa Rosa Sound and Pensacola Bay. Other trees that have taken root in the sandy soil include redbays, laurel oaks, eastern red cedars, and slash pines. Growing beneath them are yaupon holly, saw palmetto, and-in the wet peaty swales-sawgrass. The gray garlands hanging from live oaks are Spanish moss. Not a true moss but a member of the

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service panel with the title, "Standing Tall." Boardwalk through trees in the background.
images.caption: Standing Tall

bodyText: Oaks, magnolias, and hickory trees have withstood strong winds and salt spray to produce a dense forest canopy in this old dune area between Santa Rosa Sound and Pensacola Bay. Other trees that have taken root in the sandy soil include redbays, laurel oaks, eastern red cedars, and slash pines. Growing beneath them are yaupon holly, saw palmetto, and-in the wet peaty swales-sawgrass. The gray garlands hanging from live oaks are Spanish moss. Not a true moss but a member of the pineapple family, it absorbs water and food from the air. This mixed woodland serves both as a wildlife habitat and as a storm buffer for the mainland.
audioDescription:
425 words
The boardwalk with its wooden curbs curves slightly through the woods on either side. Alongside the walk on the outside of the curve there is a slanted graphic panel with touchable models of tree bark and leaves. The vegetation is thick with trees, tall shrubs and saw palmetto, looking almost like a green tunnel in places.

This panel has two parts. The top half is a graphic panel with text and photographs of birds. The bottom half has touchable models of the birds along with labels in raised lettering and in braille.

Text at the top left of the panel reads,

"Oaks, magnolias, and hickory trees have withstood strong winds and salt spray to produce a dense forest canopy in this old dune area between Santa Rosa Sound and Pensacola Bay. Other trees that have taken root in the sandy soil include redbays, laurel oaks, eastern red cedars, and slash pines. Growing beneath them are yaupon holly, saw palmetto, and-in the wet peaty swales-sawgrass. The gray garlands hanging from live oaks are Spanish moss. Not a true moss but a member of the pineapple family, it absorbs water and food from the air. This mixed woodland serves both as a wildlife habitat and as a storm buffer for the mainland."

At the right side of the panel is a photograph of a sandy path winding through woods with the twisty branches of live oak trees draped with gray-green masses of Spanish moss and saw palmetto underneath. In the middle of the panel is a smaller photograph of Spanish moss, a long dangling mass of tangled fibers.

Across the lower right of the graphic half of the panel are photographs of the foliage of three trees. At left is pignut hickory which has a compound leaf with five to seven long pointed leaflets.

Next is the eastern red cedar, an evergreen with scale-like foliage on small branchlets.

At right is the southern live oak. It has glossy leaves in the shape of narrow ovals.

Across the bottom of the panel are touchable models of the foliage and bark of these three trees. The label reads,

"Compare the leaves, needles, and bark of trees found in this woodland."

Beginning at the right is the pignut hickory with its compound leaf and rough bark.

Next is the eastern red cedar with its flat scale-like foliage and bark with larger divisions.

At the right end is the live oak with its oval leaves and bark with a roughness intermediate to the other two trees.

End of Description.

title: Stark Bayou Overlook
listingDescription: The Stark Bayou Overlooks provides views of an open marsh full of vegetation and winding waterways, all bordered by a woodland area. This is a great place to see wildlife.

images.altText: A wooden railing stands in front of dense vegetation and blue bayou.
images.title: Stark Bayou Overlook
images.caption: Stark Bayou Overlook

bodyText:
The Stark Bayou overlooks an open marsh full of vegetation and winding waterways, all bordered by a woodland area. A boardwalk stretching across the bayou makes this is a great place to view wildlife or take photographs. Often this waterway is one of the best places to see wildlife like birds, turtles, crabs, and alligators. 

Parking is available at the beginning of the waterway in front of the Nature’s Way Loop Trail entrance, or just past the waterway across at the corner of Robert MeGhee Road and Boat Launch. Please do not stop your vehicle in the road for a photo, as this can be dangerous to other cars, people, and wildlife.
audioDescription: Stark Bayou overlook. The Stark Bayou overlooks an open marsh full of vegetation and winding waterways, all bordered by a woodland area. A boardwalk stretching across the bayou makes this is a great place to view wildlife or take photographs. End of Description.

title: Step Back in History
listingDescription: This introductory wayside is located at the Fort Pickens parking lot and introduces visitors to the fort and the self-guiding tour, which is available in this app by navigating to the home screen, selecting tours, and then selecting Fort Pickens Tour. The tour begins immediately inside the sally port.

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service sign with the title text, "Step Back in History." Fort in the background.
images.caption: Interpretive Panel: Step Back in History

bodyText: Step back in history for a glance of Fort Pickens. To learn more about the fascinating history of this defensive fortification, follow the sidewalk straight ahead and begin your self-guiding tour.
audioDescription:
532 words
This point sits at the corner of the parking lot next to the fort. From here a wide sidewalk curves gently to the right towards a rounded arch entrance in the side of the weathered brick fort. Near the entrance another sidewalk curves around to the left towards a small brick building against the wall of the fort.

Left of the entrance weathered brick of the fort's walls rise tall. Small openings covered by iron bars are spaced along the walls. To the right of the entrance a section of the fort's walls is missing giving a glimpse of the arched gallery along the inside of the far wall. A wooden rail fence runs across the opening left by the missing wall section.

Behind you as you face the entrance to the fort, on the far side of this end of the parking lot, is a sidewalk leading towards a group of white wood-frame buildings, some single-story and others two-story.

Interpretive panel: Step back in history.

On the right side of this panel is a map showing the layout of the fort as it looks today. The basic shape of the main fort is five sided with an extended area called a bastion at each corner. The fort is longer in the north-south direction than east-west. Your current location at the corner of the parking lot is at the end of a sidewalk which leads to the entrance in the northern face. The northwest section of the fort, the original Bastion D, is missing.

The open area in the middle of the fort is called the parade. A roughly rectangular structure, called Battery Pensacola, lies across the middle of that space.

Along the eastern side, the left on the diagram, is an outer wall called the counterscarp wall with a dry ditch between it and the main walls of the fort.

A dotted line shows the route of a wheelchair-accessible tour route through the fort. Symbols indicate the location of restrooms and drinking fountain down a sidewalk to the left of the main entrance. The bookstore is located on the right along the entrance tunnel through the north face.

In the bottom left corner of the panel is a black and white photograph looking down into the parade area. Two of the inner walls are visibly lined with arched openings. A pyramid of stacked cannon balls sits in one corner. The caption reads,

"Fort Pickens was a Union fort during the Civil War."

At upper left text reads,

"Fort Pickens played a critical role in an 1800s homeland-security program. Pickens was the largest of four forts the US government built to protect Pensacola Bay and the navy yard. The fort succeeded, not against a foreign invasion, but against the Confederacy during the Civil War. To learn more about the fascinating history of this defensive fortification, follow the sidewalk straight ahead and begin your self-guiding tour. The fort closes at sunset."

Below the text is a quote by Lieutenant Henry W. Halleck, "Report on the Means of Defence," 1843, which reads,

"...as the means of preserving peace, and as obstacles to an invader, [the forts'] influence and power are immense."

End of Description.

title: Storm Buffers & Murky Birthplace
listingDescription:
Storm Buffers
In front of you, beyond Davis Bayou and Deer Island, are some storm buffers. Though 8 to 10 miles away, Horn Island and five other islands-Petit Bois, West Petit Bois, Ship, and Cat- help shield the sound and the mainland from the full brunt of hurricane winds and waves stoked by the gulf's warm waters. These islands slowly migrate westward as they are reshaped by currents running along the shorelines. They are part of an irregular 2,000-mile chain of barrier islands along the U.S. coast from New York to Texas.

Vegetation plays a critical role in shaping the landforms and providing some stability. On the islands, grasses trap sands that form dunes, where shrubs and trees take root. Seagrass beds and salt marshes help curb erosion.

Murky Birthplace
Don't let the stillness of the salt marsh fool you. The dark murky waters are swimming and crawling with life. Protected from predators of the open sea, the marsh serves as a productive breeding ground, maternity ward, and nursery for shrimp, crabs, shellfish, and finfish. Juvenile clams, oysters, and mussels filter nutrients from the tides. Young fiddler crabs and blue crabs feed on decaying plants and tiny organisms in the mud. Croaker, redfish, and mullet minnows devour aquatic insects, grow up, and as adults move out to the open coastal waters.

images.altText: National Park Service sign with the title, "Storm Buffers & Murky Birthplace."
images.caption: Storm Buffers & Murky Birthplace

bodyText:
Storm Buffers
In front of you, beyond Davis Bayou and Deer Island, are some storm buffers. Though 8 to 10 miles away, Horn Island and five other islands-Petit Bois, West Petit Bois, Ship, and Cat- help shield the sound and the mainland from the full brunt of hurricane winds and waves stoked by the gulf's warm waters. These islands slowly migrate westward as they are reshaped by currents running along the shorelines. They are part of an irregular 2,000-mile chain of barrier islands along the U.S. coast from New York to Texas.

Vegetation plays a critical role in shaping the landforms and providing some stability. On the islands, grasses trap sands that form dunes, where shrubs and trees take root. Seagrass beds and salt marshes help curb erosion.

Don't let the stillness of the salt marsh fool you. The dark murky waters are swimming and crawling with life. Protected from predators of the open sea, the marsh serves as a productive breeding ground, maternity ward, and nursery for shrimp, crabs, shellfish, and finfish. Juvenile clams, oysters, and mussels filter nutrients from the tides. Young fiddler crabs and blue crabs feed on decaying plants and tiny organisms in the mud. Croaker, redfish, and mullet minnows devour aquatic insects, grow up, and as adults move out to the open coastal waters.
audioDescription:
Two panels:
Storm Buffers. 256 words.
Murky Birthplace. 251 words.

Storm Buffers. 256 words.

The background of this panel has an aerial photograph of Horn Island with the Gulf of Mexico on the left and the Mississippi Sounds on the right. The island is long and narrow, white beaches along its shores and dark vegetation over the middle. Text in the upper right reads,

"In front of you, beyond Davis Bayou and Deer Island, are some storm buffers. Though 8 to 10 miles away, Horn Island and five other islands-Petit Bois, West Petit Bois, East Ship, West Ship, and Cat- help shield the sound and the mainland from the full brunt of hurricane winds and waves stoked by the gulf's warm waters. These islands slowly migrate westward as they are reshaped by currents running along the shorelines. They are part of an irregular 2,000-mile chain of barrier islands along the U.S. coast from New York to Texas."

In the lower right are three smaller photographs. The one on the left shows a sandy area with grasses in the foreground and shrubs and small trees behind. The middle Photograph is an underwater view of thick seagrass covering the bottom. The right picture shows a stretch of marsh grasses bordered by water on one side and trees on the other. The caption reads,

"Vegetation plays a critical role in shaping the landforms and providing some stability. On the islands, grasses (below, left) trap sands that form dunes, where shrubs and trees take root. Seagrass beds (middle) and salt marshes (right) help curb erosion."

Murky Birthplace. 251 words.

Text at the left end of this panel reads,

"Don't let the stillness of the salt marsh fool you. The dark murky waters are swimming and crawling with life. Protected from predators of the open sea, the marsh serves as a productive breeding ground, maternity ward, and nursery for shrimp, crabs, shellfish, and finfish. Juvenile clams, oysters, and mussels filter nutrients from the tides. Young fiddler crabs and blue crabs feed on decaying plants and tiny organisms in the mud. Croaker, redfish, and mullet minnows devour aquatic insects, grow up, and as adults move out to the open coastal waters."

At the right end is a photograph of a tricolored heron, wading through shallow water between reeds. It has a slim blue-gray body, a long neck, and a long, sharp bill. Just above that is a small photograph of two grass shrimp, their shells near transparent showing their internal organs as dark masses.

At lower left are three more photographs. Beginning at left there is a picture of a flounder, its flat, pale gray body almost invisible as it lies on the sandy bottom, two black spots on the upper side of its body. Next is a picture of three striped mullet, gray fish with narrow strips of a lighter color running down the length of their bodies. The last picture shows a blue crab peering up from seaweed on the bottom. Its left claw has a streak of bright blue on it.

End of Description.

title: Teeming with Life - Brackenridge Trail
listingDescription: From the forest floor to the treetops, this coastal woodland is full of activity. Beneath the live oaks, magnolias, and saw palmettos, frogs, skinks, snakes, and salamanders forage for bugs and beetles in the leaf litter and on downed trees. Armadillos, skunks, and raccoons shuffle along feeding on ants, worms, spiders, and berries. Squirrels dart here and there gathering acorns and nuts to feed their young high up in the oak and hickory trees. Vireos, warblers, and woodpecke

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service panel with the title, "Teeming With Life." Boardwalk through trees in the background.
images.caption: Teeming With Life Site

bodyText: From the forest floor to the treetops, this coastal woodland is full of activity. Beneath the live oaks, magnolias, and saw palmettos, frogs, skinks, snakes, and salamanders forage for bugs and beetles in the leaf litter and on downed trees. Armadillos, skunks, and raccoons shuffle along feeding on ants, worms, spiders, and berries. Squirrels dart here and there gathering acorns and nuts to feed their young high up in the oak and hickory trees. Vireos, warblers, and woodpeckers fill the air with calls and songs.
audioDescription:
453 words
At this point the boardwalk with its wooden curb on each side splits at a "Y" fork. You may follow this loop trail in either direction. At the intersection there is a slanted graphic panel with touchable models of some animals that may be found here in the woods. The vegetation on both sides of the walk is thick with trees, tall shrubs and saw palmetto, forming a green tunnel for you to walk through.

This slanted panel has a graphic across the top and touchable models along its bottom. Text at upper left reads,

"From the forest floor to the treetops, this coastal woodland is full of activity. Beneath the live oaks, magnolias, and saw palmettos, frogs, skinks, snakes, and salamanders forage for bugs and beetles in the leaf litter and on downed trees. Armadillos, skunks, and raccoons shuffle along feeding on ants, worms, spiders, and berries. Squirrels dart here and there gathering acorns and nuts to feed their young high up in the oak and hickory trees. Vireos, warblers, and woodpeckers fill the air with calls and songs."

The right side of the panel has a photograph of a view through mature tree trunks out into a woodland meadow willed with various shrubs. There are four smaller photographs of common animals. At top left is a red-bellied woodpecker. This bird has a black back with narrow white stripes across it and a red band running from its beak, across the top of it head and down its neck. Below that is a picture of a nine-banded armadillo with its rounded armored back. It has a long snout and small round ears on top of its head.

At right, the top picture shows a patent-leather beetle, all three of its body segments a shiny black. Below that is a coral snake. It has wide bands of black and red separated by narrow bands of yellow.

Touchable models of these four animals are along the bottom of the panel with labels in both braille and raised lettering. The caption reads,

"Trace the shapes of a few animals that live in these coastal woodlands."

Beginning at bottom left is the red-bellied woodpecker. It clings to the right side of a tree trunk, head at the top.

Next is the coral snake. Its head is at the left. Trace its coiled body around to its tail.

Next is the armadillo, snout at the left. Moving to the right there are its pointed ears, it clawed feet underneath and its long tail curved around it.

The last model is the beetle. Its head with its long pinchers is to the right and its oval abdomen with grooves down its length at the left.

End of Description.

title: The Mine Storeroom
listingDescription: The Mine Storeroom is operated by the park's tour boat concessioner, Pensacola Bay Cruises and is open when the tour boats are running. In this building, visitors can learn about the historic use of the building by the United States Army. Visitors may also purchase tour boat tickets, food, and beverages inside. Outside the building there are additional exhibits, a water filling station, a shade shelter, and restroom facilities.

images.altText: Exhibits about the mine storeroom line the walls with a wide open concrete space in the middle.
images.title: Fort Pickens Mine Storeroom
images.caption: Mine Storeroom

bodyText:
In the Mine Storeroom, visitors can learn about the historic use of the building by the U.S. Army. It was originally built in 1898 to hide the mine defense system. After an explosion at Fort Pickens in 1899, the structure was rebuilt on the existing foundation.  The Army eliminated Pensacola’s mine defense system in 1926. Afterward, the responsibility for the harbor’s mine system fell to the U.S. Navy. The Army repurposed each structure for other purposes and continued using them through World War II.

Today the storeroom is operated by the park's tour boat concessioner, Pensacola Bay Cruises, and is open when the tour boats are running. Visitors can purchase tour boat tickets, food, and beverages inside. Outside the building there are additional exhibits, a water filling station, a shade shelter, and restroom facilities. In between the buildings, a wide sidewalk leads to the pier where the ferry docks.
audioDescription: Fort Pickens Plaza. 197 words. The plaza is a wide concrete area near the bay side of the island. On the north side of the plaza are two small brick buildings, one with a cart in front that holds two models of mines. To the left of the buildings is a large covered pavilion with benches. In between the buildings a wide sidewalk leads to the pier where the ferry docks. On the right side of that sidewalk is a water bottle filling station. A sign on the left side of the plaza indicates directions to places of interest. The fishing pier and the Fort Pickens Discovery Center are both to the left. The building on the right is identified as the Mine Storeroom with food, ferry tickets, and exhibits. Just to the south of that building on the right is a small building with restrooms. On the back of the plaza sign is a touchable map of the Fort Pickens area including braille labels. If you turn your back to the plaza sign there is a sidewalk to the south leading to Fort Pickens. The parking area is to the right as you face the fort. End of Description.

title: Trench Trail
listingDescription: Walk the 0.5-mile level Trench Trail from Fort Barrancas to Advanced Redoubt.

images.altText: A trail sign stands next to a wooded path.
images.title: Fort Barrancas Trench Trail
images.caption: Fort Barrancas Trench Trail

bodyText:
This trail begins adjacent to the Fort Barrancas Visitor Center. Visitors may park next to the visitor center and begin the trail, which crosses the road and connects to Advanced Redoubt. Portions of the historic communication trench are visible all along the trail.
Use extreme caution crossing the busy highway. Bicycles are not permitted. The trail is 0.5 miles total.

Trailhead locations: 

  • Fort Barrancas Visitor Center
  • Advanced Redoubt

Duration: 30-45 minutes

Note: This trail is inside Naval Air Station Pensacola, which is currently closed to the public. Visitors must have an eligible DoD ID to access the base and the Fort Barrancas area. We apologize for the inconvenience.
audioDescription: Fort Barrancas Trench Trail. 84 words.From this location the smooth dirt path heads through the woods going north towards Advanced Redoubt. The woods here have small trees with thick understory of shrubs. Dappled sunlight shines on the path. To the left, the path leads to the visitor center parking lot. Behind you and to the right there are several picnic tables. Through the woods behind you the visitor center is just visible. Tucked in the woods to the right is a maintenance shed.End of Description.

title: Trench Trail - Advanced Redoubt Trailhead
listingDescription: Walk the 0.5-mile level Fort Barrancas Trench Trail along this historic communication trench from the Advanced Redoubt to Fort Barrancas . Portions of the historic trench are visible all along the trail. Use extreme caution crossing the busy highway.

images.altText: Small, tree-lined path.
images.caption: Fort Barrancas Trench Trailhead: Advanced Redoubt

bodyText:
This trail begins in the southeast corner of the Advanced Redoubt parkling lot. Visitors may park at Advanced Redoubt and begin the trail, which crosses the road and connects to Fort Barrancas and the visitor center. Portions of the historic communication trench are visible all along the trail.
Use extreme caution crossing the busy highway. Bicycles are not permitted. The trail is 0.5 miles total.

Trailhead locations: 

  • Fort Barrancas Visitor Center
  • Advanced Redoubt

Note: This trail is inside Naval Air Station Pensacola, which is currently closed to the public. Visitors must have a military or federal ID to access the base and the Fort Barrancas area. We apologize for the inconvenience.
audioDescription: Fort Barrancas Trench Trailhead. 90 words.At the south east corner of the parking lot near Advanced Redoubt is one end of the trench trail. The dirt path heads south through the woods. Dappled sun shines through the foliage of tall trees overhead. The understory is full of small trees and shrubs, limiting visibility to either side.A small sign on top of a wood post at the entrance to the trail reads, "Trench Trail. Fort Barrancas, 0.4 mile. No bicycles."Behind you is Advanced Redoubt surrounded by grassy lawns.End of Description.

title: West Petit Bois Island
listingDescription: A great place to see fish, bird watch, or camp on an undistrubed beach, this island is only accessible by boat. West Petit Bois Island is a barrier island located off the coast of Mississippi, Southeast of Davis Bayou. The island is designated a wilderness area which provides protection for plants and animals to thrive undisturbed.

images.altText: An aerial view shows West Petit Bois island in the gulf beside Petit Bois Island
images.caption: West Petit Bois Island, aerial view

bodyText:
A great place to see fish, bird watch, or camp on an undistrubed beach, this island is only accessible by boat. West Petit Bois Island is a barrier island located off the coast of Mississippi, Southeast of Davis Bayou. The island is designated a wilderness area which provides protection for plants and animals to thrive undisturbed.

Petit Bois Island is shrinking. In order to preserve it, the U.S. Army Corp of Engineers dredged sand from the island's shipping channel to create a new island, called West Petit Bois Island. As West Petit Bois Island continues to grow, plant and animal life are finding its way to the island. The impermanence and ever-changing environments of barrier islands are what make them so unique.
audioDescription: A great place to see fish, bird watch, or camp on an undistrubed beach, this island is only accessible by boat. West Petit Bois Island is a barrier island located off the coast of Mississippi, Southeast of Davis Bayou. The island is designated a wilderness area which provides protection for plants and animals to thrive undisturbed. Petit Bois Island is shrinking. In order to preserve it, the U.S. Army Corp of Engineers dredged sand from the island's shipping channel to create a new island, called West Petit Bois Island. As West Petit Bois Island continues to grow, plant and animal life are finding its way to the island. The impermanence and ever-changing environments of barrier islands are what make them so unique.

title: Wildlife Signatures
listingDescription: Think of this area as a woodland pantry full of insects, reptiles, bird eggs, and carrion that attract a variety of small mammals. Squirrels, otters, armadillos, and mice usually search for food during daylight. Raccoons, skunks, foxes, and opossums commonly rest during the day and forage at night. You may not see them, but look for footprints, scat, nibbled bark, and other signs of their presence.

images.altText: Metal framed National Park Service panel with the title, "Wildlife Signatures." Boardwalk through trees in the background.
images.caption: Wildlife Signatures Site

bodyText: Think of this area as a woodland pantry full of insects, reptiles, bird eggs, and carrion that attract a variety of small mammals. Squirrels, otters, armadillos, and mice usually search for food during daylight. Raccoons, skunks, foxes, and opossums commonly rest during the day and forage at night. You may not see them, but look for footprints, scat, nibbled bark, and other signs of their presence.
audioDescription:
510 words
The boardwalk with its wood curbs makes a broad "s" curve here through the dense woods on either side. Sunlight peeps its way through the foliage overhead, but both sides are thick with small tree trunks, shrubs and saw palmetto. At the side of the walk is a slanted graphic panel with touchable models of animal footprints.

This panel has two parts. The top half is a graphic panel with text and photographs. The bottom half has touchable models of animal footprints along with labels in raised lettering and in braille.

Text at the top left of the panel reads,

"Think of this area as a woodland pantry full of insects, reptiles, bird eggs, and carrion that attract a variety of small mammals. Squirrels, otters, armadillos, and mice usually search for food during daylight. Raccoons, skunks, foxes, and opossums commonly rest during the day and forage at night. You may not see them, but look for footprints, scat, nibbled bark, and other signs of their presence."

To the right are photographs of five animals common in this woodland. Across the top, beginning at the left is an eastern mole. The small mammal peers out from a hole in the dirt covered with thick gray fur except for its smooth pointed snout and its longs claws on its front feet.

Next is a racoon, perched on the edge of a hole in a tree trunk. He looks at us with his black mask, white nose and brown and black ringed tail.

At the right is an eastern gray squirrel sitting on a tree branch. Its body is gray with a white underbelly and its long busy tail makes an "S" curve over its back.

Below these are two more pictures. At left is a gray fox trotting across a stony patch in tall grass. Its pointed nose is black and it has a red patch behind its ears. Its long bushy tail has a black band down its top.

The final picture shows a Virginia opossum. It clings to a narrow branch. It has a white face and pointed snout with a pink tip. Its body has thick gray fur but its tail is furless and whip-like.

A label invites you to touch the footprint impressions below of a few mammal species that live in the coastal plain.

Beginning at bottom left are mole footprints. The front foot on top is wider, almost round, while the rear foot below is long and narrow.

Next are gray fox prints. These are similar to dog footprints, with a central pad and four large toes on each foot.

Next is a racoon, similar to a tiny human's hand and foot, only slightly longer and with longer toes.

Next is the gray squirrel. Its prints are like the racoon's but smaller and narrower.

The final set of prints are from an opossum. Its front print is roughly rectangular with the five pointed toes prints spread wide. The hind foot is long and has one to separate from the rest, like a mitten.

End of Description.

title: William M. Colmer Visitor Center
listingDescription: A great place to start your visit to the Davis Bayou Area or the Mississippi islands. Explore indoor exhibits about the shore and the islands. An observation deck is located around the back of the building.

images.altText: A blue building with a flag pole and grassy hill in the foreground and green trees and blue sky in the background.
images.caption: Davis Bayou Visitor Center 1

bodyText: A great place to start your visit to the Davis Bayou Area or the Mississippi islands. Explore indoor exhibits, watch a video about the history of the entire Gulf Islands National Seashore, or view wildlife in person from the observation deck located outside the building.
audioDescription: A great place to start your visit to the Davis Bayou Area or the Mississippi islands. Explore indoor exhibits about the shore and the islands. Watch a video about the history of the entire Gulf Islands National Seashore or view wildlife in person from the observation deck is located outside the building.

title: Woodland Nature Trail
listingDescription: Hike a 0.25 mile loop from the Fort Barrancas Visitor Center

images.altText: Wooden framed National Park Service sign next to a smaller brown, sign. A trail and trees in the background.
images.caption: Woodland Trail Site

bodyText:
This trail is a 0.25 mile loop that begins and ends at the Fort Barrancas Visitor Center. Visitors may park at the visitor center and begin the trail to the west. The dirt path is fairly smooth with a sandy base, but can be slippery when wet. Use caution and respect wildlife on the trail. 

Succession in natural communities is the process by which new species of plants and animals become established as conditions change. As trees grow tall in coastal woodlands, they shade out sun-loving plants on the forest floor. Sometimes change occurs rapidly. Winds generated by tropical storms knock down mature trees and strip the leaves from others. This permits sunlight to reach the forest floor again and allows the return of wildflowers, grasses, and mosses.

Duration: 15-30 minutes

Note: This trail is inside Naval Air Station Pensacola, which is currently closed to the public. Visitors must have a military or federal ID to access the base and the Fort Barrancas area. We apologize for the inconvenience.
audioDescription: Fort Barrancas Woodland Nature Trail. 116 words.The entrance to this trail is along the drive that loops in front of the visitor center to the parking area. The dirt path is fairly smooth with a sandy base and a sprinkling of dead leaves, which may be a bit slippery in wet weather. The woods are comprised mostly of small trees with a variety of shrubs filling the understory. The entrance to the visitor center is about 120 feet to the left. Over your left shoulder as you face the face is a display of cannon and mortars. To the right of the trail is a small sign that reads, "Woodland Nature Trail, half mile loop."End of Description.
